title: Six more years of Putin will worry many countries. But not China | CNN
content:
China has paid a price for this. While it claims neutrality, its refusal to condemn the invasion as the US and its allies united to sanction Russia piqued European suspicion about its motivations. It also drew attention to Beijing’s designs on the self-ruling democracy of Taiwan. An annual NATO report released Thursday reflected the bloc’s hardening line on China, with chief Jens Stoltenberg saying Beijing does “not share our values” and “challenges our interests,” while pointing to its increasing alignment with Moscow.
    

            But China’s stance enabled Xi to stay focused on deeper goals: he sees Putin as a crucial partner in the face of rising tensions with the US and in reshaping a world he believes is unfairly dominated by rules and values set by Washington and its allies. A stable relationship with Moscow, too, allows Beijing to focus on other areas of concern such as Taiwan and the South China Sea.
    

            “Xi sees Putin as a genuine strategic partner,” said Steve Tsang, director of the SOAS China Institute at the University of London, ahead of the Russian election results, adding that anything less than a landslide win for Putin would be “a disappointment” for Beijing.
    

            Xi, who has centralized control over his own nation like no Chinese leader since Mao Zedong, won’t be alone among leaders applauding Putin’s renewed grip on power.
    

            Kim Jong Un of North Korea recently met Putin in Russia’s Far East during a rare overseas trip that Washington says focused on Moscow buying munitions from Pyongyang.
    

            For Kim, that tightening bond is a major opportunity to strengthen his struggling economy as he continues weapons development in the face of increased coordination between the US and South Korea. The North Korean leader swiftly congratulated Putin on his win Monday, according to the country’s state media.

title: 普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮
content:
俄罗斯大选历时三天的投票星期天（3月17日）进入最后一天，现任总统弗拉迪米尔·普京（Vladimir Putin）在消除异己打压异议之后，即使没有开票就已经稳获压倒性“胜利”。但是被禁止参选的反对派仍在呼吁民众在投票日最后一天的中午前往投票所表达象征性的示威抗议。

现年71岁的普京1999年首度出任俄罗斯总统，如果他能把未来六年新的总统任期做完，那他在位时间不仅超越苏联时期的独裁者斯大林，而且成为俄罗斯过去200多年主政时间最长的领导人。
据法新社周日最新报道，在莫斯科的一些投票所外，周日中午许多人响应抗议呼吁排起长队。俄罗斯当局已经在十几个城市抓捕了至少74位抗议选举投票的俄罗斯人。 

此次大选进行之际，普京以“特别军事行动”之名对邻国乌克兰无端发动的大规模侵略战争刚刚进入第三个年头。这是二战以来欧洲发生的最大规模、伤亡最惨重的一场战争。

路透社周日报道，就在俄罗斯民众走向投票所的三天里，俄乌两军的激烈交锋也如影随形。

俄罗斯周日称，乌克兰对俄罗斯广泛地区发动了35架无人机袭击，包括针对莫斯科，引发一个炼油厂发生大火，另外一些地区断电。

俄罗斯萨马拉州州长星期六表示，当地两家炼油厂遭到乌克兰无人机袭击并引发大火，但是没有造成人员伤亡。

同一天，俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州州长也对外表示，州府别尔哥罗德市当天遭到乌军部队的炮击，导致两人丧生，三人受伤。这位州长还在社媒上贴文说，由于来自乌克兰的袭击增多，州政府已经决定当地的购物中心在星期日和星期一两天不营业，学校也将在星期一二两天停课。
translation:
The three-day voting in Russia's general election entered the final day on Sunday (March 17). After eliminating dissidents and suppressing dissent, the current President Vladimir Putin has secured an overwhelming "victory" even without counting the votes. But the opposition, which is banned from running in the election, is still calling on people to go to the polls at noon on the last day of voting to express symbolic protests.

The 71-year-old Putin first became the president of Russia in 1999. If he can complete his new presidential term in the next six years, his reign will not only surpass Stalin, the dictator of the Soviet Union, but also become the longest ruler of Russia in the past 200 years. The longest leader.
According to the latest report from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, many people lined up in long lines outside some polling stations in Moscow at noon on Sunday in response to calls for protests. Russian authorities have arrested at least 74 Russians protesting against the electoral vote in more than a dozen cities. 

At the time of this election, Putin's unprovoked large-scale aggressive war against neighboring Ukraine in the name of "special military operations" has just entered its third year. This is the largest war with the deadliest casualties in Europe since World War II.

Reuters reported on Sunday that in the three days as Russians went to the polls, fierce confrontations between the Russian and Ukrainian armies also followed.

Russia said on Sunday that Ukraine had launched 35 drone attacks across a wide range of Russia, including Moscow, causing a fire at an oil refinery and cutting power to other areas.

The governor of Russia's Samara region said on Saturday that two local oil refineries were attacked by Ukrainian drones and caused fires, but there were no casualties.

On the same day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod region also stated that the city of Belgorod, the state capital, was shelled by Ukrainian troops that day, killing two people and injuring three others. The governor also posted on social media that due to the increase in attacks from Ukraine, the state government has decided that local shopping malls will be closed on Sunday and Monday, and schools will also be closed on Monday and Tuesday.

The governor of Russia's Samara region said on Saturday that two local oil refineries were attacked by Ukrainian drones and caused fires, but there were no casualties.

On the same day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod region also stated that the city of Belgorod, the state capital, was shelled by Ukrainian troops that day, killing two people and injuring three others. The governor also posted on social media that due to the increase in attacks from Ukraine, the state government has decided that local shopping malls will be closed on Sunday and Monday, and schools will also be closed on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Putin may be the biggest dupe of his fake election landslide – POLITICO
content:
u201cThe most important outcome of any Russian election is legitimacy,” Vladimir Putin told Russia’s top election officials when they gathered at his residence outside Moscow in November. “That is the foundation of political stability.”
On Sunday, after three days of voting, those same officials declared a landslide victory for the president, giving him a record 87 percent of the vote. 
There is no doubt that Putin will use the outcome as proof of mass support. But such a distorted election — in which all challengers were crushed and even the dead may have voted for him — risks undermining the political stability he craves. 
This election was a historic low for post-Soviet Russia. 
“Over the years, the presidential administration has created more and more favorable conditions for itself,” David Kankiya, of independent monitoring group Golos, told POLITICO. “But this time it reached an unprecedented peak.”
Even without taking into account the crackdown on the opposition, the vote was the least competitive in Russia’s modern history: Only three Kremlin candidates separated Putin from a Stalin-style ballot with one name.  
It was also the least transparent: Never before have there been so few independent observers with so little access (tellingly, the head of Golos is in jail.)
And in another first, in some 29 regions, including those most prone to protest, voting took place electronically, described by independent election monitors as a “black box” method designed to facilitate vote tampering. 
But perhaps the most flagrant violation in “this landscape of illegality,” says Ekaterina Schulmann, a Russian political analyst at the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center in Berlin, has been a voting army of “dead souls.”
This is especially true of votes cast from the “new territories” occupied by Russia in Ukraine, where electoral authorities said there were some 4.6 million potential voters. That figure is in line with old Ukrainian statistics from peacetime, but hardly corresponds to the current population.

title: Putin wins Russia election in landslide with no serious competition
content:
Putin said Russia might need to create a buffer zone inside Ukraine to prevent such attacks in future.
While Putin’s re-election was not in doubt given his control over Russia and the absence of any real challengers, the former KGB spy had wanted to show he had the overwhelming support of Russians.
Nationwide turnout was 74.22% at 1800 GMT when polls closed, election officials said, surpassing 2018 levels of 67.5%.
There was no independent tally of how many of Russia’s 114 million voters took part in the opposition demonstrations, amid tight security involving tens of thousands of police and security officials.
Reuters journalists saw an increase in the flow of voters, especially younger people, at noon at polling stations in Moscow, St Petersburg and Yekaterinburg, with queues of several hundred people and even thousands.
Some said they were protesting, though there were few outward signs to distinguish them from ordinary voters.
At least 74 people were arrested on Sunday across Russia, according to OVD-Info, a group that monitors crackdowns on dissent.
Over the previous two days, there were scattered incidents of protest as some Russians set fire to voting booths or poured green dye into ballot boxes. Opponents posted some pictures of ballots spoiled with slogans insulting Putin.
But Navalny’s death has left the opposition deprived of its most formidable leader, and other major opposition figures are abroad, in jail or dead.
The West casts Putin as an autocrat and a killer. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Sunday that Putin wanted to rule forever and that the vote had been illegitimate.
Putin portrays the war as part of a centuries-old battle with a declining West that he says humiliated Russia after the Cold War by encroaching on Moscow’s sphere of influence.
Russia’s election comes at what Western spy chiefs say is a crossroads for the Ukraine war and the wider West.
Support for Ukraine is tangled in U.S. domestic politics ahead of the November presidential election.
Though Kyiv recaptured territory after the invasion in 2022, Russian forces have made gains after a failed Ukrainian counter-offensive last year.

title: Putin thanks Russia after predictable win
content:
Riot police kept demonstrators apart as Isaac Herzog attended the opening of a Holocaust museum in Amsterdam.
The climbers got stuck 2,300m (7,500ft) up Monte Mondolè on Saturday.
President Vladimir Putin thanks Russians for putting their trust in him as he celebrates his election win.
Videos on social media show a large bear bounding down the pavement before lunging at a man.
The volcanic eruption on the Reykjanes Peninsula is the fourth since December.
Kaja Kallas says Putin is "afraid" of a war with Nato in an interview with the BBC.
Footage from the Reykjanes Peninsula shows bright orange lava erupting into the air.
Russian officials say several people have been arrested for vandalism on the first day of voting in the presidential election.
A far-left activist group took responsibility for the fire, which left the plant without power for nearly a week.
The footage shows the suspect of a gun attack at two bars travelling through the city and the scenes that followed.
The Magura V5 sea drone has been used to sink five Russian ships to date, Ukraine says
The taoiseach (Irish Prime Minister) says "it is clear" that two referendums have been defeated.
Ros Atkins looks at Germany's week of uncomfortable questions, after top-secret discussions were made public.
A 19th-century printing press sealed the amendment into the constitution on International Women’s Day.
Environmentalists in Germany have occupied part of a forest earmarked for clearance.
Hundreds of people line up to pay their respects at the Russian opposition leader's grave in Moscow.
Risking arrest, large numbers paid tribute to the Putin critic, who died in an Arctic prison.
Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was buried at a cemetery on the outskirts of Moscow
Yulia Navalnaya addresses MEPs after the death of her husband, a high-profile critic of Putin.
Yulia Navalnaya was speaking to members of the European Parliament.

title: 普京有望再次高票当选俄罗斯总统 | TRT  中文
content:
土耳其宗教事务局和土耳其宗教基金会 (TDV) 准备的斋月援助包已交付给格鲁吉亚有需要的家庭。
                        

                            法国国防部表示，俄罗斯有关“法国准备向乌克兰派遣2000名士兵”的说法并不属实。
                        

                            尼日利亚军方报告称，在扎姆法拉州和尼日尔州开展的空中行动中消灭了多名恐怖分子。
                        

                            俄罗斯总统府克里姆林宫发言人佩斯科夫表示，他们正在密切关注北约在南高加索地区日益增加的接触活动。
translation:
Ramadan aid packages prepared by the Turkish Religious Affairs Authority and the Turkish Religious Foundation (TDV) have been delivered to families in need in Georgia.
                        

                            The French Ministry of Defense stated that Russia's statement that "France is preparing to send 2,000 troops to Ukraine" is not true.
                        

                            The Nigerian military reported the elimination of multiple terrorists during air operations in Zamfara and Niger states.
                        

                            Kremlin spokesman Peskov said they are paying close attention to NATO's increasing contacts in the South Caucasus.
input:
Ramadan aid packages prepared by the Turkish Religious Affairs Authority and the Turkish Religious Foundation (TDV) have been delivered to families in need in Georgia.
                        

                            The French Ministry of Defense stated that Russia's statement that "France is preparing to send 2,000 troops to Ukraine" is not true.
                        

                            The Nigerian military reported the elimination of multiple terrorists during air operations in Zamfara and Niger states.
                        

                            Kremlin spokesman Peskov said they are paying close attention to NATO's increasing contacts in the South Caucasus.

title: Russians vote on 2nd day of election predetermined to reelect Putin for another term | PBS NewsHour
content:
Meanwhile, a video released on social media by Russian election monitoring group Golos appeared to show staff at a polling station in the southern city of Krasnodar stuffing multiple voting slips into ballot boxes.
Also Saturday, Ukrainian drone and missile attacks once again hit deep inside the country. Tass said an armed group also tried to penetrate Russia’s border region from Ukraine.
Two people were killed in Ukrainian shelling of the Russian border city of Belgorod, regional Gov. Vyacheslav Gladkov said on Telegram, ordering shopping centers and schools to shut down because of the security situation. Meanwhile, local officials denied reports of explosions at polling stations in the border city, Tass said.
Dozens of people have been killed in Belgorod since the war began.
READ MORE: Russia says Ukrainian shelling killed 2 in Belgorod while it thwarted a border incursion
Elsewhere, a Ukrainian drone attack caused a fire at an oil refinery belonging to Russian oil company Rosneft in the Samara region, 1,065 kilometers (660 miles) southeast of Moscow, the regional governor said.
One person was killed and four other people were wounded in the city of Kakhovka in the illegally annexed Kherson region of Ukraine, the Russia-installed governor Vladimir Saldo said, blaming a Ukrainian drone attack that he said was aimed at disrupting the election.
Earlier, Tass reported that a Ukrainian drone also dropped an explosive on a polling station in the illegally annexed Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine.
In the period leading up to the vote, Putin boasted about battlefield successes in Ukraine, where Russian troops have recently made incremental gains relying on their edge in firepower.
On Friday, Putin described the week’s cross-border shelling and incursions by Ukrainian forces as an attempt by Ukraine to frighten Russians and derail the vote. He vowed that the attacks “won’t be left unpunished.”
Despite the attacks, analysts say the Kremlin needs a high turnout in the election to signal that Russians approve of the war and to legitimize Putin for another term.
The Russian defense ministry has served as a key growth engine, working around the clock to churn out missiles, tanks and ammunition and cushioning Russians from the economic impact of the war — driving down unemployment and driving up wages. Russia’s wartime economy has also proven to be resilient, expanding despite bruising Western sanctions.
Russia’s opposition movement has urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to show up at the polls at noon Sunday, the final day of voting, as a form of protest. The strategy was endorsed by Navalny not long before his death.
Voting is taking place at polling stations across Russia’s 11 time zones, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine, and online.
Western leaders have derided the vote as a travesty of democracy.
European Council President Charles Michel mockingly congratulated Putin on Friday on “his landslide victory” in an election that was technically still underway. “No opposition. No freedom. No choice,” he wrote on the social media platform X.
Beyond the lack of options for voters, the possibilities for independent monitoring are very limited. No significant international observers were present. Only registered, Kremlin-approved candidates — or state-backed advisory bodies — can assign observers to polling stations, decreasing the likelihood of independent watchdogs.

title: Putin wins Russia election in landslide with no serious competition
content:
Putin told supporters in a victory speech in Moscow that he would prioritise resolving tasks associated with what he called Russia’s “special military operation” in Ukraine and would strengthen the Russian military.
“We have many tasks ahead. But when we are consolidated - no matter who wants to intimidate us, suppress us - nobody has ever succeeded in history, they have not succeeded now, and they will not succeed ever in the future,“ said Putin.
Supporters chanted “Putin, Putin, Putin” when he appeared on stage and “Russia, Russia, Russia” after he had delivered his acceptance speech.
Inspired by opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, thousands of opponents protested at noon against Putin at polling stations inside Russia and abroad.
Putin told reporters he regarded Russia’s election as democratic and said the Navalny-inspired protest against him had had no effect on the election’s outcome.
In his first comments on his death, he also said that Navalny’s passing had been a “sad event” and confirmed that he had been ready to do a prisoner swap involving the opposition politician.
When asked by a NBC, a U.S. TV network, whether his re-election was democratic, Putin criticised the U.S. political and judicial systems.
“The whole world is laughing at what is happening (in the United States),“ he said. “This is just a disaster, not a democracy.”
“...Is it democratic to use administrative resources to attack one of the candidates for the presidency of the United States, using the judiciary among other things?” he asked, making an apparent reference to four criminal cases against Republican candidate Donald Trump.
The Russian election comes just over two years since Putin triggered the deadliest European conflict since World War Two by ordering the invasion of Ukraine.
War has hung over the three-day election: Ukraine has repeatedly attacked oil refineries in Russia, shelled Russian regions and sought to pierce Russian borders with proxy forces - a move Putin said would not be left unpunished.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Доставалось и самим оппозиционерам. Так, в Москве арестовали девушку, которая испортила бюллетени зеленкой, а в Петербурге - активистку, бросившую "коктейль Молотова" в двери участка. Всего, по данным МВД, за три дня голосования были задержаны более 85 протестующих и составлено 155 протоколов об административных правонарушениях. Среди них - активисты, пытавшиеся испортить бюллетени или напасть на избирательные участки. Впрочем, власти расценили эти инциденты как провокации и попытки дискредитировать выборы. В ответ на эти происшествия на избирательных участках, зампред Совбеза РФ Дмитрий Медведев пригрозил привлечь всех причастных к ответственности по статье о госизмене - 275 УК.

Депутаты тоже оперативно отреагировали и сейчас разрабатывают законопроект об ужесточении наказания за попытку сорвать выборы. В законопроекте предполагается лишение свободы на срок от пяти до восьми лет.
translation:
The oppositionists themselves also suffered. Thus, in Moscow, a girl was arrested for spoiling ballot papers with brilliant green, and in St. Petersburg, an activist was arrested for throwing a Molotov cocktail at the door of a polling station. In total, according to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, over three days of voting, more than 85 protesters were detained and 155 reports of administrative offenses were drawn up. Among them are activists who tried to spoil ballots or attack polling stations. However, the authorities regarded these incidents as provocations and attempts to discredit the elections. In response to these incidents at polling stations, Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev threatened to bring all those involved to justice under the article on treason - 275 of the Criminal Code.

Deputies also reacted quickly and are now developing a bill to toughen penalties for attempting to disrupt the elections. The bill envisages imprisonment for a term of five to eight years.
input:
The oppositionists themselves also suffered. Thus, in Moscow, a girl was arrested for spoiling ballot papers with brilliant green, and in St. Petersburg, an activist was arrested for throwing a Molotov cocktail at the door of a polling station. In total, according to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, over three days of voting, more than 85 protesters were detained and 155 reports of administrative offenses were drawn up. Among them are activists who tried to spoil ballots or attack polling stations. However, the authorities regarded these incidents as provocations and attempts to discredit the elections. In response to these incidents at polling stations, Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev threatened to bring all those involved to justice under the article on treason - 275 of the Criminal Code.

Deputies also reacted quickly and are now developing a bill to toughen penalties for attempting to disrupt the elections. The bill envisages imprisonment for a term of five to eight years.

title: Putin wins again but what happened in Russia’s election protests? | Vladimir Putin | Al Jazeera
content: Russia’s President Vladimir Putin claimed a record landslide victory in an election without serious opposition – but many voters got round the crackdown on dissent to take part in a mass protest on polling day.
input: Russia’s President Vladimir Putin claimed a record landslide victory in an election without serious opposition – but many voters got round the crackdown on dissent to take part in a mass protest on polling day.

title: «Угроза для Европы и мира». Что пишут зарубежные СМИ о победе Путина на выборах
content:
Путин собирается использовать свой новый шестилетний срок для дальнейшего укрепления контроля над российской политикой и продолжения военных действий на Украине, Если он останется у власти до конца этого срока, то его правление станет самым продолжительным со времен Екатерины Великой.

Издание называет прошедшие выборы "наименее прозрачными" в новейшей истории России, поскольку работа независимых наблюдателей "сократилась до уровня, невиданного со времен распада Советского Союза".

По мнению редакции NYT, Кремль рассматривает эти выборы "как ритуал, имеющий решающее значение для представления Путина о себе как о подлинно народном лидере". Аналитики ожидают, что теперь российский президент будет продвигать активных сторонников военных действий в правительстве, делая ставку на то, что западная поддержка Украины в конце концов рухнет и Киеву придется вести мирные переговоры на условиях России.

По мнению политологов, российскому лидеру нужно выглядеть крупным победителем, если он хочет получить "полную свободу действий" в возрождении консервативных православных традиций России, а также, в конечном итоге, одержать верх над Украиной и в более широкой конфронтации с Западом, пишет издание. По прогнозу WSJ, в центре внимания пятого срока Путина будут военные действия на Украине и обеспечение их поддержки среди россиян.
translation:
Putin intends to use his new six-year term to further tighten his grip on Russian politics and continue military action in Ukraine. If he remains in power until the end of this term, his reign will be the longest since Catherine the Great.

The publication calls the past elections “the least transparent” in the modern history of Russia, since the work of independent observers “has been reduced to a level not seen since the collapse of the Soviet Union.”

According to the NYT editors, the Kremlin views these elections "as a ritual crucial to Putin's vision of himself as a truly people's leader." Analysts expect the Russian president will now promote military activists within the government, betting that Western support for Ukraine will eventually crumble and Kyiv will be forced to negotiate peace on Russia's terms.

Political analysts say the Russian leader needs to be seen as a big winner if he wants to have "free rein" in reviving Russia's conservative Orthodox traditions and ultimately prevail over Ukraine and the broader confrontation with the West, the newspaper writes. The WSJ predicts that the focus of Putin's fifth term will be on military action in Ukraine and securing Russian support for it.
input:
Putin intends to use his new six-year term to further tighten his grip on Russian politics and continue military action in Ukraine. If he remains in power until the end of this term, his reign will be the longest since Catherine the Great.

The publication calls the past elections “the least transparent” in the modern history of Russia, since the work of independent observers “has been reduced to a level not seen since the collapse of the Soviet Union.”

According to the NYT editors, the Kremlin views these elections "as a ritual crucial to Putin's vision of himself as a truly people's leader." Analysts expect the Russian president will now promote military activists within the government, betting that Western support for Ukraine will eventually crumble and Kyiv will be forced to negotiate peace on Russia's terms.

Political analysts say the Russian leader needs to be seen as a big winner if he wants to have "free rein" in reviving Russia's conservative Orthodox traditions and ultimately prevail over Ukraine and the broader confrontation with the West, the newspaper writes. The WSJ predicts that the focus of Putin's fifth term will be on military action in Ukraine and securing Russian support for it.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获胜几无悬念 | 俄大选 | 大纪元
content:
周五（3月15日），俄罗斯全国11个时区的选民进行投票，拉开了为期三天的俄罗斯大选序幕。外界普遍认为，俄罗斯总统普京赢得连任是几无悬念的事情。这次大选将再“送给”普京六年的执政期。
从距离莫斯科6,300公里（3,900英里）太平洋的楚科奇（Chukotka），到波罗的海与波兰接壤的加里宁格勒（Kaliningrad）飞地，俄罗斯190多个民族中的一些选民参加投票。
尽管普京在2022年发起了欧洲自二战以来最致命的战争，但这位俄总统仍在俄罗斯政治格局中占据主导地位。周五开始的俄罗斯大选中，选票上的其他三位候选人没有一人能够对普京构成任何可信的挑战。这三位候选人分别是新人民党（New People party）的弗拉迪斯拉夫‧达万科夫（Vladislav Davankov）、自由民主党（LDPR）的列昂尼德‧斯卢茨基（Leonid Slutsky）和共产党候选人尼古拉‧哈利托诺夫（Nikolay Kharitonov）。
这些竞争对手被称为“体制内的反对派”。他们被视为是象征性的对手，他们所在政党普遍支持普京领导的政府。CNBC说，将他们列入选票的目的是为了给这次投票带来一定程度的尊重，并为俄罗斯实际上的独裁政治制度提供一种表面上的多元化。
普京预计将轻松拿下第五个任期，这将使他在俄罗斯的统治至少要到2030年。
克里姆林宫表示，普京将获胜，因为他将赢得广泛支持，将俄罗斯从后苏联时代的混乱中拯救出来，并勇敢地面对一个傲慢、敌对的西方。
普京自1999年年底以来一直担任俄罗斯总统或总理。到目前为止，他没有表现出放弃对俄控制的迹象。他得到了忠诚的核心圈子和俄罗斯安全部门的支持。
乌克兰战争的阴影笼罩着这次俄罗斯大选：俄罗斯仍有100多万武装人员在乌克兰1,000公里（600英里）的前线进行激烈战斗。
负责指挥俄罗斯战争工作的国防部长谢尔盖‧绍伊古（Sergei Shoigu）和总参谋长瓦列里‧格拉西莫夫（Valery Gerasimov）在俄罗斯南部军区投票。
超过1.14亿俄罗斯人有资格投票，其中包括被俄罗斯宣称为“新领土”上的选民。2022年10月，俄罗斯宣布吞并4个乌克兰地区。乌克兰表示，在那里举行的俄罗斯选举是非法且无效的。
乌克兰外交部周四（3月14日）在一份声明中表示，俄罗斯试图在其领土上“模仿”总统选举，这表明“俄罗斯联邦继续公然无视国际法规范和原则”。 外交部称，在被俄占领的乌克兰领土投票非法，并敦促这些地区的公民不要参加投票。
分析人士指出，克里姆林宫希望在这次选举中看到高投票率，并希望普京取得重大胜利，以使战争合法化。
咨询公司Teneo中欧和东欧顾问安德烈亚斯‧图尔萨（Andreas Tursa）周四评论说：“克里姆林宫寻求这样一个选举结果：它将显示公众对普京以及他的国内和外交政策议程的压倒性支持。 ”
他补充说：“克里姆林宫正在利用这次选举重申普京的合法性，动员公众支持他的政策，并向外部对手展示团结和决心。”克里姆林宫寻求“压倒性胜利”。
俄罗斯反对派活动人士谴责这次选举。他们中的大多数人为了逃避逮捕、监禁或袭击而逃到海外。已故反对派领导人阿列克谢‧纳瓦尼（Alexei Navalny）的遗孀尤利娅‧纳瓦尔纳亚（Yulia Navalnaya）请求俄罗斯选民投票给“除普京之外的任何候选人”，并号召公民在当地时间3月17日中午集体投票，试图压垮投票所。
她也呼吁西方不要承认选举结果。克里姆林宫的反对者也呼吁国外支持者本周日在俄罗斯大使馆外抗议。
translation:
On Friday (March 15), voters in 11 time zones across Russia went to vote, kicking off the three-day Russian general election. The outside world generally believes that there is little doubt that Russian President Putin will win re-election. This election will "give" Putin another six years of power.
Voters from some of Russia's more than 190 ethnic groups went to the polls, from Chukotka on the Pacific Ocean, 6,300 kilometers (3,900 miles) from Moscow, to the Baltic enclave of Kaliningrad on the border with Poland.
Although Putin launched Europe's deadliest war since World War II in 2022, the Russian president still dominates Russia's political landscape. None of the other three candidates on the ballot in Russia's general election, which begins on Friday, poses any credible challenge to Putin. The three candidates are Vladislav Davankov of the New People party, Leonid Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR) and Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov.
These rivals are known as “institutional opposition.” They are seen as symbolic rivals and their parties generally support Putin's government. CNBC said the purpose of including them on the ballot was to bring a level of respectability to the vote and provide a semblance of pluralism to Russia's de facto authoritarian political system.
Putin is expected to easily win a fifth term, which will keep him in power in Russia until at least 2030.
The Kremlin says Putin will win because he will win widespread support to rescue Russia from post-Soviet chaos and stand up to an arrogant, hostile West.
Putin has been president or prime minister of Russia since late 1999. So far, he has shown no sign of relinquishing control of Russia. He has the support of a loyal inner circle and Russia's security services.
The shadow of the war in Ukraine hangs over this Russian election: Russia still has more than 1 million armed personnel engaged in fierce fighting on Ukraine's 1,000 kilometers (600 miles) front line.
Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov, who are responsible for directing Russia's war efforts, voted in Russia's Southern Military District.
More than 114 million Russians are eligible to vote, including voters in what Russia claims are "new territories." In October 2022, Russia announced the annexation of four Ukrainian regions. Ukraine says the Russian elections held there are illegal and invalid.
Ukraine's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement on Thursday (March 14) that Russia's attempts to "imitate" the presidential election on its territory showed that "the Russian Federation continues to blatantly ignore the norms and principles of international law." The foreign ministry said voting in Ukrainian territories occupied by Russia was illegal and urged citizens in those areas not to vote.
Analysts pointed out that the Kremlin hopes to see high turnout in this election and hopes for a major victory for Putin to legitimize the war.
Andreas Tursa, Central and Eastern Europe consultant at consulting firm Teneo, commented on Thursday: "The Kremlin seeks an election result that will show public overwhelming support for Putin and his domestic and foreign policy agenda. sexual support.”
He added: "The Kremlin is using this election to reaffirm Putin's legitimacy, mobilize public support for his policies and demonstrate unity and resolve to external opponents." The Kremlin seeks a "landslide victory."
Russian opposition activists condemned the election. Most of them fled overseas to avoid arrest, imprisonment or assault. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of late opposition leader Alexei Navalny, asked Russian voters to vote for "any candidate other than Putin" and called on Citizens voted collectively at noon local time on March 17 in an attempt to overwhelm the polling stations.
She also called on the West not to recognize the election results. Kremlin opponents have also called on supporters abroad to protest outside the Russian embassy this Sunday.

The three candidates are Vladislav Davankov of the New People party, Leonid Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR) and Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov.

title: Итоги выборов-2024: Путин побеждает с рекордными результатом и явкой в истории РФ
content:
Итоговая явка избирателей с учетом дистанционного электронного голосования, которое работало в трети регионов, по предварительным данным, составила 74,22%, объявили в ЦИК. Вероятно, эта цифра еще вырастет.

Результаты близки к показателям, к которым, как писали СМИ в преддверии выборов. Явка оказалась самой высокой в истории выборов президента в России.

В 2018 году проголосовали 67,54% избирателей — эту планку нынешние выборы преодолели за несколько часов до закрытия участков в воскресенье. Правда, шесть лет назад выборы длились только один день.

Если верить ЦИК, активно люди голосовали даже в приграничных с Украиной областях, где все три дня выборов продолжались обстрелы. Например, в Белгородской области явка еще в середине дня в воскресенье, по данным российских властей, превысила 83%.

Российские власти утверждают, что на всех новых территориях РФ результаты Путина оказались выше, чем в среднем по стране: в Запорожье, Донецкой и Луганской областях — больше 90%, в Херсонской области — больше 88%.

Стоит отметить, что в ходе выборов были зафиксированы нарушения, а также попытки актов вандализма, которые пресекались представителями правоохранительных органов. Некоторые избиратели намеренно портили бюллетени, писали на них различные надписи.

Так в Петербурге на избирательницу составили протокол о дискредитации армии за надпись «Нет войне» в бюллетене. В Костроме протокол по этой же статье составили на секретаря костромского отделения КПРФ Андрея Тарасова. Он выложил фото бюллетеня с надписью «Нет войне» и зачеркнутым именем Владимира Путина.

Полиция задерживала людей на участках в дни выборов не только за протестные надписи на бюллетенях. Голосование-2024 стало беспрецедентным по числу инцидентов с поджогами и порчей бюллетеней.

Такой вандализм затронул участки по всей стране — в Москве, Санкт-Петербурге, Екатеринбурге, Воронеже, Ростовской области, Краснодарском крае и в других регионах.

Силовики возбуждают уголовные дела по 141-й статье УК — «воспрепятствование осуществлению избирательных прав или работе избирательных комиссий». Максимальное наказание по ней — 5 лет лишения свободы.

Кроме того, на ресурсах дистанционного электронного голосования было заблокировано около 280 тыс. хакерских атак, сообщила председатель ЦИК Элла Памфилова. Но в целом, по оценке председателя ЦИК, серьезных нарушений на выборах не было. «Мы шерстим, сидим, в основном там мусор, высосанный из пальца, ничего нет серьезного, поэтому нечего сейчас разбирать», — сказала она 16 марта.

Несмотря на все это нарушителям не удалось сорвать выборный процесс и они благополучно завершились. Некоторые лидеры государств уже поспешили поздравить Путина с победой на выборах.

Первая телеграмма по случаю победы на выборах пришла в Россию из Таджикистана. Глава Таджикистан Эмомали Рахмон поздравил Владимира Путина с победой ещё до официального окончания подсчёта голосов.
translation:
The final voter turnout, taking into account remote electronic voting, which operated in a third of the regions, according to preliminary data, amounted to 74.22%, the CEC announced. This figure is likely to increase further.

The results are close to the figures that the media wrote on the eve of the elections. The turnout turned out to be the highest in the history of presidential elections in Russia.

In 2018, 67.54% of voters voted - this level was surpassed in the current elections a few hours before the polls closed on Sunday. True, six years ago the elections lasted only one day.

According to the Central Election Commission, people actively voted even in the regions bordering Ukraine, where shelling continued throughout the three election days. For example, in the Belgorod region the turnout in the middle of the day on Sunday, according to Russian authorities, exceeded 83%.

Russian authorities claim that in all new territories of the Russian Federation, Putin’s results were higher than the national average: in Zaporozhye, Donetsk and Lugansk regions - more than 90%, in the Kherson region - more than 88%.

It is worth noting that during the elections, violations were recorded, as well as attempts at acts of vandalism, which were suppressed by law enforcement officials. Some voters deliberately damaged ballot papers and wrote various inscriptions on them.

So in St. Petersburg, a protocol was drawn up against a voter to discredit the army for writing “No to war” on the ballot. In Kostroma, a protocol under the same article was drawn up against the secretary of the Kostroma branch of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Andrei Tarasov. He posted a photo of a ballot with the words “No to war” and Vladimir Putin’s name crossed out.

The police detained people at polling stations on election days not only for protest inscriptions on ballots. The 2024 vote was unprecedented in the number of incidents of arson and damage to ballots.

Such vandalism affected areas throughout the country - in Moscow, St. Petersburg, Yekaterinburg, Voronezh, Rostov region, Krasnodar region and other regions.

Security forces are opening criminal cases under Article 141 of the Criminal Code - “obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights or the work of election commissions.” The maximum penalty for it is 5 years in prison.

In addition, about 280 thousand hacker attacks were blocked on remote electronic voting resources, said CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova. But in general, according to the chairman of the Central Election Commission, there were no serious violations in the elections. “We are woolly, we are sitting, there is mostly garbage there, sucked out of thin air, there is nothing serious, so there is nothing to sort out now,” she said on March 16.

Despite all this, the violators failed to disrupt the election process and it ended successfully. Some state leaders have already rushed to congratulate Putin on his victory in the elections.

The first telegram on the occasion of the victory in the elections came to Russia from Tajikistan. The head of Tajikistan, Emomali Rahmon, congratulated Vladimir Putin on his victory even before the official end of the vote count.

Security forces are opening criminal cases under Article 141 of the Criminal Code - “obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights or the work of election commissions.” The maximum penalty for it is 5 years in prison.

In addition, about 280 thousand hacker attacks were blocked on remote electronic voting resources, said CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova. But in general, according to the chairman of the Central Election Commission, there were no serious violations in the elections. “We are woolly, we are sitting, there is mostly garbage there, sucked out of thin air, there is nothing serious, so there is nothing to sort out now,” she said on March 16.

Despite all this, the violators failed to disrupt the election process and it ended successfully. Some state leaders have already rushed to congratulate Putin on his victory in the elections.

The first telegram on the occasion of the victory in the elections came to Russia from Tajikistan. The head of Tajikistan, Emomali Rahmon, congratulated Vladimir Putin on his victory even before the official end of the vote count.

title: 被建议新任期海外首访去中国，普京：一定会考虑
content:
（观察者网讯）据俄罗斯塔斯社19日报道，当地时间周二晚些时候，俄罗斯总统普京表示，他考虑选择中国作为其新一届总统任期开启后的首个外访目的地。


	报道称，当天与俄国家杜马各党派领导人开会时，普京被建议新任期开始后首访北京，他笑着表示“一定会考虑，不开玩笑。”


	另据路透社20日援引5名匿名知情人士消息报道称，普京或计划于今年5月访华。克里姆林宫对此回应称，普京海外出访的具体信息将在行程临近时发布。





3月17日，俄总统选举投票结束后，普京召开记者会感谢选民信任和支持 图自澎湃影像


	当地时间3月17日，俄罗斯总统大选落下帷幕。根据初步统计，现任总统普京以超过87%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，赢得此次选举，获得连任。


	据路透社报道，总统就职典礼将于5月7日左右举行，此后普京新总统任期内的首次海外之行也将提上日程。有外国外交官和观察员表示，他们预计普京连任后的第一站将是中国。


	报道称，5名据称熟悉内情的消息人士透露，普京将于今年5月前往北京与中国领导人举行会谈。其中一人称，此次中国之行可能会在5月下旬启程。


	俄罗斯总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫对此回应表示，“目前正在准备几次总统访问和高层接触。我们会在（活动）临近时通知大家。”


	塔斯社报道中提到，当地时间周二举行的俄罗斯国家杜马各党派领导人会议上，俄联邦共产党中央委员会主席久加诺夫向普京提议将北京作为海外访问的首选。“我希望您的首次访问是去东方，而不是西方。”塔斯社引述其发言称。


	据报道，普京微笑着回答他：“我一定会考虑你刚才说的话，不开玩笑。”


	路透社指出，俄中近来关系密切，普京最近一次访华是在去年10月受邀出席中方举办的第三届“一带一路”国际合作高峰论坛。这是自俄乌冲突爆发以来，普京首次访问全球主要大国，引发外界密集关注。
translation:
(Observer Network News) According to a report by Russia's TASS news agency on the 19th, late on Tuesday local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that he would consider choosing China as the destination for his first foreign visit after the start of his new presidential term.


According to reports, during a meeting with the leaders of various parties in the Russian State Duma that day, Putin was suggested to visit Beijing for the first time after the start of his new term. He smiled and said that he would "definitely consider it, no joke."


Reuters reported on the 20th, citing five anonymous sources, that Putin may plan to visit China in May this year. The Kremlin responded by saying that specific information about Putin's overseas trip will be released as the trip approaches.





On March 17, after the voting in the Russian presidential election, Putin held a press conference to thank voters for their trust and support. Picture from The Paper


On March 17, local time, the Russian presidential election came to an end. According to preliminary statistics, current President Putin won the election and was re-elected with a vote rate of more than 87%, significantly leading other candidates.


According to Reuters, the presidential inauguration will be held around May 7, and Putin’s first overseas trip during his new presidential term will also be on the agenda. Some foreign diplomats and observers said they expected Putin's first stop after his re-election would be China.


According to the report, five sources said to be familiar with the situation revealed that Putin will go to Beijing to hold talks with Chinese leaders in May this year. One of them said that the trip to China may start in late May.


Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov responded, "We are currently preparing for several presidential visits and high-level contacts. We will inform everyone as (the event) approaches."


TASS reported that at the Russian State Duma party leaders’ meeting held on Tuesday local time, Zyuganov, chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, proposed to Putin that Beijing should be his first choice for overseas visits. "I hope your first visit will be to the East, not the West." TASS quoted him as saying.


Putin reportedly responded to him with a smile: "I will definitely consider what you just said, no joke."


Reuters pointed out that Russia and China have recently had close relations. Putin's most recent visit to China was in October last year when he was invited to attend the third "Belt and Road" International Cooperation Summit Forum hosted by China. This is Putin's first visit to a major global power since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which has aroused intense attention from the outside world.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Что будет после выборов
Инаугурация избранного президента должна состояться 7 мая (по истечении шести лет со дня вступления в должность президента, победившего на предыдущих выборах). В тот же день правительство подаст в отставку. В 2018 году Путин уже в день инаугурации внес кандидатуру Дмитрия Медведева на пост главы правительства. Госдума утвердила того премьером на следующий день, 8 мая. Состав кабинета министров Медведев представил президенту через десять дней, 18 мая.

После реформы Конституции кандидатуры большинства министров в Госдуму внесет премьер-министр. Президент же предложит кандидатов на посты руководителей спецслужб, МВД, МИД и Минобороны, проведя консультации по ним с Советом Федерации.
translation:
What will happen after the elections
The inauguration of the elected president should take place on May 7 (six years from the date of the inauguration of the president who won the previous election). The government will resign on the same day. In 2018, Putin nominated Dmitry Medvedev for the post of head of government on the day of his inauguration. The State Duma confirmed him as prime minister the next day, May 8. Medvedev presented the composition of the cabinet of ministers to the president ten days later, on May 18.

After the reform of the Constitution, the Prime Minister will nominate the majority of ministers to the State Duma. The President will propose candidates for the posts of heads of the special services, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defense, having consulted on them with the Federation Council.
input:
What will happen after the elections
The inauguration of the elected president should take place on May 7 (six years from the date of the inauguration of the president who won the previous election). The government will resign on the same day. In 2018, Putin nominated Dmitry Medvedev for the post of head of government on the day of his inauguration. The State Duma confirmed him as prime minister the next day, May 8. Medvedev presented the composition of the cabinet of ministers to the president ten days later, on May 18.

After the reform of the Constitution, the Prime Minister will nominate the majority of ministers to the State Duma. The President will propose candidates for the posts of heads of the special services, the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defense, having consulted on them with the Federation Council.

title: 普京胜选
content: 据央视新闻客户端消息,俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间17日晚宣布,在已统计的60.01%的俄总统选举选票中,现任总统普京得票率为87.26%。据俄总统选举法,获半数以上选票者当选。俄罗斯现任总统普京当地时间18日凌晨召开记者会说,感谢选民信任和支持,他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
translation: According to CCTV news client, the Russian Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th local time that among the 60.01% of the Russian presidential election votes that had been counted, the current President Vladimir Putin received 87.26% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election law, the person who gets more than half of the votes is elected. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the 18th local time and said that he was grateful to voters for their trust and support and that he would continue to promote national development in his new term.
input: According to CCTV news client, the Russian Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th local time that among the 60.01% of the Russian presidential election votes that had been counted, the current President Vladimir Putin received 87.26% of the votes. According to Russian presidential election law, the person who gets more than half of the votes is elected. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the 18th local time and said that he was grateful to voters for their trust and support and that he would continue to promote national development in his new term.

title: Putin Extends Rule in Preordained Russian Election After Harshest Crackdown Since Soviet Era | Military.com
content:
Among those heeding the call was Yulia Navalnaya, Navalny’s widow, who spent more than five hours in the line at the Russian Embassy in Berlin. She told reporters that she wrote her late husband’s name on her ballot.
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: “Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he’s a killer, he’s a gangster.”
A voter in Moscow, who identified himself only as Vadim, said he hoped for change, but added that “unfortunately, it’s unlikely.” Like others, he didn’t give his full name because of security concerns.
Meanwhile, supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
Putin brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest and rejected Western criticism of the vote as he tried to turn the tables on the West, charging that the four criminal cases against U.S. Republican candidate Donald Trump were a use of the judiciary for political aims and describing denigrating democracy in the U.S. as a “catastrophe.”
“The whole world is laughing at it,” he said.
Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference, declaring that he was ready to release him in a swap for unidentified inmates in Western custody just days before the opposition leader's death.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, “I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now.”
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while a few others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes. Many more were rounded up by police for attempting to protest.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that about 90 people were arrested in 22 cities across Russia on Sunday.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said Russians were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
That left little room for people to express themselves. Still, huge lines formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
“If we have some option to protest I think it’s important to utilize any opportunity,” said 23-year-old Tatiana, who was voting in the Estonian capital of Tallinn and said she came to take part in the protest.
input:
Among those heeding the call was Yulia Navalnaya, Navalny’s widow, who spent more than five hours in the line at the Russian Embassy in Berlin. She told reporters that she wrote her late husband’s name on her ballot.
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: “Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he’s a killer, he’s a gangster.”
A voter in Moscow, who identified himself only as Vadim, said he hoped for change, but added that “unfortunately, it’s unlikely.” Like others, he didn’t give his full name because of security concerns.
Meanwhile, supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
Putin brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest and rejected Western criticism of the vote as he tried to turn the tables on the West, charging that the four criminal cases against U.S. Republican candidate Donald Trump were a use of the judiciary for political aims and describing denigrating democracy in the U.S. as a “catastrophe.”
“The whole world is laughing at it,” he said.
Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference, declaring that he was ready to release him in a swap for unidentified inmates in Western custody just days before the opposition leader's death.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, “I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now.”
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while a few others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes. Many more were rounded up by police for attempting to protest.
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that about 90 people were arrested in 22 cities across Russia on Sunday.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said Russians were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
That left little room for people to express themselves. Still, huge lines formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine.
“If we have some option to protest I think it’s important to utilize any opportunity,” said 23-year-old Tatiana, who was voting in the Estonian capital of Tallinn and said she came to take part in the protest.

title: Six more years of Putin will worry many countries. But not China | CNN
content:
Putin, for his part, has painted BRICS as part of a growing movement eclipsing the established order, including in terms of economic heft.
    

            “There is no getting away from this objective reality, and it will remain that way no matter what happens next, including even in Ukraine,” he said during his state of the union address late last month.
    

            Then he underscored a view he’ll likely want both friend and foe to consider as he enters his new term: “No enduring international order is possible without a strong and sovereign Russia.”
    

            But that doesn’t mean countries tied to Moscow aren’t also watching the conflict in Ukraine carefully. That may be especially true for China, Russia’s most powerful strategic partner.
    

            Chinese state media credulously reported the election results Monday with official news agency Xinhua highlighting Putin’s promise to continue to promote “national development,” while another state media headline hailed Russia’s “steadily advancing political process.”
    

            Coverage also noted Putin’s comments on China made during a news conference Sunday night, where he pointed to the “coinciding of state interests” between the two countries and reiterated his backing of Beijing’s claim over the self-ruling democracy of Taiwan.
    

            China has reaped significant benefit from the war and stands to continue doing so – as long as it doesn’t trend toward a Russian defeat.
    

            Chinese buyers lapped up record levels of Moscow’s crude oil in 2023, while exports of items such as cars and household electronics to Russia expanded since the invasion, buoying trade to a record high and boosting Chinese yuan-denominated transactions.
    

            Xi has used the war in Ukraine as a platform to pitch his own, albeit vague, alternative system for global security, while a diluted focus of the US government is good news for China.

            Xi has used the war in Ukraine as a platform to pitch his own, albeit vague, alternative system for global security, while a diluted focus of the US government is good news for China.

title: Путин набрал рекордные 87% — и теперь его сравнивают с азиатскими диктаторами. Мы узнали, что об этом думают в Кремле
content:
Согласно официальным итогам президентских выборов (на момент этой публикации ЦИК обработал 99,79% протоколов), Владимир Путин набрал 87,3% при явке 77,4%. Это рекорд для современной России: и по количеству голосов за победителя, и по общей явке. Более того, Путин набрал больше, чем когда-либо насчитывали Александру Лукашенко, — и вплотную приблизился к рекордам автократов из Центральной Азии, которые обычно набирают на выборах больше 90%.

Политический блок администрации президента (АП) РФ действительно превысил поставленные перед этими выборами KPI. Как ранее неоднократно писала «Медуза», перед региональными администрациями АП ставила задачу добиться от 80% за Путина и явки больше 70%. В распоряжении «Медузы» есть предвыборная стратегия, составленная в руководстве одного из регионов РФ: в этом документе цель на выборы обозначена именно так. Достичь этой цели планировалось в первую очередь за счет мобилизации бюджетников и сотрудников компаний, близких к государству.

Вместе с тем, по словам двух региональных чиновников, пообщавшихся с «Медузой» на условиях анонимности, в последние недели перед выборами из АП стали поступать «пожелания, чтобы плюс к 80% [за Путина] был побольше». В результате показатель в 80% стал восприниматься как абсолютный минимум, а многие регионы стали ориентироваться на 85%. Собеседник «Медузы», близкий к АП, подчеркнул, что глава внутриполитического блока Сергей Кириенко действительно «хотел показать президенту очень высокие цифры — что он и сделал».

Впрочем, политтехнолог, работающий с администрацией одного из регионов РФ, в разговоре с «Медузой» выделил еще один фактор настолько высокого результата Путина: «Это Дальний Восток. Там подводят итоги раньше, а потом другие регионы хотят показать лучшие цифры. Планку они задали ого-го». Действительно, в большинстве регионов, входящих в Дальневосточный федеральный округ, Путин набрал больше 85%. 80% голосов он получил только в Хабаровском крае — этот регион, который еще не так давно возглавлял Сергей Фургал, в АП считают традиционно протестным.

Чиновник, работающий в одном из дальневосточных регионов, рассказал «Медузе», что на 85% за Путина местные администрации сориентировало президентское полпредство. В Дальневосточном федеральном округе его возглавляет вице-премьер Юрий Трутнев: «Он хотел показать, что Дальний Восток — опора президента, а не протестная территория. Показал, что скажешь».

При этом в Кремле не видят проблемы в таком высоком высоком результате Путина. Два близких к АП источника «Медузы» подчеркнули, что Кириенко доволен итогами выборов — и не считает их «перегибом или нарисованной клюквой». По словам собеседника «Медузы», близкого к руководству «Единой России», Кириенко уже лично обзвонил большинство российских губернаторов и поблагодарил их за помощь на выборах.

«Кто бы что ни говорил — „перекидали“, „переборщили“, — за победу не наказывают. Высшему руководителю нравится. Он воспринимает это как реальную поддержку. СВК [Сергей Кириенко] умеет ему это подать и продать. Это главное», — подчеркнул один из источников, близких к Кремлю.

Собеседник, близкий к АП отдельно обратил внимание на итоги выборов в Москве. В столице Владимир Путин, по официальным данным, набрал больше 85% голосов, то есть ненамного меньше, чем в среднем по стране: «Раньше было отставание — в прошлую кампанию более чем на 5%. Теперь Москва образцовый лояльный регион. [Мэр Сергей] Собянин может продать президенту это как свое достижение — усмирил столицу».

Второе место на выборах занял коммунист Николай Харитонов (он набрал чуть больше 4%). Третьим с незначительным отставанием стал кандидат от «Новых людей» Владислав Даванков (за него призывали голосовать многие российские оппозиционеры как за наиболее либерального кандидата). Последнее место занял лидер ЛДПР Леонид Слуцкий, набравший немногим больше 3%.

Изначально в АП рассчитывали, что вторым станет именно Слуцкий, но тот провалил кампанию — а идти на значительные фальсификации ради его относительного успеха в Кремле не решились. В день выборов собеседники «Медузы», близкие к президентской администрации, говорили, что второе место, скорее всего, займет Даванков, — однако указывали, что шансы есть и у Харитонова.

«Даванкову бы не мешали [стать вторым]. Во многих регионах он действительно вышел на второе место, но не дотянул. А за Харитонова пришел кондовый электорат КПРФ. Плюс он был комфортнее для администраций южных регионов и нацреспублик, которым Даванков непонятен», — пояснил источник, близкий к Кремлю. По его словам, прогосударственные СМИ, тем не менее, будут позиционировать результат Харитонова как поражение КПРФ, которая получила «рекордно низкий результат и не дотянула до 10%».

В целом же, как уже писала «Медуза», кремлевские администраторы не очень беспокоились, кто именно займет второе место по стране: «Харитонову тоже не мешали. Занял и занял. Второе место с 4% — это не второе место с 10%. Все [кандидаты] одинаково слабые. Кроме первого».
translation:
According to the official results of the presidential elections (at the time of this publication, the Central Election Commission had processed 99.79% of the protocols), Vladimir Putin won 87.3% with a turnout of 77.4%. This is a record for modern Russia: both in terms of the number of votes for the winner and in overall turnout. Moreover, Putin polled more than Alexander Lukashenko ever did - and came very close to the records of Central Asian autocrats, who usually poll more than 90%.

The political bloc of the Russian Presidential Administration (AP) actually exceeded the KPIs set before these elections. As Meduza has repeatedly written before, the AP set the task for regional administrations to achieve 80% for Putin and a turnout of more than 70%. Meduza has at its disposal an election strategy drawn up by the leadership of one of the regions of the Russian Federation: in this document, the goal for the elections is indicated exactly like this. It was planned to achieve this goal primarily through the mobilization of public sector employees and employees of companies close to the state.

At the same time, according to two regional officials who spoke to Meduza on condition of anonymity, in the last weeks before the elections the Administration began to receive “wishes for the plus to 80% [for Putin] to be larger.” As a result, the figure of 80% began to be perceived as an absolute minimum, and many regions began to focus on 85%. Meduza’s interlocutor, close to the Presidential Administration, emphasized that the head of the internal political bloc, Sergei Kiriyenko, really “wanted to show the president very high numbers - which is what he did.”

However, a political strategist working with the administration of one of the regions of the Russian Federation, in a conversation with Meduza, highlighted another factor in Putin’s high result: “This is the Far East. They sum up the results earlier, and then other regions want to show better numbers. They set the bar wow.” Indeed, in most regions included in the Far Eastern Federal District, Putin scored more than 85%. He received 80% of the votes only in the Khabarovsk Territory - this region, which was not so long ago headed by Sergei Furgal, is considered traditionally a protest region in the AP.

An official working in one of the Far Eastern regions told Meduza that the presidential embassy was 85% in favor of Putin. In the Far Eastern Federal District, it is headed by Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Trutnev: “He wanted to show that the Far East is the president’s support, and not a protest territory. Showed me what you have to say.”

At the same time, the Kremlin does not see a problem with Putin’s such a high result. Two Meduza sources close to the AP emphasized that Kiriyenko is satisfied with the election results - and does not consider them “an excess or a painted cranberry.” According to Meduza’s interlocutor, close to the leadership of United Russia, Kiriyenko has already personally called most of the Russian governors and thanked them for their help in the elections.

“No matter what anyone says - ‘they overshot’, ‘overdid it’ - they are not punished for winning. The senior manager likes it. He perceives this as real support. SVK [Sergei Kiriyenko] knows how to present and sell it to him. This is the main thing,” emphasized one of the sources close to the Kremlin.

An interlocutor close to the AP drew special attention to the results of the elections in Moscow. In the capital, Vladimir Putin, according to official data, received more than 85% of the vote, that is, not much less than the national average: “Previously there was a lag - in the last campaign by more than 5%. Now Moscow is an exemplary loyal region. [Mayor Sergei] Sobyanin can sell this to the president as his achievement - he pacified the capital.”

Communist Nikolai Kharitonov took second place in the elections (he scored a little more than 4%). The third, with a slight lag, was the candidate from the “New People” Vladislav Davankov (many Russian oppositionists called for voting for him as the most liberal candidate). The last place was taken by the leader of the LDPR Leonid Slutsky, who scored a little more than 3%.

Initially, the AP hoped that Slutsky would become the second, but he failed the campaign - and they did not dare to make significant falsifications for the sake of his relative success in the Kremlin. On election day, Meduza’s interlocutors close to the presidential administration said that Davankov would most likely take second place, but indicated that Kharitonov also had a chance.

“Davankov would not be prevented [from becoming second]. In many regions, he actually came in second place, but fell short. And the crazy electorate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation came for Kharitonov. Plus, he was more comfortable for the administrations of the southern regions and national republics, which did not understand Davankov,” explained a source close to the Kremlin. According to him, pro-state media, however, will position Kharitonov’s result as a defeat for the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, which received “a record low result and did not reach 10%.”

In general, as Meduza already wrote, the Kremlin administrators were not very worried about who exactly would take second place in the country: “Kharitonov was not interfered with either. Borrowed and occupied. Second place with 4% is not second place with 10%. All [candidates] are equally weak. Except the first one.

title: Putin may be the biggest dupe of his fake election landslide – POLITICO
content:
“It’s obvious that in times of war, people get killed, they move away,” says Schulmann. 
“There’s a war going on there and zero public oversight,” agreed Kankiya, adding that residents did not even need a Russian passport to vote. “So whatever result the authorities decided on, they got. We’re entering the sphere of pure fiction here.” 
Then there were the tens of million of state employees and students who were coerced into voting. 
Paradoxically, the queues which could be seen outside some polling stations on Friday — the day most were assigned to vote on, presumably to give election officials more time to tweak the result to satisfactory levels —  were in fact a display of people “stripped of their voting rights,” said Kankiya. 
“Like in Soviet  times, when you were forced to vote, whether you wanted to or not.” 
Across the country at polling stations people dressed in costume, presumably to infuse the election with some joy. But no carnival of animals could distract from the groups of identically dressed factory workers, fishermen and men on horseback who showed up to cast their ballots at exactly the same time.
“I’m convinced that an absolute majority of Russians won’t have much faith in the results of this vote,” said Kankiya.
Although a glaringly obvious circus, the Kremlin might not care that much.
Rather than a gauge of public sentiment, elections under Putin resemble a  nationwide test of readiness for the state apparatus. And this time, like last time, it passed. 
From state companies to libraries, universities and factories, superiors instructed their lower downs how and when to vote and then harassed them for evidence they had completed the task. 
Even at the highest level, none of Putin’s three supposed rivals dared to even pretend they were going for the win. 
The past three days of voting have provided Putin with the assurance that the power vertical is in place and Russians will do as they are told. 
For the Kremlin that is useful confirmation ahead of what many predict will be turbulent times.

“Like in Soviet  times, when you were forced to vote, whether you wanted to or not.”

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
相比之下，根据俄罗斯国家统计局2023年9月的数据，俄罗斯全国平均月薪为7.09万卢布（约合人民币5587元）。
俄乌冲突爆发后，作为合同兵的萨沙便被立即派往冲突前线。两年来，萨沙很少有假期，长期与家人分离，至今仍在前线参与战斗。
随着冲突延宕，前线士兵的待遇成为了备受俄罗斯各界关注的问题。2023年2月，普京在国情咨文讲话中表示，考虑到特别军事行动参与者面临巨大的身体和心理压力，每天都面对着健康和生命危险，应当为其提供至少每6个月一次、每次至少14天的定期休假，以便每个士兵都有机会探亲访友。
当年6月，普京签令为被授予“俄罗斯英雄”称号及其他勋章的特别军事行动参与者以及参与过行动的退伍军人免费发放土地。这一命令不适用于莫斯科、圣彼得堡以及克里米亚地区的塞瓦斯托波尔，但普京要求当地提供其他社会支持方案。
2024年2月，普京在俄罗斯总统大选前夕的国情咨文中再度强调，俄罗斯的未来将在很大程度上取决于参与特别军事行动的士兵的勇气和决心，他们应在教育、商业和国家行政部门担任领导职务，能够优先在一流大学接受高等教育和专业教育，并且能够在俄武装部队中获得优先晋升的权利。
每每谈及战争，安德烈的感受总是十分复杂和矛盾。他坦言，有些人自愿去了前线，其中一些人是为了丰厚的报酬。但在他看来，人们不会只因为钱就去死亡阴影笼罩的前线。
至于自己的朋友，安德烈无奈地说，他别无选择，但也清楚自己的使命。
相较于一直在前线战斗的萨沙而言，安德烈的另一位朋友伊利亚似乎更为幸运。几年前，伊利亚在读完11年级的课程后便进入部队服义务兵役。伊利亚是一名优秀的拳击手，由于自己的身体素质很好，再加上部队的待遇不错，伊利亚在服完义务兵役后成为了一名合同兵。
2022年2月前，伊利亚在合同到期后离开了军队，因而没有被派往前线，而他的一个战友在战争前几个月刚刚延长了自己的合同。不幸的是，伊利亚的战友最终牺牲在前线，死于一枚贯穿了胃部的弹片。去世的时候，他只有25岁。
“伊利亚去参加了他战友的葬礼，当时他很悲伤。战争太可怕了，双方的人都在死去……我当然希望当局能够在不开战的情况下通过谈判解决问题，但我也能理解普京为何这样做，因为他别无选择。”安德烈说道。
translation:
In comparison, according to data from the Russian State Statistics Service in September 2023, the average monthly salary in Russia is 70,900 rubles (approximately RMB 5,587).
After the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, Sasha, a contract soldier, was immediately sent to the front line of the conflict. For two years, Sasha rarely had a vacation, was separated from his family for long periods of time, and is still fighting on the front lines.
As the conflict drags on, the treatment of frontline soldiers has become a matter of concern to all walks of life in Russia. In February 2023, Putin stated in his State of the Union address that considering that participants in special military operations face tremendous physical and psychological pressure and face risks to their health and life every day, they should be provided with medical assistance at least once every six months and every day. A regular leave of at least 14 days so that each soldier has the opportunity to visit relatives and friends.
In June of that year, Putin signed an order to distribute free land to participants of special military operations who were awarded the title of "Hero of Russia" and other medals, as well as veterans who participated in the operations. The order does not apply to Moscow, St. Petersburg and Sevastopol in the Crimea region, but Putin requested other social support packages there.
In February 2024, Putin once again emphasized in his State of the Union address on the eve of the Russian presidential election that Russia's future will largely depend on the courage and determination of soldiers participating in special military operations. They should serve in education, business and state administration. Holding a leadership position will give priority to higher education and professional education at first-class universities, and priority for promotion in the Russian Armed Forces.
Whenever he talks about war, Andre's feelings are always very complicated and contradictory. He admitted that some people voluntarily went to the front line, some of them for generous rewards. But in his opinion, people will not go to the front line where the shadow of death is looming just because of money.
As for his friends, Andre said reluctantly that he had no choice, but he also knew his mission.
Compared to Sasha, who has been fighting on the front line, Andre's other friend Ilya seems to be luckier. A few years ago, Ilya entered the army to perform compulsory military service after completing 11th grade courses. Ilya is an excellent boxer. Due to his good physical fitness and good treatment in the army, Ilya became a contract soldier after completing his compulsory military service.
Before February 2022, Ilya left the army after his contract expired and was therefore not sent to the front line, while one of his comrades had just extended his contract a few months before the war. Unfortunately, Ilya's comrade died on the front line from a shrapnel that penetrated his stomach. He was only 25 years old when he died.
"Ilya went to the funeral of his comrade and he was very sad. The war was terrible, people were dying on both sides... I certainly hope that the authorities can solve the problem through negotiations without going to war, but I can also understand Why Putin does this is because he has no choice," Andrei said.

After the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, Sasha, a contract soldier, was immediately sent to the front line of the conflict. For two years, Sasha rarely had a vacation, was separated from his family for long periods of time, and is still fighting on the front lines.
As the conflict drags on, the treatment of frontline soldiers has become a matter of concern to all walks of life in Russia. In June of that year, Putin signed an order to distribute free land to participants of special military operations who were awarded the title of "Hero of Russia" and other medals, as well as veterans who participated in the operations. The order does not apply to Moscow, St. Petersburg and Sevastopol in the Crimea region, but Putin requested other social support packages there.
In February 2024, Putin once again emphasized in his State of the Union address on the eve of the Russian presidential election that Russia's future will largely depend on the courage and determination of soldiers participating in special military operations. They should serve in education, business and state administration. Holding a leadership position will give priority to higher education and professional education at first-class universities, and priority for promotion in the Russian Armed Forces.
