Before February 2022, Ilya left the army after his contract expired and was therefore not sent to the front line, while one of his comrades had just extended his contract a few months before the war. Unfortunately, Ilya's comrade died on the front line from a shrapnel that penetrated his stomach. He was only 25 years old when he died.
"Ilya went to the funeral of his comrade and he was very sad. The war was terrible, people were dying on both sides... I certainly hope that the authorities can solve the problem through negotiations without going to war, but I can also understand Why Putin does this is because he has no choice," Andrei said.

title: Putin Extends Rule in Preordained Russian Election After Harshest Crackdown Since Soviet Era | Military.com
content:
Independent media have been crippled. His fiercest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month, and other critics are either in jail or in exile.
Beyond the fact that voters had virtually no choice, independent monitoring of the election was extremely limited.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with nearly 100% of precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin, his highest vote tally ever.
Western leaders denounced the election as a sham, while President Volodymyr Zelenskyy particularly criticized voting in Ukrainian areas that Russia has illegally annexed, saying "everything Russia does on the occupied territory of Ukraine is a crime.”
Germany sharply criticized the vote with Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokeswoman, Christina Hoffmann, saying that “in our opinion, it was not a democratic election.”
“There is no freedom of expression in Russia,” she told reporters in Berlin. “Russia, as the chancellor has already said, is now a dictatorship and is ruled by Vladimir Putin in an authoritarian manner.”
Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis also said the exercise didn't deserve the name "election.”
“It’s a procedure that is supposed to resemble elections,” he said. "Some might call it reappointment, lacking any legitimacy.”
Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un quickly congratulated Putin, along with some Central and South American leaders and presidents of nations that have historic and close current ties to Russia, such as Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.
In the tightly controlled environment, Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to go to the polls at noon on Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.
input:
Independent media have been crippled. His fiercest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic prison last month, and other critics are either in jail or in exile.
Beyond the fact that voters had virtually no choice, independent monitoring of the election was extremely limited.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with nearly 100% of precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote. Central Election Commission chief Ella Pamfilova said that nearly 76 million voters cast their ballots for Putin, his highest vote tally ever.
Western leaders denounced the election as a sham, while President Volodymyr Zelenskyy particularly criticized voting in Ukrainian areas that Russia has illegally annexed, saying "everything Russia does on the occupied territory of Ukraine is a crime.”
Germany sharply criticized the vote with Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokeswoman, Christina Hoffmann, saying that “in our opinion, it was not a democratic election.”
“There is no freedom of expression in Russia,” she told reporters in Berlin. “Russia, as the chancellor has already said, is now a dictatorship and is ruled by Vladimir Putin in an authoritarian manner.”
Lithuanian Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis also said the exercise didn't deserve the name "election.”
“It’s a procedure that is supposed to resemble elections,” he said. "Some might call it reappointment, lacking any legitimacy.”
Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un quickly congratulated Putin, along with some Central and South American leaders and presidents of nations that have historic and close current ties to Russia, such as Azerbaijan, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan.
In the tightly controlled environment, Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to go to the polls at noon on Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.

title: The Guardian view on Russia’s election: in Stalin’s footsteps | Editorial | The Guardian
content:
One of the curiosities of the Soviet Union was the serious weight its leaders attached to holding elections. In a dictatorship, why bother? Academic studies concluded that ensuring a 99% vote share for the only candidate on the ballot was a useful tool for civic mobilisation, and a way of isolating and intimidating anyone who aspired to a real democratic choice.
Under the repressive, paranoid leadership of Vladimir Putin, Russians are going back to the future. Mr Putin’s 87% landslide in Russia’s presidential election – the highest percentage in any post-Soviet poll – confirms that, almost a quarter of a century after he first entered the Kremlin, the resumption of a form of totalitarian control is all but complete. Having changed the constitution to ensure he can continue to rule, a further victory in 2030 would see him surpass Stalin’s 31 years of dictatorial power.
In a less shamelessly rigged contest, Mr Putin would probably have come out on top regardless. But this laughable margin of victory sends its own menacing message. The limited space for dissent and political competition that existed in the first years of his rule has disappeared. The three Kremlin-approved “rival” candidates in the race made no attempt to win it. Two popular anti-war figures who could have hurt Mr Putin at the polls were excluded on technicalities. Alexei Navalny, the charismatic opposition leader who caused him trouble in 2018, died last month in mysterious circumstances in a brutal penal colony.
In this dismal transition from authoritarianism to outright autocracy, Russia’s illegal war in Ukraine is playing a vital catalytic role. Mr Putin originally envisaged his “special military operation” as a short and triumphant walkover. But the grinding attrition that has actually transpired, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of lives, has left him steeped in blood. Internal repression and the promise of eventual victory in a forever war with the west are being deployed to keep any backlash at bay.
Ignoring his own advisers, Mr Putin made the war the central theme of the campaign. Attacks on civil society organisations, journalists and academics are portrayed as patriotic necessities in the midst of an existential struggle with the west. Protest has been effectively criminalised, and legislation introduced allowing dissenting Russian citizens to be designated as “foreign agents”. Plans to recruit veterans into government, and ominous warnings directed at supposedly parasitic urban elites, point to the aggressive militarisation of a society being placed on a permanent war footing.
As the Kremlin’s belief that it can “outlast” the west’s support for Ukraine grows, the situation of Russia’s democratic opposition is undeniably bleak. But Sunday’s defiant “Noon against Putin” protests – at which long midday queues of voters formed in an attempt to overload some polling stations – at least allowed opponents of the war and a murderous regime to feel less isolated and powerless. In the medium term, organisers must hope similar actions can keep the flame of resistance alive, and that the west will offer what assistance it can to their cause.
The dissident sociologist Boris Kagarlitsky, who was recently sentenced to five years’ imprisonment in a penal colony, wrote last year: “The people to whom this regime poses the most terrible threat is (aside from the Ukrainians, who are bombarded daily by shells and missiles) the Russians themselves, their people and culture, their future.” This mockery of an election has grimly underlined his point.
input:
One of the curiosities of the Soviet Union was the serious weight its leaders attached to holding elections. In a dictatorship, why bother? Academic studies concluded that ensuring a 99% vote share for the only candidate on the ballot was a useful tool for civic mobilisation, and a way of isolating and intimidating anyone who aspired to a real democratic choice.
Under the repressive, paranoid leadership of Vladimir Putin, Russians are going back to the future. Mr Putin’s 87% landslide in Russia’s presidential election – the highest percentage in any post-Soviet poll – confirms that, almost a quarter of a century after he first entered the Kremlin, the resumption of a form of totalitarian control is all but complete. Having changed the constitution to ensure he can continue to rule, a further victory in 2030 would see him surpass Stalin’s 31 years of dictatorial power.
In a less shamelessly rigged contest, Mr Putin would probably have come out on top regardless. But this laughable margin of victory sends its own menacing message. The limited space for dissent and political competition that existed in the first years of his rule has disappeared. The three Kremlin-approved “rival” candidates in the race made no attempt to win it. Two popular anti-war figures who could have hurt Mr Putin at the polls were excluded on technicalities. Alexei Navalny, the charismatic opposition leader who caused him trouble in 2018, died last month in mysterious circumstances in a brutal penal colony.
In this dismal transition from authoritarianism to outright autocracy, Russia’s illegal war in Ukraine is playing a vital catalytic role. Mr Putin originally envisaged his “special military operation” as a short and triumphant walkover. But the grinding attrition that has actually transpired, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of lives, has left him steeped in blood. Internal repression and the promise of eventual victory in a forever war with the west are being deployed to keep any backlash at bay.
Ignoring his own advisers, Mr Putin made the war the central theme of the campaign. Attacks on civil society organisations, journalists and academics are portrayed as patriotic necessities in the midst of an existential struggle with the west. Protest has been effectively criminalised, and legislation introduced allowing dissenting Russian citizens to be designated as “foreign agents”. Plans to recruit veterans into government, and ominous warnings directed at supposedly parasitic urban elites, point to the aggressive militarisation of a society being placed on a permanent war footing.
As the Kremlin’s belief that it can “outlast” the west’s support for Ukraine grows, the situation of Russia’s democratic opposition is undeniably bleak. But Sunday’s defiant “Noon against Putin” protests – at which long midday queues of voters formed in an attempt to overload some polling stations – at least allowed opponents of the war and a murderous regime to feel less isolated and powerless. In the medium term, organisers must hope similar actions can keep the flame of resistance alive, and that the west will offer what assistance it can to their cause.
The dissident sociologist Boris Kagarlitsky, who was recently sentenced to five years’ imprisonment in a penal colony, wrote last year: “The people to whom this regime poses the most terrible threat is (aside from the Ukrainians, who are bombarded daily by shells and missiles) the Russians themselves, their people and culture, their future.” This mockery of an election has grimly underlined his point.

title: Putin cultivates leader for life image in landslide win without competition - The Washington Post
content:
The protest spoiled Putin’s picture of overwhelming popularity and showed that many Russians are still fired up by Navalny’s dream of a free and democratic Russia.
The noon protest, however, posed no threat to the regime. Nor did other displays of frustration, including a flood of photos of ballots spoiled with anti-Putin slogans posted on Russian social media.
Official tallies outside Russia, where Putin was beaten by little-known candidate Vladislav Davankov in cities such as Warsaw, Prague, The Hague and Yerevan, Armenia, highlighted the extent to which the Russian opposition has been forced into exile.
Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, who has accused Putin of ordering the murder of her husband, attended a protest in Berlin. On Monday, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov dismissed Navalnaya and her allegations.
“There are a lot of people who are completely detached from their homeland,” Peskov said. “Yulia Navalnaya you mentioned belongs to the camp of those people who are losing their roots, losing ties with their homeland, losing their understanding of their homeland and ceasing to feel the pulse of their country.”
Amid his late-night elation, Putin dismissed Western criticism of the election in comments that offered insight into the real problem of nearly a quarter-century of Putin’s rule. He craves the legitimacy that democracy offers, but he fears democracy’s safeguards against corruption and abuses, as well as its accountability.
“What did you want? For them to stand up and applaud?” he said, portraying the criticisms as just part of a Western military war against Russia. “They set themselves the goal of restraining our development. Of course, they will tell you whatever they want.”
But the path he has taken — war against Ukraine, isolation and repression of all opposition — forces Russia into a cycle of repression and harsher authoritarianism. To survive, Putin needs the energizing effect of a mobilized militaristic, nationalist minority to cow internal dissent and reinforce the regime.
“The level of repression is already very high,” said Andrei Kolesnikov, senior fellow at the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center. “The war of attrition is continuing, and any other methods of conducting it are not really being reviewed.”
Russia’s Central Election Commission, which routinely bars genuine opposition candidates from running against Putin and airbrushes manipulations, announced the turnout at more than 77 percent. Putin attributed this to the unifying impact of the war, in comments that highlighted the benefit to the regime of an extended conflict and its mobilizing effect on hard-line nationalists.
“This is linked to the dramatic nature of events that Russia is going through, linked to the present-day situation, linked to the fact that we are forced to literally protect the interests of our citizens, our people, with arms in hands and create the future for a full-fledged, sovereign and safe development of Russia, our motherland,” Putin said in his late-night news conference. “The results, and primarily turnout, show that common people feel this and understand that very many things depend on them.”

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
在2024年15-17日举行的俄罗斯大选中，据俄罗斯中央选举委员会网站当地时间3月18日发布的最新信息，全部选票均已计票完成，初步数据显示，现任总统普京获得76277708张选票，得票率为87.28%。
“俄罗斯终于变得更像俄罗斯了”
2018年的上一次总统大选时，2014年所谓的“克里米亚效应”早已经消失，大选没有在村子里引起什么波澜。但今年情况完全不同了。除了号召大家去投票的大选海报，更加随处可见的是与“特别军事行动”相关的元素：圣乔治丝带（俄罗斯为纪念卫国战争胜利而创造的一种丝带）、征兵广告、俄罗斯和苏联旗帜等等。
乌克兰社会学家沃洛迪米尔·伊申格此前告诉澎湃新闻，俄乌冲突爆发后，不少西方学者和媒体聚焦乌克兰一方的民众动员。出于鼓舞乌方士气的需要，自下而上的民众组织支援前线的活动被重点关注。这些民间热情并非为乌方独享。实际上，有社会学调查显示，莫斯科和圣彼得堡以外的一些俄农村地区具有类似强度的战时爱国情绪。
由于A村的学校缺乏教师，尼基塔要承担的远不止英语课的教学任务。他来自首都，见多识广，还曾经多次出国旅行，于是校长让他同时给孩子们上地理和历史课。
“一开始我想，不就是初中的文科基础课嘛，有什么难教的，还能多赚点工资。所以我一口答应下来。但后来事实证明我的想法还是太简单了。”尼基塔说。
尼基塔口中的“难”并不是说初中教材内容有何艰深之处，而是教师难以把握授课时的叙事方向。随着与西方关系的紧张，俄罗斯基础教育阶段中的历史教学也发生了一些微妙的变化。
尼基塔自觉是个对自己祖国历史怀着自豪之情的人。
translation:
In the Russian general election held from 15 to 17 days in 2024, according to the latest information released on the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes. The vote rate was 87.28%.
“Russia is finally becoming more like Russia”
During the last presidential election in 2018, the so-called "Crimea effect" of 2014 had long since disappeared, and the election did not cause any ripples in the village. But this year things are completely different. In addition to general election posters calling on everyone to vote, elements related to "special military operations" can be seen everywhere: St. George ribbons (a ribbon created by Russia to commemorate the victory in the Great Patriotic War), recruitment advertisements, Russian and Soviet flags etc.
Ukrainian sociologist Volodymyr Ischenger previously told The Paper that after the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, many Western scholars and media focused on the popular mobilization on the Ukrainian side. In order to boost the morale of the Ukrainian side, bottom-up activities of popular organizations to support the front line have been focused on. These folk enthusiasms are not exclusive to Ukraine. In fact, sociological surveys show that some rural areas in Russia outside Moscow and St. Petersburg had wartime patriotic sentiments of similar intensity.
Due to the lack of teachers in the school in Village A, Nikita has to shoulder far more than just teaching English classes. He was from the capital, well-informed and had traveled abroad many times, so the principal asked him to give geography and history classes to the children at the same time.
"At first I thought, isn't it just a basic liberal arts course in junior high school? Nothing difficult to teach, and I can earn more salary. So I agreed. But later it turned out that my idea was too simple." Nikita said .
The “difficulty” Nikita refers to does not mean that the content of junior high school textbooks is difficult, but that it is difficult for teachers to grasp the narrative direction during teaching. As relations with the West become tense, some subtle changes have also taken place in the teaching of history in Russia's basic education.
Nikita considers himself a person who is proud of the history of his country.
input:
In the Russian general election held from 15 to 17 days in 2024, according to the latest information released on the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes. The vote rate was 87.28%.
“Russia is finally becoming more like Russia”
During the last presidential election in 2018, the so-called "Crimea effect" of 2014 had long since disappeared, and the election did not cause any ripples in the village. But this year things are completely different. In addition to general election posters calling on everyone to vote, elements related to "special military operations" can be seen everywhere: St. George ribbons (a ribbon created by Russia to commemorate the victory in the Great Patriotic War), recruitment advertisements, Russian and Soviet flags etc.
Ukrainian sociologist Volodymyr Ischenger previously told The Paper that after the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out, many Western scholars and media focused on the popular mobilization on the Ukrainian side. In order to boost the morale of the Ukrainian side, bottom-up activities of popular organizations to support the front line have been focused on. These folk enthusiasms are not exclusive to Ukraine. In fact, sociological surveys show that some rural areas in Russia outside Moscow and St. Petersburg had wartime patriotic sentiments of similar intensity.
Due to the lack of teachers in the school in Village A, Nikita has to shoulder far more than just teaching English classes. He was from the capital, well-informed and had traveled abroad many times, so the principal asked him to give geography and history classes to the children at the same time.
"At first I thought, isn't it just a basic liberal arts course in junior high school? Nothing difficult to teach, and I can earn more salary. So I agreed. But later it turned out that my idea was too simple." Nikita said .
The “difficulty” Nikita refers to does not mean that the content of junior high school textbooks is difficult, but that it is difficult for teachers to grasp the narrative direction during teaching. As relations with the West become tense, some subtle changes have also taken place in the teaching of history in Russia's basic education.
Nikita considers himself a person who is proud of the history of his country.

title: “快把普京照片拿下来！”-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
俄罗斯总统大选落幕，俄罗斯总统普京再次连任。俄罗斯中央选举委员会（CEC）今（18）日公布的资料显示，普京获得超过 87.85% 的选票，其他候选人获得 2.97% 至 3.86%的选票。对该选举不满的纳瓦尼（Alexei Navalny）遗孀尤莉雅（Yulia Navalnaya），于当地时间 17 日参加反普京行动。
据报道，身为俄罗斯反对派领袖纳瓦尼遗孀的尤莉雅，参与了“中午反普京”（Noon Against Putin）行动。该活动举办地点为柏林的俄罗斯大使馆。反对派也号召民众到俄罗斯投票地点抗议当局。
事实上在俄罗斯当局禁止 2 名反战候选人参选的情况下，普京可说是没有实质性对手，几乎肯定会赢得选举。对于俄罗斯这样的选举情况，有网友调侃说：“俄罗斯此次选举共有这 4 位候选人。”，并配上候选人全是普京的恶搞图。

值得注意的是，俄罗斯投票站的工作人员，还在国际观察员到来前，进行小动作。X（前推特）帐号乌克兰战争．最新进展发文指出，多个俄罗斯投票站都在国际观察员到来前，纷纷将普京的肖像移除。
影片显示，俄罗斯投票站的工作人员透过梯子到达普京肖像悬挂处后，将该肖像摘下。
translation:
The Russian presidential election ended, and Russian President Vladimir Putin was re-elected. Data released by the Russian Central Election Commission (CEC) today (18th) showed that Putin received more than 87.85% of the votes, and other candidates received 2.97% to 3.86% of the votes. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of Alexei Navalny, who was dissatisfied with the election, participated in anti-Putin actions on the 17th local time.
According to reports, Yulia, who is the widow of Russian opposition leader Navalny, participated in the "Noon Against Putin" operation. The event takes place at the Russian Embassy in Berlin. The opposition also called on people to protest against the authorities at polling locations in Russia.
In fact, with the Russian authorities banning two anti-war candidates from running, Putin has no real opponents and is almost certain to win the election. Regarding the election situation in Russia, some netizens joked: "There are four candidates in this election in Russia.", and accompanied it with a spoof picture of all the candidates being Putin.

It is worth noting that Russian polling station staff also performed small actions before the arrival of international observers. X (former Twitter) account Ukraine war. According to the latest development, many Russian polling stations have removed Putin's portraits before the arrival of international observers.
The video shows workers at a Russian polling station reaching the place where Putin's portrait hung via a ladder and taking it off.
input:
The Russian presidential election ended, and Russian President Vladimir Putin was re-elected. Data released by the Russian Central Election Commission (CEC) today (18th) showed that Putin received more than 87.85% of the votes, and other candidates received 2.97% to 3.86% of the votes. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of Alexei Navalny, who was dissatisfied with the election, participated in anti-Putin actions on the 17th local time.
According to reports, Yulia, who is the widow of Russian opposition leader Navalny, participated in the "Noon Against Putin" operation. The event takes place at the Russian Embassy in Berlin. The opposition also called on people to protest against the authorities at polling locations in Russia.
In fact, with the Russian authorities banning two anti-war candidates from running, Putin has no real opponents and is almost certain to win the election. Regarding the election situation in Russia, some netizens joked: "There are four candidates in this election in Russia.", and accompanied it with a spoof picture of all the candidates being Putin.

It is worth noting that Russian polling station staff also performed small actions before the arrival of international observers. X (former Twitter) account Ukraine war. According to the latest development, many Russian polling stations have removed Putin's portraits before the arrival of international observers.
The video shows workers at a Russian polling station reaching the place where Putin's portrait hung via a ladder and taking it off.

title: Putin’s vote share nears outer limits but still the only way is up | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
Alexander Baunov, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center, said the numbers marked “the final break with western conventions”.
He said: “The first part of Putin’s rule took place with the tacit recognition of western rules … [but] 85% when elected for a fifth term is a complete sovereignisation of numbers, a turn to the east and one of the ways to communicate that the Russian regime now operates according to laws that are not even superficially related to the western ones.”
The elections were also about stabilising Putin’s rule at home, where the greatest threat to his government may come not from a democratic opposition but instead from conservative forces or even those in his own government, whom he has entrusted with running Russia’s vast security and state apparatus.
Noble called the election result an “important signalling mechanism to various audiences, including, most importantly, the elite. The message is that Putin is still firmly in control and able to secure a thumping electoral victory, including through the use of various types of manipulation. That will likely dissuade members of the elite from thinking about a post-Putin world, for now.”
There will be a post-election hangover as the populist measures taken by the government to control prices for petrol and food are relaxed. (Major breweries have already warned retailers that prices for beer will soon rise by 8-15%.)
Abbas Gallyamov, a former Putin speechwriter, said the “parties are over, the work week is beginning. Soon, people will begin to get a stronger feeling that they have been fooled: they promised one thing but they are slipping something completely different.”
But the Kremlin will cajole, coerce or falsify those votes again in 2030, and then again perhaps by 2036, when Putin will probably seek even higher numbers.

He said: “The first part of Putin’s rule took place with the tacit recognition of western rules … [but] 85% when elected for a fifth term is a complete sovereignisation of numbers, a turn to the east and one of the ways to communicate that the Russian regime now operates according to laws that are not even superficially related to the western ones.”
The elections were also about stabilising Putin’s rule at home, where the greatest threat to his government may come not from a democratic opposition but instead from conservative forces or even those in his own government, whom he has entrusted with running Russia’s vast security and state apparatus.
Noble called the election result an “important signalling mechanism to various audiences, including, most importantly, the elite. The message is that Putin is still firmly in control and able to secure a thumping electoral victory, including through the use of various types of manipulation. That will likely dissuade members of the elite from thinking about a post-Putin world, for now.”
There will be a post-election hangover as the populist measures taken by the government to control prices for petrol and food are relaxed. (Major breweries have already warned retailers that prices for beer will soon rise by 8-15%.)
Abbas Gallyamov, a former Putin speechwriter, said the “parties are over, the work week is beginning. Soon, people will begin to get a stronger feeling that they have been fooled: they promised one thing but they are slipping something completely different.”
But the Kremlin will cajole, coerce or falsify those votes again in 2030, and then again perhaps by 2036, when Putin will probably seek even higher numbers.

title: 普京再当六年俄罗斯总统 | Radio-Canada.ca
content:
71岁的普京周日毫无悬念地连任俄罗斯总统。官方数据指出，普京以超过87%选票再次当选。
普京在克里姆林宫的在位时间，如无意外将超过斯大林的29年。
普京发表讲话表示，其连任证明俄罗斯选了正确的道路。他还感谢了在乌克兰战斗的士兵，并承诺连任后将实现所有目标。
他又罕有地提及本来最能威胁他的对手纳瓦尔尼的名字。
他还表示，在纳瓦尔尼死前已同意以他交换囚犯。他说，纳瓦尔尼与关押在西方的俄罗斯人进行交换的主要条件是，对方永远不得返回俄罗斯。
他指，反对派发起的抗议活动，不会影响总统选举，更指将起诉那些污损选票的人。
三个候选人陪跑
官方估计选举投票率为74.22%，高于上次2018年选举的67.5%。
普京以外的其他三名候选人均非真正可较量候选人。
投票分三天进行，票站分布在俄国内的十一个时区。自周五上午八时（当地时间）在俄罗斯远东地区开始，至周日晚上八时在与欧盟接壤的加里宁格勒（Kaliningrad）结束。
此外，在被非法吞并的乌克兰地区、网上和世界各地某些大使馆中也设有票站。
俄罗斯前总统梅德韦杰夫（Dmitry Medvedev）祝贺普京取得巨大胜利。梅德韦杰夫目前是俄罗斯安全委员会的二号人物。由于任期限制，普京在2008至2012年改担任总理，由梅德韦杰夫担任总统。
反对者召集中午到票站
纳瓦尔尼的支持者曾呼吁俄罗斯人午间来到票站，投票反对普京。
他的遗孀尤利娅（Yulia Navalnaya）在俄罗斯驻德国柏林大使馆投票。她表示在选票上写了纳瓦尔尼的名字，在选举前一个月，普京的主要反对者已经入狱，却仍被杀害，这是不可能的。
流亡立陶宛、纳瓦尔尼的得力助手沃尔科夫（Leonid Volkov），上周被袭后仍矢言会继续反抗。他在Ｘ的帖文指，普京捏造的选举结果完全脱离现实，实在不值一谈。
有俄罗斯独立媒体公布选民散发的作废选票图片，其中一张写著杀手和小偷字样，另一张写著在海牙等你字样。不过亦有公民表示很高兴把票投给普京。在莫斯科投票的谢尔吉延科（Dmitri Sergienko）说，我对一切都很满意，我希望一切都像现在这样继续下去。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基指责普京伪造选举结果。他在社交网络X上写道：世界上每个人都清楚地看到，这个人物就像历史上经常发生的那样，沉醉于权力之中，为了永远统治不择手段。
白宫国家安全委员会发言人认为，普京监禁反对派，阻止其他人竞选；德国外交部则说，普京的专制政权，建立在审查、镇压和暴力的基础上。
虽然反对活动零星，但据专门监测镇压活动的非政府组织OVD-Info报道，俄罗斯至少有77人因选举抗议活动被捕。
translation:
Putin, 71, was re-elected as Russian president without any doubt on Sunday. Official data pointed out that Putin was re-elected with more than 87% of the vote.
Putin's time in the Kremlin, if nothing unexpected happens, will exceed Stalin's 29 years.
Putin said in a speech that his re-election proved that Russia had chosen the right path. He also thanked the soldiers fighting in Ukraine and promised to achieve all his goals if re-elected.
He also rarely mentioned the name of Navalny, the opponent who was the most threatening to him.
He also said that he had agreed to exchange prisoners with Navalny before his death. He said Navalny's main condition in exchange for Russians imprisoned in the West was that they would never return to Russia.
He stated that the protests launched by the opposition would not affect the presidential election, and that those who defaced the ballots would be prosecuted.
Three candidates accompany the race
Officially estimated election turnout was 74.22%, up from 67.5% in the last 2018 election.
None of the other three candidates besides Putin are serious contenders.
Voting took place over three days, with polling stations located in eleven time zones across Russia. It started at 8 am (local time) in the Russian Far East on Friday and ended at 8 pm on Sunday in Kaliningrad (Kaliningrad) on the border with the European Union.
In addition, there are polling stations in illegally annexed areas of Ukraine, online and in certain embassies around the world.
Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev congratulated Putin on his great victory. Medvedev is currently the No. 2 person on the Russian Security Council. Due to term limits, Putin served as prime minister from 2008 to 2012, with Medvedev serving as president.
Opponents called to polling stations at noon
Navalny's supporters had called on Russians to come to the polls at noon and vote against Putin.
His widow Yulia Navalnaya voted at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, Germany. She said it was impossible to put Navalny's name on the ballot and still be killed a month before the election when Putin's main opponent was in jail.
Leonid Volkov, Navalny's right-hand man who lives in exile in Lithuania, vowed to continue resisting after being attacked last week. His post on X stated that Putin’s fabricated election results were completely divorced from reality and were really not worth talking about.
Some Russian independent media published pictures of invalidated ballots distributed by voters. One of them had the words "Killer and Thief" written on it, and another had the words "Waiting for you in The Hague" written on it. However, some citizens said they were happy to vote for Putin. Dmitri Sergienko, who voted in Moscow, said, "I am very satisfied with everything and I hope everything continues as it is now."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Putin of falsifying the election results. He wrote on the social network
A spokesperson for the White House National Security Council believes that Putin imprisons opponents and prevents others from running for election; the German Foreign Ministry said that Putin's authoritarian regime is based on censorship, repression and violence.
While opposition activity has been sporadic, at least 77 people have been arrested in Russia over election protests, according to OVD-Info, an NGO that monitors the crackdown.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
普京2022年签署乌东四地（顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克、扎波罗热、赫尔松）入俄联邦法律后，上述被俄称为“新地区”此番首次举行大选投票。
在普京12月公开宣布参选之前，圣彼得堡政治基金会创始人兼主席米哈伊尔·维诺格拉多夫（Mikhail Vinogradov）颇为困惑。他原本预计11月4日“俄罗斯统一日”当天会为2024年3月总统选举开启的大规模造势和宣传活动没有发生，普京也没有借此场合正式宣布参选。莫斯科举行的以“俄罗斯”为主题的大型展会开幕式也没有出现总统的身影，这本应是他的竞选活动的重要一幕。
“一些分析人士将此归因于最近在达吉斯坦（共和国）发生的反犹太（抗议）骚乱。”他当时在给卡内基国际和平基金会网站上撰文写道，他将这场反犹太事件视为俄乌冲突期间普京面临的三次严重危机之一，另外两次是2022年9月俄罗斯从乌克兰哈尔科夫地区撤退，以及2023年6月瓦格纳雇佣军武装叛乱，“另一些人则认为，克里姆林宫正试图缩短选举季，从而降低风险。”
translation:
After Putin signed the law of joining the four eastern regions of Ukraine (Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhye, and Kherson) into the Russian Federation in 2022, the above-mentioned "new regions" called by Russia will hold general election votes for the first time.
Before Putin publicly announced his candidacy in December, Mikhail Vinogradov, founder and chairman of the St. Petersburg Political Foundation, was confused. He originally expected that the large-scale campaign and propaganda activities for the presidential election in March 2024 would be launched on November 4, "Russian Unity Day", but it did not happen, and Putin did not use this occasion to formally announce his candidacy. The president was also absent from the opening ceremony of a major "Russia"-themed exhibition in Moscow, which was supposed to be a key event in his campaign.
"Some analysts attribute this to the recent anti-Semitic (protest) riots in Dagestan (Republic of)." He wrote on the website of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at the time, which he attributed to the anti-Semitic riots. The incident is regarded as one of the three serious crises faced by Putin during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The other two are Russia's withdrawal from the Kharkov region of Ukraine in September 2022, and the armed rebellion of Wagner mercenaries in June 2023. "Others It is believed that the Kremlin is trying to shorten the election season and thereby reduce risks.”
input:
After Putin signed the law of joining the four eastern regions of Ukraine (Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhye, and Kherson) into the Russian Federation in 2022, the above-mentioned "new regions" called by Russia will hold general election votes for the first time.
Before Putin publicly announced his candidacy in December, Mikhail Vinogradov, founder and chairman of the St. Petersburg Political Foundation, was confused. He originally expected that the large-scale campaign and propaganda activities for the presidential election in March 2024 would be launched on November 4, "Russian Unity Day", but it did not happen, and Putin did not use this occasion to formally announce his candidacy. The president was also absent from the opening ceremony of a major "Russia"-themed exhibition in Moscow, which was supposed to be a key event in his campaign.
"Some analysts attribute this to the recent anti-Semitic (protest) riots in Dagestan (Republic of)." He wrote on the website of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace at the time, which he attributed to the anti-Semitic riots. The incident is regarded as one of the three serious crises faced by Putin during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The other two are Russia's withdrawal from the Kharkov region of Ukraine in September 2022, and the armed rebellion of Wagner mercenaries in June 2023. "Others It is believed that the Kremlin is trying to shorten the election season and thereby reduce risks.”

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
Russia’s Central Election Commission, which routinely bars any real challengers from running, reported late Sunday that Putin had received more than 87 percent of the vote with 75 percent of ballots counted. Putin quickly claimed a fifth term in office, extending his rule until at least 2030. He said he would continue his war against Ukraine where “in some areas our guys are simply cutting the enemy to pieces right now.”
Russia’s elections have long been widely condemned as neither free nor fair and failing to meet basic democratic standards, with the Kremlin approving opposition candidates and tightly controlling media access. That meant Putin’s victory was preordained. The turnout of protesters in wartime Russia, by contrast, was far less certain. Navalny had urged the midday action before dying suddenly in prison last month.
In remarks claiming victory after midnight, Putin commented on Navalny’s death for the first time and confirmed reports that talks had been underway to exchange Navalny, long his most formidable political critic, for Russians imprisoned in the West.
“A few days before Mr. Navalny passed away some people told me there is an idea to exchange him with some people who are incarcerated in Western countries,” Putin said. “You can believe me or not but even before the person could finish their phrase I said I agree. But what happened happened unfortunately. I had only one condition — that we swap him and that he doesn’t come back. Let him sit there. But this happens. You can’t do anything about that.”
Russian authorities said Navalny died of natural causes while Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, has accused Putin of ordering his murder. The Kremlin rejects the allegations.
The “Noon Against Putin” protest, with voters forming queues at polling stations in major cities such as Moscow, St. Petersburg, Yekaterinburg, Chelyabinsk, Tomsk and Novosibirsk, was a striking — if futile — display of solidarity and dissent and challenged the Kremlin’s main message: that Putin is a legitimate president who commands massive support.
Many polling stations in Moscow were deathly quiet on Sunday morning, but long lines appeared at exactly 12 p.m. — despite authorities sending mass text messages warning people against participating in “extremist” actions and in the face of severe repression of dissent since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022, which has resulted in hundreds of arrests.

“A few days before Mr. Navalny passed away some people told me there is an idea to exchange him with some people who are incarcerated in Western countries,” Putin said. “You can believe me or not but even before the person could finish their phrase I said I agree. But what happened happened unfortunately. I had only one condition — that we swap him and that he doesn’t come back. Let him sit there. But this happens. You can’t do anything about that.”
Russian authorities said Navalny died of natural causes while Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, has accused Putin of ordering his murder. The Kremlin rejects the allegations.

Many polling stations in Moscow were deathly quiet on Sunday morning, but long lines appeared at exactly 12 p.m. — despite authorities sending mass text messages warning people against participating in “extremist” actions and in the face of severe repression of dissent since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022, which has resulted in hundreds of arrests.

title: 全球前瞻｜巴以斋月会否停火受关注，俄罗斯将举行总统选举
content:
俄罗斯总统选举在即
3月17日，俄罗斯将举行总统选举，有4名候选人参选，分别为：俄罗斯现任总统普京、自由民主党领导人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基，俄罗斯联邦共产党党员尼古拉·哈里托诺夫，俄罗斯新人党党员弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫。
现年71岁的普京自2000年以来已四度担任俄罗斯总统。普京最早在2000年至2008年间担任俄罗斯总统。2008年其两届总统任期届满后，时任俄罗斯第一副总理的梅德韦杰夫继任总统，普京则转任俄罗斯政府总理。
2012年，普京时隔4年再次当选俄罗斯总统，根据此前新修订的宪法，俄总统任期从4年变成了6年。2018年3月，普京又以约77%的得票率赢得连任，开始了自己的第四个总统任期。他的本届任期将于2024年结束。
俄民意调查机构FOM在2023年10月21日至11月13日对6100名受访者进行的一项有关普京选举前景的调查表明，对普京持积极态度的受访者比几年前有所上升。
在回答现任总统是否应该连任时，给出肯定回答的受访者比例在2019年为33%，2022年为62%，现在已上升至70%。
translation:
Russian presidential election is coming
On March 17, Russia will hold a presidential election, with four candidates running: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, and member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Harry Tonov, Vladislav Davankov, a member of the New People's Party of Russia.
Putin, 71, has served as Russia's president four times since 2000. Putin first served as President of Russia from 2000 to 2008. After his two terms as president expired in 2008, Medvedev, then Russia's first deputy prime minister, succeeded him as president, and Putin became prime minister of the Russian government.
In 2012, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia after 4 years. According to the newly revised constitution, the term of the Russian President was changed from 4 years to 6 years. In March 2018, Putin won re-election with about 77% of the vote, beginning his fourth presidential term. His current term will end in 2024.
A survey on Putin’s electoral prospects conducted by the Russian opinion polling agency FOM from October 21 to November 13, 2023 among 6,100 respondents showed that the number of respondents who have a positive attitude towards Putin is higher than a few years ago. rise.
When asked whether the current president should be re-elected, the proportion of respondents who answered affirmatively was 33% in 2019, 62% in 2022, and has now risen to 70%.
input:
Russian presidential election is coming
On March 17, Russia will hold a presidential election, with four candidates running: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, and member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Harry Tonov, Vladislav Davankov, a member of the New People's Party of Russia.
Putin, 71, has served as Russia's president four times since 2000. Putin first served as President of Russia from 2000 to 2008. After his two terms as president expired in 2008, Medvedev, then Russia's first deputy prime minister, succeeded him as president, and Putin became prime minister of the Russian government.
In 2012, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia after 4 years. According to the newly revised constitution, the term of the Russian President was changed from 4 years to 6 years. In March 2018, Putin won re-election with about 77% of the vote, beginning his fourth presidential term. His current term will end in 2024.
A survey on Putin’s electoral prospects conducted by the Russian opinion polling agency FOM from October 21 to November 13, 2023 among 6,100 respondents showed that the number of respondents who have a positive attitude towards Putin is higher than a few years ago. rise.
When asked whether the current president should be re-elected, the proportion of respondents who answered affirmatively was 33% in 2019, 62% in 2022, and has now risen to 70%.

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
Другие издания сделали акцент на речи, с которой Владимир Путин выступил в своем предвыборном штабе. Например, газета Berliner Zeitung указала на то уважение, с которым президент говорил о российских военных:
В своей речи Путин обратился с особыми словами благодарности к военным, которые выполняют важнейшие задачи на фронтах специальной военной операции на Украине.
translation:
Other publications focused on the speech that Vladimir Putin gave at his campaign headquarters. For example, the Berliner Zeitung pointed out the respect with which the president spoke of the Russian military:
In his speech, Putin addressed special words of gratitude to the military who are performing critical tasks on the fronts of a special military operation in Ukraine.
input:
Other publications focused on the speech that Vladimir Putin gave at his campaign headquarters. For example, the Berliner Zeitung pointed out the respect with which the president spoke of the Russian military:
In his speech, Putin addressed special words of gratitude to the military who are performing critical tasks on the fronts of a special military operation in Ukraine.

title: Putin, Kim, Assad and their most fantastical election wins – POLITICO
content:
In case you missed it, Russian President Vladimir Putin secured another six years in power for himself over the weekend, “winning” a rigged election with virtually no real opponent.
Shocking, right?
In a feat of generosity, Putin only gave himself 87 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results, the biggest share he has claimed in any of his five presidential election wins since 2000.
In Putin’s (dis)honor, we compiled a list of leaders who claimed smashing success at their own elections.
Kim Jong Un
Kim Jong Un succeeded his father as “supreme leader” of North Korea in 2011, the third member of his family dynasty to rule the country. Since then, the country has held largely symbolic elections for the parliamentary body — which usually feature 99.99 percent voter turnout and where people vote “yes” or “no” on a single-candidate ballot. Each candidate usually scrapes home with, err, 100 percent of the vote in their constituencies, including Kim Jong Un in 2014 and his sister Kim Yo Jong in 2019. 
Alexander Lukashenko
In August 2020, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko won 80 percent of the vote in Belarus’ presidential election, securing himself another mandate. The result of the election — widely considered fraudulent and which came after he’d jailed opposition leader Sergei Tikhanovsky, the husband of Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya who assumed his mantle  — triggered a wave of mass, futile protests across the country, with pro-democracy groups and opposition leaders calling for Lukashenko’s ouster. Lukashenko, who has been in power since 1994, has taken several pages out of Putin’s book on leadership, cracking down on opposition and amending laws to grant himself lifelong immunity. 
Joseph Stalin
Before Putin, there was Stalin. The Soviet dictator stayed in power in Moscow for three decades before dying in 1953. Elections during his reign went as one might expect: high turnout and 100 percent of the votes for the unopposed communist autocrat. With his victory over the weekend, Putin moved one step closer to nudging out Stalin as Russia’s longest-serving ruler.
Bashar al-Assad
Bashar al-Assad has been the president of Syria since 2000, following the death of his father, Hafez al-Assad, who ruled for 30 years. During his reign, Assad has brought home multiple thumping electoral “victories,” securing nearly 89 percent of the votes in 2014 and over 95 percent in 2021, all in elections widely regarded as fraudulent. Those big wins came during a devastating civil war in which Assad (with Putin’s help, incidentally) crushed multi-sided opposition, killing hundreds of thousands of people in a conflict that has lasted more than a decade.  
Ilham Aliyev
Caviar all round!  Just last month, Azebaijan’s President Ilham Aliyev received close to 94 percent of the vote in a tainted election in the South Caucasus. Aliyev, whose country will host the U.N.’s COP29 climate summit later this year, secured his fifth term leading a nation that is ranked as one of the least free in the world. Outside observers said the election was marred by a harsh crackdown on opposition activists and journalists.

title: Shpilkin's Razor: How A Statistical Model Raises Questions About Putin's Election. Again.
content:
Turnout was about 77.44 percent -- 87.1 million people -- of all eligible voters. Voting was also conducted illegally in the Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine.

Those results are nearly 10 percentage points higher than Putin's 2018 election results.
But for years, officials have constrained any sort of independent or outside monitoring of voting procedures. Western observer missions have been blocked, Russian monitors like Golos have been forced to flee the country, and even Internet cameras used by monitors to observe hundreds of balloting precincts around the country have been taken down.

Shpilkin's analyses, meanwhile, have been embraced as a verifiable model that holds up to scrutiny and highlights just how election officials allegedly manipulate tallies.

In layman's terms, the model and the graphs derived from it show unusual, jagged anomalies in vote tallies over the course of balloting, as turnout increases. If there was no manipulation, according to this model, then the distribution of votes among Putin and the other candidates would appear smoother, with few sharp deviations.

Researchers say the anomalies can be explained by ballot counters entering fictitious tallies into official records.
Ivan Shukshin, a researcher with Golos, said he came to a similar conclusion using the Shpilkin model, independent of the media reports: 22 million fraudulent votes, a tally he said excluded online voting and voting in Ukrainian territories that Russia claims to have annexed.

Andras Toth-Czifra, a political and risk analyst with the Foreign Policy Research Institute, said Shpilkin's method is convincing but it tends not to catch more sophisticated forms of electoral manipulation, like coerced voting, or the preferences of those who did not participate.

The model, he said, also appears to indicate turnout figures that were "almost certainly significantly lower" than official numbers.

"This is important because engineering a high turnout was one of the main goals of the Kremlin, and the authorities put a lot of effort and resources toward achieving this," he told RFE/RL. "If getting the desired results still required them to invent tens of millions of votes, that tells a lot about the authorities' ability to mobilize voters."

Shukshin, the Golos expert, also concluded that one of Putin's challengers, Vladislav Davankov, had his vote tallies tweaked so that he ended up in third place, behind the candidate from the Communist Party.
Some opposition activists had urged people to vote for Davankov in the slim hope of forcing a second round of voting.
"This was the most filthily falsified presidential election in the country's history," Shukshin wrote.
input:

"This is important because engineering a high turnout was one of the main goals of the Kremlin, and the authorities put a lot of effort and resources toward achieving this," he told RFE/RL. "If getting the desired results still required them to invent tens of millions of votes, that tells a lot about the authorities' ability to mobilize voters."

Shukshin, the Golos expert, also concluded that one of Putin's challengers, Vladislav Davankov, had his vote tallies tweaked so that he ended up in third place, behind the candidate from the Communist Party.
Some opposition activists had urged people to vote for Davankov in the slim hope of forcing a second round of voting.
"This was the most filthily falsified presidential election in the country's history," Shukshin wrote.

title: Putin extends rule in preordained Russian election after harshest crackdown since Soviet era - ABC News
content:
Germany also sharply criticized the vote. “Russia, as the chancellor has already said, is now a dictatorship and is ruled by Vladimir Putin in an authoritarian manner,” said Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokeswoman, Christina Hoffmann. 
Chinese President Xi Jinping, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan congratulated Putin, as did North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and the presidents of nations that have historic and current ties to Russia, such as Azerbaijan and Belarus.
Navalny's associates urged those unhappy with Putin or the war to go to the polls at noon Sunday — and lines outside a number of polling stations both inside Russia and at its embassies around the world appeared to swell at that time.
Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, who spent more than five hours in the line at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, told reporters that she wrote her late husband’s name on her ballot. 
Asked whether she had a message for Putin, Navalnaya replied: “Please stop asking for messages from me or from somebody for Mr. Putin. There could be no negotiations and nothing with Mr. Putin, because he’s a killer, he’s a gangster.”
Putin referenced Navalny by name for the first time in years at the news conference, declaring that he had been ready to release him in a swap for unidentified inmates in Western custody just days before the opposition leader’s death.
Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, disputed those claims. He told reporters during a White House briefing Monday that U.S. officials had spoken to Russia for “months and years” about releasing American detainees but “have not heard a Russian official raise Navalny as part of a prisoner swap in any of these conversations."
Supporters of Navalny streamed to his grave in Moscow, some bringing ballots with his name written on them.
The Russian leader brushed off the effectiveness of the apparent protest and rejected Western criticism of the vote. Instead, he tried to turn the tables on the West, charging that the four criminal cases against former President Donald Trump were a use of the judiciary for political aims.
“The whole world is laughing at it,” he said.
Some people told the AP that they were happy to vote for Putin — unsurprising in a country where state TV airs a drumbeat of praise for the Russian leader and voicing any other opinion is risky.
Dmitry Sergienko, who cast his ballot in Moscow, said, “I am happy with everything and want everything to continue as it is now.”
Voting took place over three days at polling stations across the vast country, in illegally annexed regions of Ukraine and online.
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while a few others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes. Many more were rounded up by police for attempting to protest. 
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that about 90 people were arrested in 22 cities across Russia on Sunday.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said Russians were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
Huge lines formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin's invasion of Ukraine. 
___
This story has been updated to correct that Putin referred to Navalny by name for the first time in years in his remarks after polls closed.

title: Vladimir Putin claims landslide Russian election victory | Vladimir Putin | The Guardian
content:
The ‘election’ in the occupied territories of #Ukraine is null and void & another breach of international law.”
Navalny’s team called on voters to spoil their ballot papers, write “Alexei Navalny” across the voting slip or vote for one of the three candidates standing against Putin, though the opposition regards them as Kremlin “puppets”.
Reports from the ground suggested that queues suddenly formed at numerous polling stations across Russia’s big cities as the clock struck midday.
Leonid Volkov, a Navalny aide who was attacked by an unknown assailant with a hammer in Vilnius last week, said several thousand queues had formed at midday at polling stations across the country.
Ruslan Shaveddinov of Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation said: “We showed ourselves, all of Russia and the whole world that Putin is not Russia, that Putin has seized power in Russia.”
En route to Putin’s win, Russia disqualified anti-war candidates, launched an unparalleled get-out-the-vote campaign targeted at state workers, and spent more than £1bn on a propaganda drive, according to leaked documents shared with the Guardian.
The Russian leader has faced no meaningful contest after the authorities barred two candidates who had voiced their opposition to the war in Ukraine. Three other politicians running in the election did not directly question Putin’s authority and their participation was meant to add an air of legitimacy to the race.
Long queues also formed at noon in places popular among Russian émigrés such as Berlin, Yerevan in Armenia, London and the Thai island of Phuket. Hundreds of thousands of Russians are estimated to have left the country since the start of the invasion of Ukraine more than two years ago.
“This action was Navalny’s last wish. We just had to come today at noon,” said Dmitry, a Russian voter who moved to Phuket shortly after the start of the war in Ukraine. He asked for his last name to be withheld for fear of repercussions.
The German broadcaster Deutsche Welle estimated that more than 2,000 voters turned up for the midday protest outside the Russian embassy in Berlin.
On Friday Russian prosecutors threatened any voters who took part in the “noon against Putin” action with five years in prison. In the southern city of Kazan, police detained more than 20 voters who had joined the protest, according to the independent rights monitor OVD-Info.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
三是及时调整外交方针,打破美西方多年的封锁和孤立。

20多年来俄罗斯对美西方国家的外交政策,前后出现较大反差,从当初凭空幻想逐步走向理智和务实。

普京执政之初曾一心扑向西方。俄罗斯人骨子里是向往西方,回归欧洲。普京执政初期,曾想借助美西方国家的援助,振兴俄国,强立世界。他首先出访的是英国等10多个欧洲国家。“9.11”事件后,普京第一个给美国时任总统小布什打电话,表示对美反击恐怖主义的坚决支持。随后向美国提供了除英国外,比北约成员国总和还多的援助,及时向美提供有关情报,说服中亚国家为美英军事行动开放“空中走廊”,允许美军使用中亚国家的军事基地......普京的各种善举换来的是美西方国家的口惠而实不至。

俄罗斯与美西方国家外交吃了亏,上了当,及时回归“双头鹰”外交方针,转向东西兼顾,在与西方国家保持正常外交的同时,重点向中印两个大国倾斜,同中国建立了新时代全面战略协作伙伴关系,同印度保持和发展了传统友好交往,取得了可喜效果。

2014年,俄罗斯为防止北约东扩威胁的扩大,果断收回克里米亚,俄与美西国家关系陷入低谷。俄乌冲突以来,美西方国家加大对俄打压、制裁和封锁。俄及时转向全面“向东看”,以中国为外交支点,以上海合作组织、金砖国家和集体安全条约组织为平台,开展积极灵活的外交,与朝鲜、东盟等国家加强了交往,适时兼顾南方国家,召开俄罗斯-非洲峰会,与非洲多国互动,不断发展同伊朗、土耳其、沙特阿拉伯、埃及和叙利亚等国的关系,从而有效摆脱了外交困境。俄在国际舞台仍然发挥着十分的重要作用。
translation:
The third is to adjust the diplomatic policy in a timely manner and break the blockade and isolation imposed by the United States and the West for many years.

Over the past 20 years, Russia's foreign policy towards the United States and Western countries has shown great contrast. It has gradually moved from fantasy to rationality and pragmatism.

At the beginning of Putin's rule, he devoted himself to the West. At their core, Russians yearn for the West and return to Europe. In the early days of Putin's administration, he wanted to use the assistance of the United States and Western countries to revitalize Russia and build a strong world. He first visited more than 10 European countries including the United Kingdom. After the "9.11" incident, Putin was the first to call the then US President George W. Bush to express his firm support for the US's fight against terrorism. Subsequently, it provided more assistance to the United States than the total number of NATO member states except the United Kingdom, provided relevant intelligence to the United States in a timely manner, persuaded Central Asian countries to open "air corridors" for US and British military operations, and allowed the US military to use military bases in Central Asian countries. .....Putin’s various good deeds were rewarded with lip service from the United States and Western countries but no real results.

Russia suffered a loss in its diplomacy with the United States and Western countries and was deceived. It promptly returned to the "double-headed eagle" diplomatic policy and turned to balancing the East and the West. While maintaining normal diplomacy with Western countries, it focused on China and India, the two major powers, and established a relationship with China. China has established a comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era, maintained and developed traditional friendly exchanges with India, and achieved gratifying results.

In 2014, in order to prevent the expansion of the threat of NATO's eastward expansion, Russia decisively took back Crimea, and Russia's relations with the United States and Spain fell into a low point. Since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, the United States and Western countries have increased their suppression, sanctions and blockade against Russia. Russia timely turned to a comprehensive "Look East", using China as the fulcrum of diplomacy, using the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, BRICS and the Collective Security Treaty Organization as platforms, carrying out active and flexible diplomacy, strengthening exchanges with North Korea, ASEAN and other countries, and taking into account all matters in a timely manner. The southern countries held the Russia-Africa Summit, interacted with many African countries, and continuously developed relations with countries such as Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Syria, thereby effectively getting rid of diplomatic difficulties. Russia still plays a very important role on the international stage.

title: ﻿普京成功连任 得票率逾87% _大公网
content:
普京警告三战仅一步之遥
　　普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话，感谢所有选民的支持。他表示，俄罗斯是一个大家庭，本次选举结果体现了选民的信任和期望，国家将会进一步向前发展，变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。对于西方国家的负面反应，普京表示：“这是意料之中的。你能指望他们起立鼓掌吗？”他还表示，美国政府正在利用其权力和资源攻击一名总统参选人，美国竞选气氛正变得越来越不文明，“全世界都在嘲笑美国正在发生的事情”。俄媒称，普京提到的美国总统参选人是特朗普。
　　谈及新任期面临的挑战时，普京表示，俄罗斯必须完成在乌克兰的特别军事行动。他说，前线的主动权完全掌握在俄军手中。被问及法国近期表示不排除未来在乌部署地面部队、俄罗斯与北约发生冲突的可能性时，普京说：“现代世界一切皆有可能。每个人都清楚，（若俄罗斯与北约发生冲突）距离第三次世界大战只有一步之遥。我想没有人乐见如此。”
　　普京数年来首次公开提及反对派人士纳瓦尔尼的名字。纳瓦尔尼上月在狱中死亡。普京说，他曾考虑用纳瓦尔尼交换被关押在西方的囚犯。“但不幸的是，这种事情发生了。你能做什么？人生就是这样。”
　　团结友好国家打破西方封锁
　　俄经济在乌克兰危机升级初期遭遇震荡后，逐步展现出韧性。但西方国家对俄在金融、投资、技术产品进口等领域的封锁给俄经济长远发展带来困难。如何继续对冲西方制裁影响是普京新任期的一个重要任务。普京上月底表示，俄罗斯将大力加强教育、科技等领域发展，让技术自主成为产业升级的动力，以提高经济的效率和竞争力。
　　俄专家认为，抵制西方围堵打压、团结友好国家、实现既定外交目标将成为普京今后外交政策的着力点。俄罗斯国际事务理事会专家科尔图诺夫说，接下来一段时间，俄美将继续深度对抗，但双方仍将保持一定克制，以避免发生核战争等意外。
　　俄政治信息中心主任穆欣表示，俄罗斯将继续在金砖合作机制和上合组织等框架内发挥重要作用。
translation:
Putin warns that three wars are only one step away
Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters. The country will further move forward and become stronger, stronger and more efficient. Regarding the negative reaction from Western countries, Putin said: "This is expected. Can you expect them to stand up and applaud?" He also said that the U.S. government is using its power and resources to attack a presidential candidate, and the atmosphere of the U.S. election campaign is becoming increasingly uncivilized and “the whole world is laughing at what’s happening in America.” Russian media said that the US presidential candidate mentioned by Putin was Trump.
When talking about the challenges facing the new term, Putin said that Russia must complete its special military operations in Ukraine. He said that the initiative on the front line is entirely in the hands of the Russian army. When asked about France’s recent statement that it would not rule out the possibility of deploying ground troops in Ukraine and a conflict between Russia and NATO in the future, Putin said: “Everything is possible in the modern world. Everyone knows that (if there is a conflict between Russia and NATO) the distance is World War III is just one step away. I don’t think anyone wants that.”
Putin publicly mentioned opposition figure Navalny's name for the first time in several years. Navalny died in prison last month. Putin said he had considered trading Navalny for prisoners held in the West. "But unfortunately, it happens. What can you do? That's life."
Unite friendly countries to break the Western blockade
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is an important task for Putin in his new term. Putin said at the end of last month that Russia will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve economic efficiency and competitiveness.
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.

title: 俄大选结果Q&A _大公网
content:
选举结果如何？
　　18日公布的对100%选票的统计结果显示，普京得票率为87.28%，以创纪录的优势再次赢得连任。此次选举投票率超过73%，创下当代俄罗斯选举的最高纪录。

　　选举结果说明了什么？
　　俄选民表示，普京经验丰富，能让俄罗斯在如今的艰难环境中继续发展。专家指出，普京是俄罗斯的“危机管理者”，俄民众不希望在俄乌冲突期间看到领导人发生变动。

　　国际社会有何反应？
　　中国、古巴、朝鲜、玻利维亚等国向普京表示祝贺，天主教教宗方济各亦祝贺普京再次当选俄罗斯总统。乌克兰、美国、德国、英国等国则指责俄选举“不公平”。

　　普京有何表态？
　　普京感谢所有选民的支持，并强调俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展，变得更坚实、更强大、更高效。
　　对于中俄关系，普京表示，两国关系将继续深化发展，造福两国人民。
　　对于俄乌冲突，普京说，主动权完全掌握在俄军手中，并重申俄方支持和平谈判。他警告说，若北约与俄罗斯爆发直接冲突，那么距离世界大战仅有一步之遥。
translation:
What was the result of the election?
The statistics of 100% of the votes released on the 18th showed that Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won re-election again with a record advantage. The electoral turnout exceeded 73%, setting a record for contemporary Russian elections.

What do the election results show?
Russian voters said that Putin has rich experience and can enable Russia to continue to develop in today's difficult environment. Experts pointed out that Putin is Russia's "crisis manager" and the Russian people do not want to see a change in leadership during the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

What is the reaction of the international community?
China, Cuba, North Korea, Bolivia and other countries congratulated Putin. Catholic Pope Francis also congratulated Putin on his re-election as president of Russia. Ukraine, the United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and other countries accused the Russian election of being "unfair."

What did Putin say?
Putin thanked all voters for their support and emphasized that Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that the relations between the two countries will continue to deepen and develop and benefit the two peoples.
Regarding the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, Putin said that the initiative lies entirely in the hands of the Russian military and reiterated Russia’s support for peace negotiations. He warned that if a direct conflict breaks out between NATO and Russia, it will be just one step away from world war.

What was the result of the election?
The statistics of 100% of the votes released on the 18th showed that Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won re-election again with a record advantage. The electoral turnout exceeded 73%, setting a record for contemporary Russian elections.

What do the election results show?
Russian voters said that Putin has rich experience and can enable Russia to continue to develop in today's difficult environment. Experts pointed out that Putin is Russia's "crisis manager" and the Russian people do not want to see a change in leadership during the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

What is the reaction of the international community?
