title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
content:
当地时间3月18日凌晨，俄罗斯第八届总统选举投票结束几个小时后，结果就已基本明朗。俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布的初步计票数据显示，在已统计的约95%选票中，现任总统普京的得票率超过87%。这意味着普京事实上已经赢得大选，锁定了下一届俄罗斯总统之位。
 
这一结果并不令人意外。由于没有强有力的竞争者，大选之前，外界就普遍预测普京将轻松赢得此次总统选举。从目前的结果来看，事实也是如此，普京的三位挑战者得票率都低于5%。普京18日凌晨发表了胜选演讲，他感谢选民的支持，并表示自己将在新的任期内继续推动国家发展。
 
压倒性的胜利
 
据俄罗斯塔斯社报道，俄罗斯中央选举委员会最新计票结果显示，在已完成计票的95.08%选票中，独立候选人普京赢得87.32%的选票，取得了压倒性的胜利。
 
位列第二的是俄联邦共产党的尼古拉·哈里托诺夫，他获得4.28%的选票。俄新人党候选人弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫得票率为3.85%，位列第三。俄自由民主党候选人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基位列第四，得票率为3.15%。


3月17日在俄罗斯首都莫斯科街头拍摄的屏幕上的总统选举实时统计数据。新华社发
 
根据俄罗斯总统选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将于3月28日前确认此次总统选举结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
 
初步选举结果出炉后，普京在他的竞选总部发表了胜选演讲。据“今日俄罗斯”报道，普京在讲话中指出，俄罗斯目前面临着众多挑战，但只要俄罗斯人民保持团结，他们就能战胜所有挑战。
 
他感谢俄罗斯选民对他的信任，称“我将竭尽全力完成国家面临的任务，实现我们都认为最优先的目标”。他还说，国家发展的所有主要任务都已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述，他将竭尽所能完成既定目标。
translation:
In the early morning of March 18, local time, a few hours after the voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election ended, the results were basically clear. Preliminary vote counting data released by Russia's Central Election Commission showed that out of about 95% of the votes counted, current President Putin won more than 87% of the votes. This means that Putin has actually won the election and locked in the position of the next Russian president.
 
This result is not surprising. Since there is no strong competitor, before the election, it was widely predicted that Putin would easily win the presidential election. Judging from the current results, this is also true. Putin's three challengers all received less than 5% of the vote. Putin delivered a victory speech in the early morning of the 18th. He thanked voters for their support and stated that he would continue to promote national development during his new term.
 
overwhelming victory
 
According to Russia's TASS news agency, the latest vote counting results from Russia's Central Election Commission showed that independent candidate Putin won 87.32% of the 95.08% votes that had been counted, achieving an overwhelming victory.
 
In second place was Nikolai Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, who received 4.28% of the votes. The candidate of the Russian New People's Party Vladislav Davankov ranked third with 3.85% of the vote. The candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Leonid Slutsky, ranked fourth with 3.15% of the vote.


Live statistics of the presidential election are shown on a screen captured on the streets of the Russian capital Moscow on March 17. Xinhua News Agency
 
According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election before March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
 
After the preliminary election results came out, Putin delivered a victory speech at his campaign headquarters. According to "Russia Today", Putin pointed out in his speech that Russia is currently facing many challenges, but as long as the Russian people remain united, they can overcome all challenges.
 
He thanked Russian voters for their trust in him, saying "I will do my best to complete the tasks facing the country and achieve the goals that we all consider to be the highest priority." He also said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of parliament and that he will do his best to accomplish the set goals.

title: 普京胜选表态:竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标
content:
中新社莫斯科3月18日电 (记者 田冰)俄罗斯总统候选人、现任总统普京18日在选举投票结束后召开的首场记者会上表示,将竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标。
莫斯科时间18日7时,俄中央选举委员会公布对99.43%选票的计票结果,普京在2024年总统大选中获得87.32%的支持。实际上普京已经赢得大选。
俄联邦共产党提名的候选人哈里托诺夫获得4.32%的选票,俄新人党提名的候选人达万科夫获得3.79%的选票,俄自民党提名的候选人斯卢茨基得票率为3.19%。
普京在18日凌晨来到克里姆林宫附近的竞选总部发表讲话,并随后召开记者会。
普京表示,俄罗斯权力的来源是人民,每个俄罗斯公民的选票构成了人民的统一意志。他将在新的任期继续推动国家发展。
普京指出,俄罗斯发展的所有主要任务和目标已在近期向议会两院发表的国情咨文中阐述,他将竭尽所能完成既定目标。俄罗斯将会进一步向前发展,变得更强大、有力、高效。
针对乌克兰问题,普京表示,对乌特别军事行动前线的主动权完全掌握在俄军手中。特别军事行动问题和加强俄国防能力是其新任期的主要任务之一。他说,俄方支持和平谈判,但不能只是因为对方的子弹快用完了,而是他们如果确实地、认真地、长期地希望两国建立和平,俄罗斯支持就乌克兰问题进行谈判。“这是非常严肃的问题”。
普京同时表示,考虑到乌军对俄罗斯别尔哥罗德州等地的攻击,俄罗斯不排除将于某个时候在边境地区建立“安全区”的可能性。
对于美国,普京再次表示,俄方对任何一位美国总统候选人都没有偏好,俄罗斯准备与美国选民投票支持的任何美国领导人合作。
在回答俄罗斯与北约之间是否有可能爆发全面冲突以及有多大可能性问题时,普京说,“在现代世界一切皆有可能”。他指出,乌克兰目前有北约国家的军事人员存在,而且他们正在“大量死亡”。
对于中俄关系,普京表示,俄中关系经过多年发展,非常稳定,具有很强互补性。普京指出,俄中两国在经济、外交等领域有诸多契合点。就亚欧地区发展而言,俄中关系是一个重要稳定因素,中方提出的共建“一带一路”倡议非常重要。
普京积极评价中国的发展成就。他认为,中国正在非常自信地实现飞速发展,并向创新型经济转型；中国在国际舞台上日益活跃并取得巨大成功,在世界各地拥有许多朋友。
普京强调,台湾是中国不可分割的一部分；那些在台湾周围进行挑衅并采取种种措施迟滞中国发展的企图,无疑会彻底失败。
俄罗斯第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。俄中选委宣布,将不晚于3月28日确认本届总统选举最终结果,并在确认后3日内公布。
translation:
China News Service, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Tian Bing) Russian presidential candidate and current President Vladimir Putin said at his first press conference after the election voting on the 18th that he would do his best to achieve the country's main tasks and goals.
At 7:00 a.m. Moscow time on the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission announced the counting results of 99.43% of the votes. Putin won 87.32% of the support in the 2024 presidential election. Putin has actually won the election.
Kharitonov, the candidate nominated by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, received 4.32% of the votes, Davankov, the candidate nominated by the Russian New People's Party, received 3.79% of the votes, and Slutsky, the candidate nominated by the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, received 3.19% of the votes.
Putin came to the campaign headquarters near the Kremlin to deliver a speech in the early morning of the 18th, and then held a press conference.
Putin said that the source of Russian power is the people, and the votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people. He will continue to promote national development in his new term.
Putin pointed out that all the main tasks and goals of Russia's development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Union address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals. Russia will move forward and become stronger, more powerful and more efficient.
Regarding the Ukrainian issue, Putin stated that the initiative on the frontline of the special military operation against Ukraine lies entirely in the hands of the Russian army. The issue of special military operations and strengthening Russia's defense capabilities are one of the main tasks of his new term. He said that Russia supports peace negotiations, but not just because the other side is running out of bullets, but if they truly, seriously and long-term hope that the two countries can establish peace, Russia supports negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "This is a very serious issue."
Putin also said that considering the Ukrainian army's attacks on Russia's Belgorod region and other places, Russia does not rule out the possibility of establishing a "safe zone" in the border area at some point.
Regarding the United States, Putin once again stated that Russia has no preference for any American presidential candidate and that Russia is ready to cooperate with any American leader that American voters vote for.
When answering the question of whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO is possible and how likely it is, Putin said, "Everything is possible in the modern world." He pointed out that there are currently military personnel from NATO countries in Ukraine, and they are "dying in large numbers."
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary. Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.
Putin spoke positively of China's development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those who seek provocation around Taiwan and take various measures to delay China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. The Russian-Chinese Election Commission announced that it will confirm the final results of this presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
content:
3月17日中午，有俄罗斯选民在接到纳瓦利内遗孀尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚 (Yulia Navalnaya)的电话后前往投票站，莫斯科和其他俄罗斯城市的几个投票站前排起了长队。
尤利娅·纳瓦利纳亚自己则在俄罗斯驻德国大使馆前露面，敦促她的支持者集体出现。报道称，17日中午有超过2000名选民参加了俄罗斯驻德国大使馆外的抗议活动。
“你们给了我希望，一切都没有白费，我们仍然会战斗。” 纳瓦利纳亚在17日的一篇帖子中说，自己在选票上写下了“纳瓦利内”。
此前几天，俄罗斯国内也有民众进行抗议活动，包括将染料倒入投票箱和纵火袭击投票站。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃 (Ella Pamfilova) 16日表示，由于有选民试图将各种液体倒入投票箱，“总共至少有 214 张选票已经不可挽回地被损坏了。” 
帕姆菲洛娃还表示，俄罗斯至少有20个地区的29个投票站报告称有人试图破坏选票：有20个投票站报告称有人企图向选票箱内倒入液体，有8个投票站报告称有人企图纵火，有1个投票站报告称有人企图投掷烟雾弹。
俄罗斯联邦国家安全会议副主席兼统一俄罗斯党主席、俄前总统德米特里·梅德韦杰夫 (Dmitry Medvedev) 表示，肇事者可能面临叛国罪指控，最高可被判处20年监禁。俄罗斯内政部表示，在2024年总统选举期间已提出155项行政指控，并立案61起刑事案件，其中包括21起妨碍选民权利的案件。
translation:
At noon on March 17, some Russian voters went to the polling station after receiving a call from Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, and queues formed in front of several polling stations in Moscow and other Russian cities. There was a long queue.
Yulia Navalnaya herself appeared in front of the Russian Embassy in Germany, urging her supporters to show up en masse. According to reports, more than 2,000 voters participated in a protest outside the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon on the 17th.
"You gave me hope that everything was not in vain and we will still fight." Navalnaya said in a post on the 17th that he wrote "Navalny" on the ballot.
In the past few days, people in Russia also carried out protests, including pouring dye into ballot boxes and setting fire to attack polling stations.
Ella Pamfilova, chairwoman of Russia's Central Election Commission, said on the 16th that "a total of at least 214 ballots have been irreparably damaged due to voters trying to pour various liquids into the ballot boxes."
Pamfilova also said that 29 polling stations in at least 20 regions in Russia reported attempts to sabotage ballots: 20 polling stations reported attempts to pour liquid into ballot boxes, and 8 polling stations reported attempts to sabotage ballots. There were attempts at arson and one polling station reported attempts at throwing smoke grenades.
Dmitry Medvedev, deputy chairman of the National Security Council of the Russian Federation, chairman of the United Russia party and former Russian president, said the perpetrators may face treason charges, which could lead to a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. The Russian Interior Ministry stated that 155 administrative charges have been filed during the 2024 presidential election and 61 criminal cases have been opened, including 21 cases of obstructing voters' rights.
input:
At noon on March 17, some Russian voters went to the polling station after receiving a call from Navalny’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya, and queues formed in front of several polling stations in Moscow and other Russian cities. There was a long queue.
Yulia Navalnaya herself appeared in front of the Russian Embassy in Germany, urging her supporters to show up en masse. According to reports, more than 2,000 voters participated in a protest outside the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon on the 17th.
"You gave me hope that everything was not in vain and we will still fight." Navalnaya said in a post on the 17th that he wrote "Navalny" on the ballot.
In the past few days, people in Russia also carried out protests, including pouring dye into ballot boxes and setting fire to attack polling stations.
Ella Pamfilova, chairwoman of Russia's Central Election Commission, said on the 16th that "a total of at least 214 ballots have been irreparably damaged due to voters trying to pour various liquids into the ballot boxes."
Pamfilova also said that 29 polling stations in at least 20 regions in Russia reported attempts to sabotage ballots: 20 polling stations reported attempts to pour liquid into ballot boxes, and 8 polling stations reported attempts to sabotage ballots. There were attempts at arson and one polling station reported attempts at throwing smoke grenades.
Dmitry Medvedev, deputy chairman of the National Security Council of the Russian Federation, chairman of the United Russia party and former Russian president, said the perpetrators may face treason charges, which could lead to a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. The Russian Interior Ministry stated that 155 administrative charges have been filed during the 2024 presidential election and 61 criminal cases have been opened, including 21 cases of obstructing voters' rights.

title: 枪口之下：被占地区的乌克兰人在俄罗斯选举中支持普京 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
由莫斯科任命的“总督们”公开敦促被占领地区的居民投票支持普京。
由俄罗斯任命的扎波罗热州长叶夫根尼·巴利茨基在Telegram上表示，“我相信我们公民的活动将会非常活跃，该地区的每位居民都会投票给我们的总统。”
在本周五上午，俄罗斯官员报告了提前投票率——扎波罗热被占领地区的投票率为45%，顿涅茨克和赫尔松地区的投票率为58%。
俄新社于当天上午8点05分提交了这份报告，即占领地区公立学校和政府大楼的投票站开放5分钟之后。
此次选举为克里姆林宫提供了一个机会，为国家控制的媒体及其俄罗斯观众制造一种幻觉。
“当局组织了许多人群，他们很乐意摆出姿势拍摄视频，以提供一张张漂亮的照片。他们不需要强迫任何人去投票。没有人会制造骚乱”，这位前埃涅尔戈达尔居民这样说道。
俄罗斯甚至允许那些尚未获得红色俄罗斯护照的人参与投票，而这公然违反了俄罗斯自己的选举法。
想要投票的人可以出示任何有效身份证件，包括乌克兰护照或者驾驶执照。
俄罗斯在其所谓的乌克兰“信息转移”中公布了严格的安全措施。
俄罗斯报告称，乌克兰情报部门搜集选民信息并向选举官员发出威胁。
这些威胁“看起来是复制粘贴的，只有一些词语发生了变化”，被俄罗斯占领的顿涅茨克地区首席选举官员弗拉基米尔·维索茨基对塔斯社这样说道。
俄罗斯首席选举官员埃拉·帕姆菲洛娃在本周四表示，“我们第一次在如此复杂、极端的情况下举行选举，国际局势如此恶劣，威胁不断，还存在大量其他的负面因素。”
与此同时，乌克兰观察家大声质疑俄罗斯选举的必要性，背景是普京已成为自苏联统治者斯大林以来在任时间最长的俄罗斯领导人。
基辅的政治心理学家协会副会长斯维特兰娜·丘尼基纳表示，“普京狂热地坚持通过‘选举’来延长其无休止的节奏，同时完全消除竞争和开放式结局的本质，而这体现了极权主义现实中存在的深刻分裂。”
“在俄罗斯，他们认为选举是权力合法化最具声望的方式”，她告诉半岛电视台记者，“但是极权主义现实不会产生任何威望。它只会产生恐惧和顺从。”
乌克兰不出所料地严厉谴责了在被占领地区举行的投票。
乌克兰外交部在本周四的一份声明中表示，“模仿总统选举的活动表明俄罗斯进一步无视国际法的标准和原则。”
translation:
Moscow-appointed “governors” publicly urged residents of the occupied areas to vote for Putin.
"I believe that the activity of our citizens will be very active and every resident of the region will vote for our president," Yevgeny Balitsky, the Russian-appointed governor of Zaporozhye, said on Telegram.
On Friday morning, Russian officials reported early voting rates - 45% in the occupied Zaporozhye region and 58% in the Donetsk and Kherson regions.
RIA Novosti submitted the report at 8:05 a.m. that day, five minutes after polling stations opened at public schools and government buildings in the occupied areas.
The election provides the Kremlin with an opportunity to create an illusion for the state-controlled media and its Russian audience.
"The authorities organized large crowds who were happy to pose for videos to provide beautiful photos. They did not need to force anyone to vote. No one was going to cause riots," said the former Enel Godard resident Said so.
Russia even allowed those who had not yet obtained a red Russian passport to vote, in flagrant violation of Russia's own electoral laws.
Those who want to vote can present any valid ID, including a Ukrainian passport or driving license.
Russia has unveiled strict security measures over what it calls "information transfers" from Ukraine.
Russian reports say Ukrainian intelligence services collected voter information and issued threats to election officials.
The threats "appear to have been copied and pasted, with only some words changed," Vladimir Vysotsky, the chief electoral official in the Russian-occupied Donetsk region, told the TASS news agency.
Ella Pamfilova, Russia’s chief electoral official, said on Thursday, “For the first time we are holding an election under such complex and extreme circumstances, with such a bad international situation, constant threats, and a lot of other negative factors. "
Meanwhile, Ukrainian observers are loudly questioning the need for elections in Russia, as Putin becomes Russia's longest-serving leader since Soviet ruler Joseph Stalin.
Svetlana Chunikina, vice-president of the Association of Political Psychologists in Kyiv, said: “Putin’s fanatical insistence on prolonging his interminable rhythm through ‘elections’ while completely eliminating the competitive and open-ended nature of the This reflects the deep divisions that exist in totalitarian reality.”
“In Russia, they see elections as the most prestigious way to legitimize power,” she told Al Jazeera. “But totalitarian reality does not generate any prestige. It only generates fear and compliance.”
Ukraine predictably harshly condemned the vote in the occupied territories.
Ukraine’s Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Thursday that “activities that imitate the presidential election demonstrate Russia’s further disregard for the standards and principles of international law.”

title: 再干6年，普京能带出一个强大的俄罗斯吗？
content:
当地时间3月17日，普京在竞选总部向媒体发表讲话。图自视觉中国


	中国国际关系学会副会长、华东师范大学俄罗斯研究中心执行主任刘军认为：“总体来看，普京过去20多年的治理是比较成功的，他让俄罗斯走出了上世纪90年代苏联解体以后的衰落。”


	从经济上看，现在的俄罗斯远不能算是强国，但是其政治和军事实力在当今国际社会绝对不容小觑。


	普京在国情咨文中提到，按照购买力平价计算，如今俄罗斯是欧洲最大的经济体、世界第五大经济体，不久的将来会成为世界四大经济强国之一。


	“普京很自信，未来他会更加自信”。刘军说，这份自信来自于他过去20多年的成功治理，也来自于克里米亚问题和特别军事行动的顺利推进，当然还有此次俄大选的高票当选。


	刘军认为，在接下来的6年或12年时间里，“普京会继续巩固俄罗斯在后苏联空间的核心领导地位；积极推进并落实其‘向东转’策略；不排除俄罗斯与西方的关系将慢慢解冻，尽管俄美关系很难解冻，但是加强与欧洲接触是有可能的。”


	中国社科院俄罗斯东欧中亚研究所副研究员郝赫则认为，未来的6-12年，俄罗斯会怎样更多地取决于世界会变成什么样。“因为俄罗斯通过脱胎换骨式的模式转换取得特别大经济成就的可能性不是很大，但是在百年未有之大变局之际，世界的变化可能给俄罗斯带来一些新机遇。”


竞选过程中普京为何主打“民生牌”？


	此次俄罗斯大选在俄乌冲突的大背景下如期举行。


	这是俄罗斯首次战时选举，也是俄罗斯首次在顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克、扎波罗热和赫尔松四个“新地区”举行总统大选投票，目前四地均处于战时状态。在这之前，乌克兰宣布战时取消总统选举。





当地时间3月17日，卢甘斯克地区民众参加俄总统选举投票。
translation:
On March 17, local time, Putin delivered a speech to the media at the campaign headquarters. Picture from Visual China


Liu Jun, vice president of the China Society of International Relations and executive director of the Russian Studies Center at East China Normal University, believes: "Overall, Putin's governance over the past 20 years has been relatively successful. He has brought Russia out of the decline that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union in the 1990s. ”


From an economic point of view, Russia is far from being considered a powerful country, but its political and military strength must not be underestimated in today's international society.


Putin mentioned in his State of the Union address that Russia is now the largest economy in Europe and the fifth largest economy in the world based on purchasing power parity, and will become one of the world's four major economic powers in the near future.


"Putin is very confident, and he will be even more confident in the future." Liu Jun said that this confidence comes from his successful governance over the past 20 years, the smooth advancement of the Crimea issue and special military operations, and of course, his high vote in the Russian election.


Liu Jun believes that in the next 6 or 12 years, “Putin will continue to consolidate Russia’s core leadership position in the post-Soviet space; actively promote and implement his ‘turn east’ strategy; and will not rule out the relationship between Russia and the West. "It will slowly thaw. Although it is difficult to thaw Russia-US relations, it is possible to strengthen contacts with Europe."


Hao He, associate researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, believes that what Russia will do in the next 6 to 12 years will depend more on what the world will become. "Because it is not very likely that Russia will achieve particularly great economic achievements through a radical transformation of its model, but at a time of major changes unseen in a century, changes in the world may bring some new opportunities to Russia."


Why did Putin focus on the "people's livelihood card" during the election campaign?


The Russian general election was held as scheduled against the backdrop of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.


This is Russia's first wartime election, and it is also the first time Russia has held presidential election voting in the four "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhie and Kherson. All four regions are currently in a state of war. Prior to this, Ukraine declared wartime cancellation of presidential elections.





On March 17, local time, people in the Luhansk region participated in voting in the Russian presidential election.

title: Russia sees polling station protests with Putin set to extend long rule | CNN
content:
Navalny’s widow Yulia Navalnaya, meanwhile, was pictured out in Berlin on Sunday, greeting supporters who were rallying against Putin.
    

            Earlier this month, Yulia called for “an all-Russian protest action,” adding, “Alexey called for participation in this noon action against Putin and that’s why it’s so important to me.”
    

            She called on supporters to register their protest by showing up simultaneously at polling booths, and then making their own choice to vote against Putin, write in Navalny, invalidate their ballot or simply leave in silent protest.
    

            Speaking on YouTube, Navalnaya said that the protests “will take place not just in every city, but in every district of every city, millions of Russians can take part and tens of millions more will see it.”
    

            Navalny, Putin’s most formidable opponent, died aged 47 in an Arctic prison on February 16, sparking condemnation from world leaders and accusations from his aides that he had been murdered. The Kremlin has denied any involvement in his death.
    

            Voting in the presidential election has seen some acts of civil disobedience, with Russia filing at least 15 criminal cases after people poured dye in ballot boxes, started fires or lobbed Molotov cocktails.
    

            More than 60 Russians have been detained across 16 Russian cities Sunday, according to independent human rights group OVD-Info.
    

            Dissent has effectively been outlawed in Russia since it launched its invasion of Ukraine more than two years ago.
    

            Sunday marks the third and final day of voting, with Russian President Vladimir Putin almost certain to win a fifth term in office.
    

            Voting has been taking place across the country’s 11 time zones – from the far eastern regions near Alaska to the western exclave of Kaliningrad on the Baltic Coast – and its 88 federal subjects, including parts of occupied Ukraine illegally annexed by Russia.
    

            Polling stations in all but the most western regions of Russia have closed with the first election results expected after 9 p.m. Moscow time (2 p.m. ET) Sunday.
    

            The turnout in the election surpassed 70% of eligible voters, according to the Election Commission, with the percentage of people voting in the final hours exceeding the final turnout in 2018, according to official figures.
    

            Putin’s reelection would extend his rule until at least 2030. Following constitutional changes in 2020, he would then be able to run again and potentially stay in power until 2036, which would see him secure his place as Russia’s longest-serving ruler since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin.
    

This is a developing story and will be updated. 


  CNN’s Seb Shukla and Fred Pleitgen in Berlin contributed reporting.

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
content:
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会周一（3月18日）上午公布的选举初步结果，普京获得了87.3%的选票。西方国家一致谴责普京在大选中取得的所谓“压倒性”胜利，称此次选举不公平、不民主，中印和朝鲜则祝贺这位俄罗斯老牌领导人的统治又将延续六年。
这种截然不同的反应凸显了当下国际地缘政治的裂痕不断扩大。裂痕肇始于两年前俄罗斯全面入侵乌克兰，俄罗斯与西方关系出现了自冷战结束以来最严重的危机。
周一，欧盟各国外长抵达布鲁塞尔，一致斥责俄罗斯此次选举结果是一场骗局，随后宣布对与克里姆林宫批评人士阿列克谢‧纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）被虐待致死案有关的个人实施制裁。
他们认为，普京在一场没有真正反对派的选举中获得压倒性胜利是不可避免的，也是滑稽可笑的。
translation:
According to the preliminary election results announced by Russia's Central Election Commission on Monday (March 18) morning, Putin received 87.3% of the votes. Western countries unanimously condemned Putin's so-called "landslide" victory in the election, calling the election unfair and undemocratic, while China, India and North Korea congratulated the veteran Russian leader on extending his rule for another six years.
The contrasting responses highlight the widening rifts in current international geopolitics. The rift began two years ago with Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and relations between Russia and the West have entered the most serious crisis since the end of the Cold War.
European Union foreign ministers arrived in Brussels on Monday and unanimously denounced Russia's election results as a sham before announcing sanctions on individuals linked to the torture and death of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny.
They view Putin's landslide victory in an election with no real opposition as inevitable and farcical.
input:
According to the preliminary election results announced by Russia's Central Election Commission on Monday (March 18) morning, Putin received 87.3% of the votes. Western countries unanimously condemned Putin's so-called "landslide" victory in the election, calling the election unfair and undemocratic, while China, India and North Korea congratulated the veteran Russian leader on extending his rule for another six years.
The contrasting responses highlight the widening rifts in current international geopolitics. The rift began two years ago with Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and relations between Russia and the West have entered the most serious crisis since the end of the Cold War.
European Union foreign ministers arrived in Brussels on Monday and unanimously denounced Russia's election results as a sham before announcing sanctions on individuals linked to the torture and death of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny.
They view Putin's landslide victory in an election with no real opposition as inevitable and farcical.

title: 分析｜掌政24年，普京如何改变了俄罗斯和世界？_世界频道_财新网
content:
【财新网】2024年2月的最后一天，俄罗斯最具公信力的民调机构列瓦达中心公布了对俄罗斯民意的最新调查。该机构写道：“所有指标均显示出温和的积极动态。”这具体指的是，当前相信俄罗斯正走在正确道路上、和支持普京继续担任俄罗斯总统的受访者，都达到了多年来的新高。
　　在俄罗斯新一届大选前发布的这份民调中，75%的受访者肯定了俄罗斯当前的发展路线，另有多达86%的人表示支持俄罗斯总统普京。
　　当时，以乌军弃守乌克兰南部重镇阿夫杰耶夫卡为标志，俄罗斯刚在战场上斩获了近一年来首个获得公认的军事胜利，并逐渐掌握了战场主动权。但与此同时，在俄罗斯国内，入狱三年的俄反对派领袖人物阿列克谢·纳瓦利内突然传来的死讯，以及由此引发的国际舆论风波，又构成了外界观察2024年春天的俄罗斯的另一维度。
translation:
[Caixin] On the last day of February 2024, the Levada Center, Russia’s most credible polling organization, released its latest survey of Russian public opinion. “All indicators point to moderately positive dynamics,” the agency wrote, referring specifically to the number of respondents who currently believe Russia is on the right path and support Putin’s continued leadership as Russia’s president. new high.
In this poll released before Russia's new election, 75% of the respondents affirmed Russia's current development path, and as many as 86% expressed support for Russian President Putin.
At that time, marked by the Ukrainian army's abandonment of the important town of Avdeyevka in southern Ukraine, Russia had just won its first recognized military victory on the battlefield in the past year, and gradually took the initiative on the battlefield. But at the same time, in Russia, the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who had been imprisoned for three years, and the resulting international public opinion storm constituted a new trend for outsiders to observe in 2024. Another dimension of Russia in spring.
input:
[Caixin] On the last day of February 2024, the Levada Center, Russia’s most credible polling organization, released its latest survey of Russian public opinion. “All indicators point to moderately positive dynamics,” the agency wrote, referring specifically to the number of respondents who currently believe Russia is on the right path and support Putin’s continued leadership as Russia’s president. new high.
In this poll released before Russia's new election, 75% of the respondents affirmed Russia's current development path, and as many as 86% expressed support for Russian President Putin.
At that time, marked by the Ukrainian army's abandonment of the important town of Avdeyevka in southern Ukraine, Russia had just won its first recognized military victory on the battlefield in the past year, and gradually took the initiative on the battlefield. But at the same time, in Russia, the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who had been imprisoned for three years, and the resulting international public opinion storm constituted a new trend for outsiders to observe in 2024. Another dimension of Russia in spring.

title: Russian voters, answering Navalny’s call, protest as Putin extends his rule to 2030 - The Washington Post
content:
“It’s important to show that people are not alone and that there is still support for this kind of action.”
For Putin’s election in occupied Ukraine, voting is forced at gunpoint
It is difficult to stage any form of protest in wartime Russia. Authorities swiftly disperse even small street gatherings and have cracked down mercilessly on activist and opposition groups. Citizens have been arrested for laying flowers at memorials for Navalny, and some have been detained for standing alone holding up blank sheets of paper.
Russian courts, one of the regime’s major tools of control, have imposed long prison sentences on people for trivial actions, such as social media reposts or replacing price tags in supermarkets with information about the war.
The Noon Against Putin protest was particularly striking at Russian embassies in nations with significant numbers of Russians who fled after the invasion of Ukraine. They included those in Armenia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Germany, China, Portugal, Britain and others.
It was impossible to estimate how many people participated in Russia and around the world, but photos and videos showed lines of hundreds of people at many polling stations.
Even pro-Kremlin analyst Sergei Markov, who routinely echoes Kremlin talking points, admitted that the protest “was brilliant from the point of view of political technology.”
Markov said that it covered an extremely wide area, had a great slogan and that all opposition groups had joined in.
input:
“It’s important to show that people are not alone and that there is still support for this kind of action.”
For Putin’s election in occupied Ukraine, voting is forced at gunpoint
It is difficult to stage any form of protest in wartime Russia. Authorities swiftly disperse even small street gatherings and have cracked down mercilessly on activist and opposition groups. Citizens have been arrested for laying flowers at memorials for Navalny, and some have been detained for standing alone holding up blank sheets of paper.
Russian courts, one of the regime’s major tools of control, have imposed long prison sentences on people for trivial actions, such as social media reposts or replacing price tags in supermarkets with information about the war.
The Noon Against Putin protest was particularly striking at Russian embassies in nations with significant numbers of Russians who fled after the invasion of Ukraine. They included those in Armenia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Germany, China, Portugal, Britain and others.
It was impossible to estimate how many people participated in Russia and around the world, but photos and videos showed lines of hundreds of people at many polling stations.
Even pro-Kremlin analyst Sergei Markov, who routinely echoes Kremlin talking points, admitted that the protest “was brilliant from the point of view of political technology.”
Markov said that it covered an extremely wide area, had a great slogan and that all opposition groups had joined in.

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
content:
“今天我们要对我们大家说 – 中午仅仅是个开始，”路透社引述“中午反普京”示威倡议活动星期天一早在社媒电报上的贴文说。
“是的，我们中的一些人感到害怕。是的，做这样的选择并不轻松。但是我们是人民。我们直面我们的选择和责任，”倡议活动的贴文说。
路透社报道说，在前两天的投票中，俄罗斯各地发生了一些零星的抗议事件。有些投票点被放火，有的投票箱被喷洒颜料。而俄罗斯官员则称做这些举动的人为“败类”和“叛徒”。
根据路透社的报道，在俄罗斯远东的新西伯利亚市的一个投票所，星期天中午约有100人出来排队。而俄罗斯在海外从泰国到悉尼、从比什凯克到塔什干开设的投票所前面，星期天中午也出现大排长龙的人群。但是目前并不清楚，这些人是前往投票还是现身抗议的。
普京两年多前发动乌克兰战争并在俄罗斯国内发布动员令时，很多俄罗斯役龄年轻人都已经逃往国外，而许多反对普京的俄罗斯人也离开。普京虽然在俄罗斯国内表现得像个强人，西方对他看法普遍负面，称他为独裁者、战争罪犯和屠夫。
translation:
“Today we say something to all of us – noon is just the beginning,” Reuters quoted the “Noon Against Putin” demonstration initiative as saying in a post on social media Telegram early Sunday morning.
"Yes, some of us are scared. Yes, making this choice is not easy. But we are the people. We face our choices and responsibilities head-on," the initiative's post said.
Reuters reported that there were sporadic protests across Russia during the first two days of voting. Some polling places were set on fire and some ballot boxes were sprayed with paint. Russian officials have called those responsible for these actions "scum" and "traitors."
According to Reuters, at a polling station in the city of Novosibirsk in Russia's Far East, about 100 people came out to queue at noon on Sunday. In front of the polling stations opened by Russia overseas from Thailand to Sydney, from Bishkek to Tashkent, long lines of people also appeared at noon on Sunday. But it is unclear whether these people went to vote or showed up to protest.
When Putin launched the Ukraine war more than two years ago and issued a mobilization order in Russia, many young Russians of military age had already fled abroad, and many Russians who opposed Putin also left. Although Putin behaves like a strongman in Russia, the West generally views him negatively, calling him a dictator, a war criminal and a butcher.
input:
“Today we say something to all of us – noon is just the beginning,” Reuters quoted the “Noon Against Putin” demonstration initiative as saying in a post on social media Telegram early Sunday morning.
"Yes, some of us are scared. Yes, making this choice is not easy. But we are the people. We face our choices and responsibilities head-on," the initiative's post said.
Reuters reported that there were sporadic protests across Russia during the first two days of voting. Some polling places were set on fire and some ballot boxes were sprayed with paint. Russian officials have called those responsible for these actions "scum" and "traitors."
According to Reuters, at a polling station in the city of Novosibirsk in Russia's Far East, about 100 people came out to queue at noon on Sunday. In front of the polling stations opened by Russia overseas from Thailand to Sydney, from Bishkek to Tashkent, long lines of people also appeared at noon on Sunday. But it is unclear whether these people went to vote or showed up to protest.
When Putin launched the Ukraine war more than two years ago and issued a mobilization order in Russia, many young Russians of military age had already fled abroad, and many Russians who opposed Putin also left. Although Putin behaves like a strongman in Russia, the West generally views him negatively, calling him a dictator, a war criminal and a butcher.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
content:
Рекордная явка, нарушения и международная изоляция: главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
Начнем с главного - явки избирателей. Более 77% россиян пришли на участки или проголосовали онлайн - это абсолютный рекорд за всю историю президентских выборов в стране. В некоторых регионах, таких как Чечня, Тува и Кемеровская область, явка и вовсе зашкаливала за 90%. Особенно "отличились" в этом плане Чечня, где за Путина якобы проголосовали 98,99%. Независимые экзитполы показали гораздо более скромные цифры поддержки действующего президента - от 55% до 76%.

Такой ажиотаж объясняется несколькими факторами.

Во-первых, сыграл свою роль "крымский консенсус" и патриотический подъем на фоне противостояния с Западом. Многие россияне видят в Путине защитника национальных интересов и гаранта стабильности в непростые времена. Во-вторых, нельзя сбрасывать со счетов административный ресурс и мобилизацию бюджетников, силовиков и других лояльных власти групп населения.

Вот в качестве примера смотрите, студенты Волгоградского медуниверситета "самостоятельно, без приказов, совершенно случайно" собрались и пришли дружной очередью голосовать, как "обычно бывает" у всех студентов. Просто так совпало.
translation:
Record turnout, violations and international isolation: the main results of the 2024 Russian presidential elections
Let's start with the main thing - voter turnout. More than 77% of Russians went to the polling stations or voted online - this is an absolute record in the entire history of presidential elections in the country. In some regions, such as Chechnya, Tuva and the Kemerovo region, turnout went beyond 90%. Chechnya especially “distinguished itself” in this regard, where 98.99% allegedly voted for Putin. Independent exit polls showed much more modest figures for support for the incumbent president - from 55% to 76%.

This excitement is explained by several factors.

Firstly, the “Crimean consensus” and patriotic upsurge against the background of the confrontation with the West played a role. Many Russians see Putin as a defender of national interests and a guarantor of stability in difficult times. Secondly, we cannot discount the administrative resource and the mobilization of state employees, security forces and other groups of the population loyal to the authorities.

Here, as an example, look, students of Volgograd Medical University “on their own, without orders, completely by accident” gathered and came in a friendly line to vote, as “usually happens” with all students. It just happened that way.
input:
Record turnout, violations and international isolation: the main results of the 2024 Russian presidential elections
Let's start with the main thing - voter turnout. More than 77% of Russians went to the polling stations or voted online - this is an absolute record in the entire history of presidential elections in the country. In some regions, such as Chechnya, Tuva and the Kemerovo region, turnout went beyond 90%. Chechnya especially “distinguished itself” in this regard, where 98.99% allegedly voted for Putin. Independent exit polls showed much more modest figures for support for the incumbent president - from 55% to 76%.

This excitement is explained by several factors.

Firstly, the “Crimean consensus” and patriotic upsurge against the background of the confrontation with the West played a role. Many Russians see Putin as a defender of national interests and a guarantor of stability in difficult times. Secondly, we cannot discount the administrative resource and the mobilization of state employees, security forces and other groups of the population loyal to the authorities.

Here, as an example, look, students of Volgograd Medical University “on their own, without orders, completely by accident” gathered and came in a friendly line to vote, as “usually happens” with all students. It just happened that way.

title: Putin cultivates leader for life image in landslide win without competition - The Washington Post
content:
Appearing supremely confident, Putin shrugged off the “unfortunate” death of his main rival, Alexei Navalny, in prison last month, which has left Putin with no conceivable challenger. He even spoke Navalny’s name aloud, which he is known to have done only once before.
Putin also staked out his determination to continue the war against Ukraine, even at the risk of war with NATO. “It is clear to everyone that this will be one step away from a full-scale World War III,” Putin said, blaming the West for providing support to Kyiv.
Putin’s 87.28 percent election result generally tracks with his recent wartime public approval ratings. But Boris Bondarev, a former Russian diplomat who served at Russia’s U.N. mission in Geneva and resigned over the invasion of Ukraine, said that no one in Russia’s elite is convinced by the numbers.
“I think they don’t really care about the figures,” Bondarev said. “They just know that everything is still under control, that Putin still manages to outplay anybody. And, of course, nobody from the very beginning considered these elections to be elections.”
Some observers speculate that Putin, an impenetrable and often seemingly isolated figure, is the only person who fully believed the Kabuki theater of Russia’s election.
“This is the result of his team’s work, which is bringing him on a tray whatever he wants to see,” said Tatiana Stanovaya, the founder of R.Politik, a Russian political consultancy, now based in France. “But he sincerely believes … that the population supports him. He really does believe these figures are true.”
Stanovaya added, “Putin lives in the picture of the world he created for himself, and everything that doesn’t fit into it is removed from him.”
The message of the election to supporters of the Russian opposition is that they will always be dismissed as a tiny minority who can never win — despite Sunday’s remarkable protest, dubbed Noon Against Putin, in which voters in Russia and cities abroad formed long lines outside polling stations at precisely 12 o’clock.
input:
Appearing supremely confident, Putin shrugged off the “unfortunate” death of his main rival, Alexei Navalny, in prison last month, which has left Putin with no conceivable challenger. He even spoke Navalny’s name aloud, which he is known to have done only once before.
Putin also staked out his determination to continue the war against Ukraine, even at the risk of war with NATO. “It is clear to everyone that this will be one step away from a full-scale World War III,” Putin said, blaming the West for providing support to Kyiv.
Putin’s 87.28 percent election result generally tracks with his recent wartime public approval ratings. But Boris Bondarev, a former Russian diplomat who served at Russia’s U.N. mission in Geneva and resigned over the invasion of Ukraine, said that no one in Russia’s elite is convinced by the numbers.
“I think they don’t really care about the figures,” Bondarev said. “They just know that everything is still under control, that Putin still manages to outplay anybody. And, of course, nobody from the very beginning considered these elections to be elections.”
Some observers speculate that Putin, an impenetrable and often seemingly isolated figure, is the only person who fully believed the Kabuki theater of Russia’s election.
“This is the result of his team’s work, which is bringing him on a tray whatever he wants to see,” said Tatiana Stanovaya, the founder of R.Politik, a Russian political consultancy, now based in France. “But he sincerely believes … that the population supports him. He really does believe these figures are true.”
Stanovaya added, “Putin lives in the picture of the world he created for himself, and everything that doesn’t fit into it is removed from him.”
The message of the election to supporters of the Russian opposition is that they will always be dismissed as a tiny minority who can never win — despite Sunday’s remarkable protest, dubbed Noon Against Putin, in which voters in Russia and cities abroad formed long lines outside polling stations at precisely 12 o’clock.

title: 普京是否值得第五次连任总统？ | 政治 | 半岛电视台
content:
俄罗斯总统选举投票程序周日进入第三天，人们预计现任总统弗拉基米尔·普京将赢得压倒性多数选票，这自动意味着选举结束而不会进入第二轮。
如果发生这种情况，这将是普京继2018年连任总统任期后第五次担任俄罗斯总统，之后在2020年通过宪法修正案，称为“重置总统任期”（将总统任期归零），允许普京竞选总统直至2036年。
普京从鲍里斯·叶利钦手中夺取权力，当时的经济贫穷且饱受危机困扰，在整个 90 年代要么直线下滑，要么缓慢下滑。这一时期的特点是出现了与市场经济“健康规则”不符的现象，商品投机和垄断现象普遍存在，拖欠工资、通货膨胀猖獗、卢布（当地货币）汇率持续意外飙升，对本国不利，此外还有巨额预算赤字和国债、违约工资支付和不支付工资。
这份名单中还包括诚信可疑的管理者、机构濒临破产的状况以及压倒性的帮派力量。
这都是在和平年代，当时的数据和报告表明，苏联在二战期间的经济增长优于20世纪90年代，尽管拥有巨大的战略财富储备，特别是石油和天然气，但这个超级大国在许多领域重新回到了第三世界国家的行列。
除此之外，俄罗斯在国际舞台上的主要作用下降，内部动荡，分裂主义情绪高涨，或者是要求国内许多地区拥有更大的主权范围，这在某些阶段表现为武装叛乱。
这些数据对于评价普京1999年以来的治国政绩起到了实实在在的作用，并且在许多情况下，它们构成了任何方法的基础，基于第一任和最后一任苏联总统米哈伊尔·戈尔巴乔夫与苏联解体后俄罗斯第一任总统鲍里斯·叶利钦时代之间的比较因素。
translation:
Voting in Russia's presidential election entered its third day on Sunday, with current President Vladimir Putin expected to win an overwhelming majority of votes, automatically ending the election without entering a second round.
If this happens, it will be Putin's fifth term as president of Russia after being re-elected to one term in 2018, before passing a constitutional amendment in 2020, known as the "reset presidential term" (resetting the presidential term to zero), allowing Putin runs for president until 2036.
Putin seized power from Boris Yeltsin in a poor and crisis-plagued economy that either plummeted or slid slowly throughout the 1990s. This period was characterized by phenomena inconsistent with the "healthy rules" of the market economy, widespread commodity speculation and monopoly, wage arrears, rampant inflation, continued unexpected surges in the ruble (local currency) exchange rate to the country's detriment, in addition to There are huge budget deficits and national debts, wage payment defaults and non-payment of wages.
The list also includes managers of questionable integrity, institutions on the brink of bankruptcy and overwhelming gang power.
This was all in peacetime, when data and reports showed that the Soviet Union's economic growth during World War II was better than that of the 1990s, and despite having huge reserves of strategic wealth, especially oil and gas, the superpower was re-inventing itself in many areas. Back to the ranks of third world countries.
Added to this is the decline of Russia's major role on the international stage, internal unrest, rising separatist sentiments, or demands for greater sovereignty in many parts of the country, which at some stages manifested themselves in armed rebellions.
These data play a real role in assessing Putin's governance since 1999, and in many cases they form the basis of any methodology based on the first and last Soviet president Mikhail Gorba Comparative factors between Jov and the era of Boris Yeltsin, Russia’s first president after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
input:

If this happens, it will be Putin's fifth term as president of Russia after being re-elected to one term in 2018, before passing a constitutional amendment in 2020, known as the "reset presidential term" (resetting the presidential term to zero), allowing Putin runs for president until 2036.
Putin seized power from Boris Yeltsin in a poor and crisis-plagued economy that either plummeted or slid slowly throughout the 1990s. This period was characterized by phenomena inconsistent with the "healthy rules" of the market economy, widespread commodity speculation and monopoly, wage arrears, rampant inflation, continued unexpected surges in the ruble (local currency) exchange rate to the country's detriment, in addition to There are huge budget deficits and national debts, wage payment defaults and non-payment of wages.
The list also includes managers of questionable integrity, institutions on the brink of bankruptcy and overwhelming gang power.
This was all in peacetime, when data and reports showed that the Soviet Union's economic growth during World War II was better than that of the 1990s, and despite having huge reserves of strategic wealth, especially oil and gas, the superpower was re-inventing itself in many areas. Back to the ranks of third world countries.
Added to this is the decline of Russia's major role on the international stage, internal unrest, rising separatist sentiments, or demands for greater sovereignty in many parts of the country, which at some stages manifested themselves in armed rebellions.
These data play a real role in assessing Putin's governance since 1999, and in many cases they form the basis of any methodology based on the first and last Soviet president Mikhail Gorba Comparative factors between Jov and the era of Boris Yeltsin, Russia’s first president after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
content:
俄罗斯总统大选落幕，现任总统普京(Vladimir Putin)赢得五连任，将执政到2030年。普京3月18日发表胜选谈话时强调，俄中关系牢固且互补，也获得中国领导人习近平的贺电回应。虽然外界多视这场大选为“假选举”，但不少中国网民透过微博讨论选情，并语带讽刺地说:“至少俄罗斯人还能投票选总统，自己连选票长啥模样，都没见过。”

俄罗斯中央选举委员会3月18日宣布，99.67%的选票已计算完毕，普京以高达87.32%的得票率，遥遥领先其他三名对手，赢得下一个6年任期。
习近平电贺普京高票当选

普京顺利五连任，但美国、德国、英国及波兰等多国外交部先后表态，质疑俄罗斯大选的正当性。各国普遍认为，普京监禁声势最高的异议领袖纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny），且随着纳瓦尔尼2月突然于狱中离奇暴毙，等于无劲敌挑战。，这样的总统大选既不自由，也不公平，而是基于镇压、暴力的独裁统治。

不过，也是共产体制的中国和朝鲜则同声祝贺。
translation:
The Russian presidential election ended with current President Vladimir Putin winning five consecutive terms and will be in power until 2030. In his victory speech on March 18, Putin emphasized that Russia-China relations are strong and complementary, and received a congratulatory message from Chinese leader Xi Jinping in response. Although the outside world mostly regarded this election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and said sarcastically: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. What does it look like to vote for yourself? Never seen it.”

Russia's Central Election Commission announced on March 18 that 99.67% of the votes had been counted, and Putin won the next six-year term with a vote rate of 87.32%, far ahead of the other three opponents.
Xi Jinping sent a message to congratulate Putin on his overwhelming victory

Putin was successfully re-elected for a fifth term, but the foreign ministries of the United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and Poland have successively expressed doubts about the legitimacy of the Russian election. Countries generally believe that Putin has imprisoned Alexei Navalny, the most vocal dissident leader, and since Navalny suddenly and mysteriously died in prison in February, he has no strong opponent to challenge him. , such a presidential election is neither free nor fair, but a dictatorship based on repression and violence.

However, China and North Korea, which are also communist systems, congratulated each other.
input:
The Russian presidential election ended with current President Vladimir Putin winning five consecutive terms and will be in power until 2030. In his victory speech on March 18, Putin emphasized that Russia-China relations are strong and complementary, and received a congratulatory message from Chinese leader Xi Jinping in response. Although the outside world mostly regarded this election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and said sarcastically: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. What does it look like to vote for yourself? Never seen it.”

Russia's Central Election Commission announced on March 18 that 99.67% of the votes had been counted, and Putin won the next six-year term with a vote rate of 87.32%, far ahead of the other three opponents.
Xi Jinping sent a message to congratulate Putin on his overwhelming victory

Putin was successfully re-elected for a fifth term, but the foreign ministries of the United States, Germany, the United Kingdom and Poland have successively expressed doubts about the legitimacy of the Russian election. Countries generally believe that Putin has imprisoned Alexei Navalny, the most vocal dissident leader, and since Navalny suddenly and mysteriously died in prison in February, he has no strong opponent to challenge him. , such a presidential election is neither free nor fair, but a dictatorship based on repression and violence.

However, China and North Korea, which are also communist systems, congratulated each other.

title: Russia claims US and 'Western countries' are trying to hack its presidential election
content:
The Kremlin, which conducted an extensive interference operation targeting the 2016 U.S. presidential election, has a history of making baseless accusations to satisfy its own political goals.
The Russian National Computer Incident Coordination Center (CERT) has also issued a warning to online voters about the escalating cyber threats, including those that could originate from Ukraine and its allied countries. According to the CERT statement, cybercriminals will try to discredit the election, stir up social tension, spread fake news and infect online voters with malware.
The agency has advised its users to be cautious of phishing websites posing as electronic voting services. They also warned against emails and messages containing malicious links, disguised as official correspondence from Russian state agencies.
This week, Russia's foreign intelligence service specifically accused the U.S. of attempting to interfere in Russia's election and launching a cyberattack on its online voting system. The White House denied this statement.
“These allegations are categorically false and nothing more than propaganda," a White House National Security Council spokesperson told Reuters. "The U.S. has not and will not meddle in Russia’s election. It is Russia that has a long history of targeting U.S. and other democratic elections.”
Last week, the Kremlin said that Russia will not meddle in the upcoming U.S. presidential election in November, and dismissed the findings that Moscow was behind the campaigns to interfere in both the 2016 and 2020 U.S. presidential elections.
So far, there have been no public cases of Russian state websites going down, and none of the prominent Ukrainian hacktivist groups have claimed responsibility for such attacks.
On Monday, the Russian independent media organization Meduza said that it has been targeted by an “unprecedented” cyber campaign ahead of the upcoming presidential election.
Local independent media are also warning of possible internet or social media outages during the election period. This is a common practice in authoritarian countries and was recently used during Pakistan’s elections.
The reports of internet outages in Russia have become more frequent recently, with some appearing to be politically motivated.
The Kremlin is also trying to prevent its opponents from speaking up against Putin. For example, Russia banned the publication of polls, forecasts, and studies related to the presidential elections.
Supporters of the killed opposition leader Alexey Navalny also reported receiving fake messages, stating that the protests they are planning to organize on election day have been postponed.
“Don’t be fooled by fakes! They are trying to deceive you! Come to the polling stations on March 17 at 12:00 local time and vote against Putin,” Navalny’s team said.

title: Putin ‘wins’ rigged Russian election with 87 percent of the vote – POLITICO
content:
The result more than met the objective of an overwhelming win to buttress Putin’s claim that Russians wholeheartedly back their leader and his invasion of Ukraine. The three days of voting were an exercise in pro-Putin mobilization and a test of loyalty for Russia’s state apparatus. 
Nikolai Petrov from the Chatham House foreign affairs think tank in London said the result made Russia a “totally consolidated autocracy.” 
The election campaign, which saw three other candidates refrain from criticizing the president, was overshadowed by the death last month of Putin’s key opponent, Alexei Navalny.
Even with Navalny out of the way, Putin was taking no chances. On the first two days of voting, thousands of public sector employees, students, and workers from Russian corporations were compelled to cast their ballots.
Turnout was monitored by management — civil service employees were required to report back once they had voted. In some regions, they were even expected to bring relatives and share their geolocations with supervisors via a specially designed app. 
But Putin didn’t have it all go his way. The intended image of unanimity was marred by dozens of attacks on polling stations. In about 20 Russian regions, individuals either set voting booths ablaze or poured paint into the ballot boxes.
input:
The result more than met the objective of an overwhelming win to buttress Putin’s claim that Russians wholeheartedly back their leader and his invasion of Ukraine. The three days of voting were an exercise in pro-Putin mobilization and a test of loyalty for Russia’s state apparatus. 
Nikolai Petrov from the Chatham House foreign affairs think tank in London said the result made Russia a “totally consolidated autocracy.” 
The election campaign, which saw three other candidates refrain from criticizing the president, was overshadowed by the death last month of Putin’s key opponent, Alexei Navalny.
Even with Navalny out of the way, Putin was taking no chances. On the first two days of voting, thousands of public sector employees, students, and workers from Russian corporations were compelled to cast their ballots.
Turnout was monitored by management — civil service employees were required to report back once they had voted. In some regions, they were even expected to bring relatives and share their geolocations with supervisors via a specially designed app. 
But Putin didn’t have it all go his way. The intended image of unanimity was marred by dozens of attacks on polling stations. In about 20 Russian regions, individuals either set voting booths ablaze or poured paint into the ballot boxes.

title: Putin scores a resounding win, but what’s next for Russia? | CNN
content:
In a generally anodyne interview with government propagandist Dmitry Kiselyov, Putin evaded speculation about whether, for instance, a government shake-up might be expected after the election.
    

            Asked if the government of Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin might survive post-election, Putin merely said, “We need to talk about this after the elections, after the votes are counted. It seems to me that now this is simply incorrect. But on the whole, the government is working … quite satisfactorily.”
    

            So far, so yawn. But a bigger question now looms for Russia: What really comes next?
    

            Will there be a rearrangement of the deck chairs on the Kremlin ship of state? And what are the actual tasks at hand for a re-elected Putin?
    

            Among Russia-watchers, some speculation has centered on a few big-picture issues. For starters, if the presidential vote is indeed a referendum on Russia’s war, does the election give Putin a free hand to continue in Ukraine as he sees fit?
    

            On that count, Putin does seem to have room for maneuver. The Russian president is projecting confidence about developments on the battlefield, particularly after the fall of the eastern Ukrainian towns of Bakhmut and Avdiivka. And with Western dithering about continued aid to Ukraine – particularly in the US Congress, where a crucial aid package to Kyiv remains held up – the election result gives him more rhetorical ammunition.
    

            In his pre-election interview with Kiselyov, Putin trotted out that just that talking point.
    

            “To negotiate now just because they are running out of ammunition is somehow ridiculous on our part,” he said, projecting confidence about Ukraine being on the back foot.
    

            But Russia’s incremental advances in eastern Ukraine have come at horrific human cost. Speculation persists that Putin and his generals may need to launch a fresh round of post-election mobilization to feed troops into the meat grinder.
    

            Following initial Russian setbacks in the attempt to encircle Ukraine from three sides and capture Kyiv, Putin announced a partial mobilization in September 2022. But Russia remains locked in a war of attrition along a 1,000-kilometer front. Some observers believe Putin would have to wait until after the election to take the potentially unpopular step of another big call-up.

title: Russia election 2024: Putin’s grip on power tightens - Vox
content:
As expected, Russian President Vladimir Putin has won his fifth term in office, following a campaign in which all his significant rivals were barred from running, imprisoned, or dead.
Voting started Friday and concluded Sunday. Putin won the contest with over 87 percent of the vote, with a reported 77 percent turnout. The record post-Soviet win was Putin’s choreographed attempt to demonstrate his popularity — and that of the war in Ukraine. But it is impossible to take much away, given the level of repression in Russian society and Putin’s ambition to make himself synonymous with the Russian state.
The results come just a month after the death of Putin’s most potent and vocal foe, the anti-corruption campaigner Alexei Navalny, while he was serving a 19-year sentence in an Arctic penal colony on multiple charges including extremism. It’s also a little over two years after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which Russia refers to as a “special military operation.” Western countries have backed Ukraine during the grueling two-year war and imposed heavy sanctions on Russia, but those efforts have done little to loosen Putin’s grip on power; on the contrary, Putin’s government is at its most repressive since he first took power in 2000.
Even before his fifth term starts, Putin will already be the longest-serving Russian leader since Soviet dictator Josef Stalin. If he serves out the entirety of this six-year term, he will surpass Stalin and be in the running next with Catherine the Great and then perhaps eventually Peter the Great — two rulers whose imperial power Putin has sought to mimic in his conquest of Ukraine and other former Soviet and imperial lands.
With his reelection, Putin will be in power till at least 2030, unless he dies or is somehow removed from power in the intervening six years.
Putin’s ruthless quest to build power — not only his own, but Russia’s — might come as a surprise to anyone who saw him when he first became president in 2000. 
An unknown, unmemorable bureaucrat from St. Petersburg who served in the Soviet spy agency in Dresden during the tail end of the Cold War, Putin hardly seemed poised to gain the near-total power he now has in Russia.
But through a combination of immense wealth, cronyism, fraud, increasingly cruel repression, and constant information warfare, Putin has consolidated his power over the past 24 years, even when his deputy Dmitry Medvedev was nominally in charge.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
content:
五是高举反霸旗帜,带领俄国努力维护国际战略平衡。

普京从叶利钦时期俄饱尝与美国打交道的苦果,到执政初期受美国愚弄而上当受骗后的醒悟,亲身感知到美国对俄的战略完全是削弱、肢解俄罗斯。从伊拉克战争、北约轰炸南联盟,亲眼目睹美国在国际社会单边强权的横行霸道,逐渐树立起美国“完全靠不住”,必须“坚决抵制”、“建立一个公平的国际新秩序”的理念。

20多年来,普京多次宣称,“‘美国佬’羞辱了我们”,“有美国的存在,世界人民都是一个悲剧”,“以一个或几个国家霸权为基础的所谓单极世界是俄罗斯不能接受的”,“俄罗斯愿意和盟友以及所有相关国家合作,一起应对人类面临的共同挑战”。普京说到做到,俄与美关系渐行渐远,甚至走向抵制和对抗。两年前俄罗斯对乌克兰采取的特别军事行动,其实质是俄罗斯对美国单边霸权的军事反击。

国际社会的许多事实展现出,普京成为冲在反美、反霸第一线的斗士。他领导下的俄罗斯成为维护国际战略平衡和世界稳定的一支重要力量。
translation:
Fifth, hold high the banner of anti-hegemony and lead Russia in its efforts to maintain international strategic balance.

From the time when Russia suffered the bitter consequences of dealing with the United States during the Yeltsin period, to when he realized after being fooled and deceived by the United States in the early days of his administration, Putin personally felt that the United States' strategy towards Russia was completely to weaken and dismember Russia. From the Iraq War to NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia, I have witnessed the unilateral dominance of the United States in the international community, and gradually established the concept that the United States is "completely unreliable" and must be "resolutely resisted" and "establish a fair new international order."

For more than 20 years, Putin has repeatedly declared that "the 'Yanks' have humiliated us", "the existence of the United States is a tragedy for the people of the world", "the so-called unipolar world based on the hegemony of one or a few countries is Russia's "Unacceptable", "Russia is willing to cooperate with its allies and all relevant countries to deal with common challenges facing mankind." Putin keeps his word, and the relationship between Russia and the United States is gradually drifting away, even heading towards boycott and confrontation. The essence of Russia's special military action against Ukraine two years ago was Russia's military counterattack against the unilateral hegemony of the United States.

Many facts in the international community show that Putin has become a fighter on the front line against the United States and hegemony. Under his leadership, Russia has become an important force in maintaining international strategic balance and world stability.
input:

From the time when Russia suffered the bitter consequences of dealing with the United States during the Yeltsin period, to when he realized after being fooled and deceived by the United States in the early days of his administration, Putin personally felt that the United States' strategy towards Russia was completely to weaken and dismember Russia. From the Iraq War to NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia, I have witnessed the unilateral dominance of the United States in the international community, and gradually established the concept that the United States is "completely unreliable" and must be "resolutely resisted" and "establish a fair new international order."

For more than 20 years, Putin has repeatedly declared that "the 'Yanks' have humiliated us", "the existence of the United States is a tragedy for the people of the world", "the so-called unipolar world based on the hegemony of one or a few countries is Russia's "Unacceptable", "Russia is willing to cooperate with its allies and all relevant countries to deal with common challenges facing mankind." Putin keeps his word, and the relationship between Russia and the United States is gradually drifting away, even heading towards boycott and confrontation. The essence of Russia's special military action against Ukraine two years ago was Russia's military counterattack against the unilateral hegemony of the United States.

Many facts in the international community show that Putin has become a fighter on the front line against the United States and hegemony. Under his leadership, Russia has become an important force in maintaining international strategic balance and world stability.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
这是一种孤岛感。玛莎，叶利尼亚镇，或者说整个俄罗斯，就像一座孤零零的堡垒，独自面对全新的外部环境。从叶利尼亚的居民视角来看，过去俄罗斯遭受了太多的不公，从苏联解体到2010年代，尊严在西方面前掉落一地。如今生活困顿，前途黯淡也就罢了，现在似乎他们一直引以为豪的伟大历史也受到了威胁。
“苏联人民——我们的祖父母们——为了卫国战争胜利奋战了四年，千万条生命被吞噬。他们不仅解放了自己的土地，还解放了整个东欧。但现在，正是那些被解放的欧洲人的后代们，竟然不敢承认他们的父母、祖父母曾经饱含感激亲吻了红军士兵的面颊和T-34坦克的履带。他们应该为健忘症感到羞耻！”在一场统一俄罗斯党的集会上，叶利尼亚镇的镇长背靠红军战士雕像和刻有“永志不忘”字样的纪念碑，面对一排排手持祖父辈照片的“不朽军团”游行人群，发出了对欧洲的愤怒指责。
“西方从来没有接受过我们，也永远不会这么做。”2022年开战之后，在数百公里之外的A村，尼基塔的邻居谢尔盖也对西方发出了类似的不满。
“但乌克兰毕竟有我们的亲人，这真的是最好的方式吗？”尼基塔试图把话头转回每日的新闻头条。
“哦，是吗？或许你会给我大谈国际法，或许你还可以讲述乌克兰人的遭遇，但没有人切身体会过我们的屈辱感，知道吗？没有人。”谢尔盖预判了话题的方向，用带着愤懑的眼神回应着尼基塔有些“出格”的言论，“先是戈尔巴乔夫，后来又是叶利钦，现在是普京，我们总是在后退，你看不到吗？”
俄罗斯坐拥世界面积最大国土，军队规模庞大，还有威慑力十足的核武库，其民众普遍对自身军事力量感到自信。因此，外人并不容易设身处地体会俄罗斯的安全困境。
当地时间2023年5月9日，俄罗斯莫斯科，在纪念二战结束78周年的红场胜利日阅兵式上，军人列队行进。

尼基塔如此向澎湃新闻记者解释这种对安全的“偏执”：“我不和你说一大堆历史了，就一条，在俄语里‘安全’这个词是безопасность，字面构词上是‘没有危险’，这和英语、法语、德语的构词方式都不一样，恐怕也和中文不一样吧。”
“语言能反映人下意识的思维方式。所以，你可以看到俄罗斯人观念中有多么害怕外来的危险。”他说。
事实上，这种心态也体现在了俄罗斯官方的话语之中。为了应对西方制裁和外部风险，俄政府制定了一揽子策略，其中被命名为“俄罗斯堡垒”（Fortress Russia）的计划旨在加大俄经济和社会的自身韧性，进一步降低对西方依赖。其实，早在与西方尚处于“蜜月”的2005年，就有俄罗斯官方智库在题为“俄罗斯堡垒”的政策文件中建议，一种有效降低对外依赖的“孤立主义”政策（乃至世界观）从长远来看是可行的。
“所谓‘孤立主义’是指一种国家存在模式，政府仅仅建立和维系相对有限的对外接触。
translation:
It’s a sense of isolation. Masha, the town of Yelnya, or Russia as a whole, is like a lonely fortress, facing a new external environment alone. From the perspective of residents of Yelniya, Russia has suffered too many injustices in the past. From the disintegration of the Soviet Union to the 2010s, dignity fell to the ground before the West. Nowadays, life is difficult and their future is bleak. Now it seems that the great history they have always been proud of is also threatened.
"The Soviet people - our grandparents - fought for four years to win the Great Patriotic War, with tens of millions of lives devoured. They not only liberated their own land, but also all of Eastern Europe. But now, it is those who were liberated The descendants of Europeans dare not admit that their parents and grandparents once kissed the cheeks of Red Army soldiers and the tracks of T-34 tanks. They should be ashamed of their amnesia. "At a United Russia party rally! With his back to the statue of a Red Army soldier and a monument engraved with the words "Never Forget", the mayor of Yelniya Town faced rows of "Immortal Legion" marchers holding photos of their grandparents, expressing his anger against Europe. Accusation.
"The West has never accepted us and will never do so." After the war started in 2022, in Village A hundreds of kilometers away, Nikita's neighbor Sergey also expressed similar dissatisfaction with the West.
"But after all, we have our relatives in Ukraine, is this really the best way?" Nikita tried to turn the conversation back to the daily news headlines.
"Oh, really? Maybe you can talk to me about international law, and maybe you can talk about what happened to the Ukrainians, but no one has experienced our humiliation, you know? No one." Sergey predicted the topic. direction, responding to Nikita’s somewhat “outrageous” remarks with angry eyes, “First it was Gorbachev, then Yeltsin, and now Putin, we are always retreating, can’t you see? "
Russia has the largest land area in the world, a large military, and a powerful nuclear arsenal. Its people generally feel confident in its military power. Therefore, it is not easy for outsiders to put themselves in Russia’s security dilemma.
On May 9, 2023 local time, in Moscow, Russia, soldiers lined up during the Victory Day military parade on Red Square to commemorate the 78th anniversary of the end of World War II.

Nikita explained this "paranoia" about security to The Paper reporter: "I won't tell you a lot of history, just one thing. The word 'security' in Russian is безопасность, which literally means ' "There is no danger." This is different from the way words are formed in English, French, and German, and I'm afraid it's also different from Chinese. "
"Language can reflect people's subconscious thinking. So you can see how afraid Russians are of external dangers," he said.
In fact, this mentality is also reflected in Russian official discourse. In order to deal with Western sanctions and external risks, the Russian government has formulated a package of strategies. Among them, the plan named "Fortress Russia" aims to increase the resilience of Russia's economy and society and further reduce its dependence on the West. In fact, as early as 2005, when relations with the West were still in the "honeymoon", a Russian official think tank suggested in a policy document titled "Fortress Russia" that an "isolationist" policy (and even a world view) that would effectively reduce foreign dependence would be It is feasible in the long run.
“The so-called ‘isolationism’ refers to a mode of national existence in which the government only establishes and maintains relatively limited external contacts.

title: 俄总统选举选票全部统计完成，普京得票率为87.28%
content: 根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会网站当地时间3月18日发布的数据，2024年俄罗斯总统选举全部选票均已计票完成。初步数据显示，现任总统普京获得76277708张选票，得票率为87.28%。
translation: According to data released on the website of the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, all votes for the 2024 Russian presidential election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes, with a vote rate of 87.28%.
input: According to data released on the website of the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, all votes for the 2024 Russian presidential election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes, with a vote rate of 87.28%.

title: Russia election: Putin declared winner of race that was never in doubt | AP News
content:
Any public criticism of Putin or his war in Ukraine has been stifled. 
Putin appeared Monday evening on Red Square in the heart of Moscow at a concert to mark the tenth year since he annexed Crimea from Ukraine. Putin’s three token challengers for the presidency appeared on stage beside him and publicly supported him after campaigns in which none of them criticized him.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999. At the end of his fifth term, he would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
Emboldened by his sweeping victory, Putin said he planned to carve out a buffer zone in Ukraine to protect Russia from cross-border shelling and attacks. Asked if an open clash could erupt between Russia and NATO, Putin responded curtly by saying: “Everything is possible in today’s world.” He added, “It’s clear to everyone that it will put us a step away from full-scale World War III.”
Russian officials said they recruited over 500,000 volunteers for the army last year, but many expect Putin to mobilize more forces to attempt to push deeper into Ukraine. Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes. 
The Kremlin is now “increasingly confident,” because it has “learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is,” said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote.
