Putin appeared Monday evening on Red Square in the heart of Moscow at a concert to mark the tenth year since he annexed Crimea from Ukraine. Putin’s three token challengers for the presidency appeared on stage beside him and publicly supported him after campaigns in which none of them criticized him.
Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since December 1999. At the end of his fifth term, he would be the longest-serving Russian leader since Catherine the Great, who ruled during the 18th century.
Emboldened by his sweeping victory, Putin said he planned to carve out a buffer zone in Ukraine to protect Russia from cross-border shelling and attacks. Asked if an open clash could erupt between Russia and NATO, Putin responded curtly by saying: “Everything is possible in today’s world.” He added, “It’s clear to everyone that it will put us a step away from full-scale World War III.”
Russian officials said they recruited over 500,000 volunteers for the army last year, but many expect Putin to mobilize more forces to attempt to push deeper into Ukraine. Analysts say that in the post-election period, Russian authorities could also introduce unpopular measures such as raising taxes. 
The Kremlin is now “increasingly confident,” because it has “learned just how passive the population is and how effective their own repression is,” said Nigel Gould-Davies, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.
Russia’s Central Election Commission said Monday that with all the precincts counted, Putin got 87% of the vote.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
content:
В России завершились первые и истории страны трехдневные выборы президента. На пост главы государства претендовали четыре кандидата. Процесс волеизъявления граждан сопровождался столкновениями с украинскими силами на границе в Курской и Белгородской областях, а также инцидентами на избирательных участках в разных городах. Как проходил процесс голосования и что известно о результатах — в материале «Ленты.ру».

Выборы президента России завершились 17 марта в 21:00 по московскому времени, когда в 20:00 по местному часовому поясу участки закрылись в самой западной точке страны — Калининградской области. Теперь избиркомы приступают к подсчету голосов.

По официальной информации, общая явка на выборах президента России, включая дистанционное электронное голосование, составила 77,44 процента, что стало максимальным показателем в истории современной России. Предыдущий рекорд по явке на президентских выборах — 74,66 процента — был зафиксирован еще до распада СССР, в 1991 году, когда выбирали президента РСФСР. Предыдущий рекордный результат в XXI веке был зафиксирован в 2008 году — 69,81 процента.
translation:
The first three-day presidential election in the country's history has ended in Russia. Four candidates ran for the post of head of state. The process of expressing the will of citizens was accompanied by clashes with Ukrainian forces on the border in the Kursk and Belgorod regions, as well as incidents at polling stations in different cities. How the voting process took place and what is known about the results is in the Lenta.ru material.

The Russian presidential elections ended on March 17 at 21:00 Moscow time, when at 20:00 local time zone polling stations closed in the westernmost point of the country - the Kaliningrad region. Now the election commissions begin counting votes.

According to official information, the overall turnout in the Russian presidential elections, including remote electronic voting, was 77.44 percent, which was the highest figure in the history of modern Russia. The previous record for turnout in presidential elections - 74.66 percent - was recorded before the collapse of the USSR, in 1991, when the president of the RSFSR was elected. The previous record result in the 21st century was recorded in 2008 - 69.81 percent.
input:
The first three-day presidential election in the country's history has ended in Russia. Four candidates ran for the post of head of state. The process of expressing the will of citizens was accompanied by clashes with Ukrainian forces on the border in the Kursk and Belgorod regions, as well as incidents at polling stations in different cities. How the voting process took place and what is known about the results is in the Lenta.ru material.

The Russian presidential elections ended on March 17 at 21:00 Moscow time, when at 20:00 local time zone polling stations closed in the westernmost point of the country - the Kaliningrad region. Now the election commissions begin counting votes.

According to official information, the overall turnout in the Russian presidential elections, including remote electronic voting, was 77.44 percent, which was the highest figure in the history of modern Russia. The previous record for turnout in presidential elections - 74.66 percent - was recorded before the collapse of the USSR, in 1991, when the president of the RSFSR was elected. The previous record result in the 21st century was recorded in 2008 - 69.81 percent.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
content:
有分析认为，这一方面与新冠疫情后人口流动性增加、俄乌冲突后离开俄罗斯的人们陆续回国有关，另一方面也与通胀高企以及越来越高的基准利率密切相关。
根据俄国家统计局今年1月发布的数据，俄罗斯2023年通胀率为7.42%。为了抑制通胀，俄罗斯央行自2023年7月起多次上调基准利率。今年2月16日，俄央行宣布将基准利率维持在16%不变。由于购房贷款利率变高，越来越多的俄罗斯人将目光转向租房市场，从而进一步推高了对出租房的需求。在供不应求、物价上涨的背景下，许多房东选择了提高房租。
这一趋势目前仍在持续。以首都莫斯科为例，Yandex Rent提供的数据显示，今年1月，莫斯科一室公寓的平均租金上涨至5.5万卢布（约合人民币4389元），两室公寓平均租金则达到8万卢布（约合人民币6384元）。而根据莫斯科统计局的数据，2023年1-9月，莫斯科的平均工资同比上涨15.4%，为7.86万卢布（约合人民币6280元）。
对于住房问题，普京在2024年的国情咨文中予以回应，2023年俄罗斯新增住房面积超过1.1亿平方米。未来，俄罗斯将继续加大投入力度，提供优惠的抵押贷款政策，让普通家庭能够负担得起住房，尤其是要减轻多子女家庭在住房上的压力。
在组建自己的小家庭前，德米特里为了节省房租，曾经和自己的两个朋友一起合租过一套三室一厅的公寓。有了自己的孩子后，依靠程序员的工作所带来的高于平均水平的工资，以及“母亲资本”提供的补贴，德米特里贷款买下了一套属于自己的房产。
现在，德米特里已经不再需要为了住房而感到苦恼。对他来说，最大的担忧或许是不知何时能够结束的战争。尽管住在莫斯科周边、远离前线，但他也曾经不止一次听到过有无人机在附近被击落的消息。当听闻普里戈任以及瓦格纳的士兵正在向莫斯科开进时，他也曾感到过恐惧。
关于政治，德米特里不喜欢进行过多的讨论。他坦言，自己不是普京的粉丝，但现在别无选择。与此同时，他也对为乌克兰提供大量武器的西方国家没有好感。德米特里唯一能够确定的是，自己的国家正在进行一场不能输的战争。
“我对战争的态度很复杂。我们有理由发动这场战争，可这一切的发生还是非常可悲的……但我确信，我们必须赢。”
translation:
Some analysts believe that this is related to the increase in population mobility after the COVID-19 epidemic and the continued return of people who left Russia after the Russia-Ukraine conflict. On the other hand, it is also closely related to high inflation and increasingly higher benchmark interest rates.
According to data released by the Russian State Statistics Service in January this year, Russia’s inflation rate in 2023 will be 7.42%. In order to curb inflation, the Central Bank of Russia has raised its benchmark interest rate several times since July 2023. On February 16 this year, the Russian Central Bank announced that it would keep the benchmark interest rate unchanged at 16%. As home loan interest rates rise, more and more Russians are turning their attention to the rental market, further boosting demand for rental housing. With supply exceeding demand and rising prices, many landlords have chosen to raise rents.
This trend is still continuing. Taking the capital Moscow as an example, data provided by Yandex Rent shows that in January this year, the average rent of a one-bedroom apartment in Moscow rose to 55,000 rubles (approximately RMB 4,389), and the average rent of a two-bedroom apartment reached 80,000 rubles (approximately RMB 4,389). RMB 6384). According to data from the Moscow Statistics Bureau, from January to September 2023, the average salary in Moscow increased by 15.4% year-on-year to 78,600 rubles (approximately RMB 6,280).
Regarding the housing issue, Putin responded in his 2024 State of the Union address. In 2023, Russia will have more than 110 million square meters of new housing area. In the future, Russia will continue to increase investment and provide preferential mortgage loan policies to make housing affordable for ordinary families, especially to reduce the housing pressure on families with many children.
Before starting his own small family, Dmitry once shared a three-bedroom apartment with two of his friends in order to save rent. After having his own children, Dmitry took out a loan to buy a property of his own, relying on the above-average salary brought by his job as a programmer and the subsidies provided by "Mother Capital".
Now, Dmitry no longer has to worry about housing. For him, perhaps the biggest worry is the uncertainty of when the war will end. Although he lives near Moscow, far away from the front line, he has heard news more than once that a drone was shot down nearby. He had also felt fear when he heard that Prigozhin and Wagner's soldiers were marching towards Moscow.
Regarding politics, Dmitri did not like to discuss too much. He admitted that he was not a fan of Putin, but now he had no choice. At the same time, he also has no good opinion of Western countries that provide Ukraine with large amounts of weapons. The only thing Dmitry is sure of is that his country is fighting a war it cannot lose.
"I have a complicated attitude towards the war. We had reasons to start this war, but it is still very sad that all this happened... But I am convinced that we must win."

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
content:
当地时间2024年3月18日凌晨，俄罗斯莫斯科，俄罗斯总统普京在莫斯科竞选总部的新闻发布会上发表讲话。   视觉中国 图

据新华社消息，俄罗斯中央选举委员会当地时间3月18日凌晨发布的数据，在俄总统选举统计完成的超95%选票中，现任总统普京以超87%的得票率大幅领先其他候选人，实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
另据环球网援引据俄罗斯卫星通讯社报道，普京18日凌晨在竞选总部发表讲话，他在讲话中感谢选民的信任和支持，并表示将在新的任期内继续推动国家发展。
普京得票率遥遥领先
俄罗斯于3月15日至17日举行总统选举。投票有史以来第一次进行了三天多的时间，并采用了在线投票的方式，该投票方式覆盖了俄罗斯约三分之一的地区。
据央视新闻消息，莫斯科当地时间17日21时（北京时间18日2时）2024俄罗斯总统选举投票结束，俄全境内投票站均已关闭。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会视频墙上发布的最新计票结果，目前2024年总统选举95.08%的选票已经清点完毕，以独立候选人身份参选的俄罗斯现任总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 以87.32%的得票率领先。
俄联邦共产党候选人尼古拉·哈里托诺夫以4.28%的得票率位居第二，其次是俄新人党候选人弗拉迪斯拉夫·达万科夫，得票率为3.85%。俄自由民主党候选人列昂尼德·斯卢茨基排名第四，得票率为3.15%。
俄罗斯政府表示，2024年俄总统选举的投票率为74%，创下历史最高纪录。普京此前的最高的得票纪录是在2018年的总统选举中，彼时普京赢得了76.7%的选票，而当年投票率为67.5%。
根据俄总统选举规则，在选举中获得50%以上选票者当选总统。俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
俄罗斯国家电视台在报道中指出，“这是围绕弗拉基米尔·普京的令人难以置信的支持和团结，也是向西方国家发出的信号”。
俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）副议长康斯坦丁·科萨切夫表示，俄罗斯议员们邀请来监督俄总统选举的国际观察员在三天多的投票期间内没有提出异议。
科萨切夫在社交平台Telegram上称，观察员们的普遍共识是此次俄总统选举符合最高的国际标准；它是公平和诚实的。
translation:
In the early morning of March 18, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a speech at a press conference at the Moscow campaign headquarters.   Visual China Map

According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of March 18, local time, showed that among the more than 95% of the votes counted in the Russian presidential election, the current President Vladimir Putin was significantly ahead of other candidates with more than 87% of the votes. In fact, has won this presidential election.
According to Global Network, Russian Satellite News Agency reported that Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th. In his speech, he thanked voters for their trust and support and stated that he would continue to promote national development during his new term.
Putin leads by a wide margin
Russia holds presidential elections from March 15 to 17. For the first time ever, voting took place over three days and featured online voting, which covered about a third of Russia's regions.
According to CCTV news, voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election ended at 21:00 local time in Moscow on the 17th (2:00 on the 18th Beijing time), and all polling stations across Russia have been closed.
According to the latest vote counting results posted on the video wall of the Russian Central Election Commission, 95.08% of the votes for the 2024 presidential election have been counted. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin (Vladimir Putin), who is running as an independent candidate, has Leading with 87.32% of the votes.
Nikolai Kharitonov, candidate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, came in second with 4.28% of the vote, followed by Vladislav Davankov, candidate of the New People's Party of Russia, with 3.85% of the vote. The candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Leonid Slutsky, ranked fourth with 3.15% of the vote.
The Russian government stated that the turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election was 74%, setting a record high. Putin's previous highest vote record was in the 2018 presidential election, when Putin won 76.7% of the vote, and the turnout rate that year was 67.5%.
According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
Russian state television pointed out in the report that "this is an incredible show of support and unity around Vladimir Putin, and it is also a signal to Western countries."
Konstantin Kosachev, deputy speaker of the Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament), said that international observers invited by Russian parliamentarians to monitor the Russian presidential election raised no objections during the more than three days of voting.
Kosachev said on the social platform Telegram that the general consensus among observers is that the Russian presidential election meets the highest international standards; it is fair and honest.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
普京：迈向第五个任期，不参与选前辩论
弗拉基米尔·普京1952年10月7日出生于列宁格勒（今圣彼得堡）。曾任俄罗斯第5任（1999年）、第9任（2008年-2012年）总理，俄罗斯第3和第4任（2000年 - 2008年）、第6和第7任（2012年 - 2024年）总统（2012年期间，俄罗斯修改宪法，总统任期年限从4年延长到6年）。
普京

据克里姆林宫网站介绍，普京“早在从学校毕业前”就希望进入苏联的情报部门工作。他曾前往克格勃招募中心，在那里，有人建议他先攻读法律学位。1970年普京进入列宁格勒国立大学（今圣彼得堡国立大学）法律系学习，并在1975年获经济学副博士学位。
大学毕业后，普京开始在克格勃工作。1985年，他被派往民主德国工作。1989年，克格勃驻德累斯顿的低级别特工普京被卷入东欧剧变的浪潮。1990年普京回国，在列宁格勒开始了他的政治生涯，担任过列宁格勒大学校长外事助理、圣彼得堡市市长顾问、圣彼得堡市第一副市长等职位。
1996年起，普京在莫斯科担任多项高级职务，包括俄总统事务管理局副局长、俄总统办公厅副主任兼监察总局局长、总统办公厅第一副主任、俄联邦安全总局局长、俄联邦安全会议秘书等。1999年获得时任俄罗斯总统叶利钦任命为总理，12月31日叶利钦突然宣布辞去总统职务，普京受命成为代理总统。2000年3月26日，普京当选俄总统。自此，除2008年-2012年担任总理外，普京一直担任俄罗斯总统一职。
如果普京能够在2024年3月的大选中获胜，将是他第五次担任俄罗斯总统。
translation:
Putin: Moving towards a fifth term, not participating in pre-election debates
Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg). He served as the 5th (1999) and 9th (2008-2012) Prime Minister of Russia, and the 3rd and 4th (2000-2008), 6th and 7th (2012-2024) Prime Ministers of Russia. ) President (During 2012, Russia revised its constitution and extended the presidential term from 4 to 6 years).
Putin

According to the Kremlin website, Putin wanted to work in the Soviet intelligence service "long before he graduated from school." He went to a KGB recruitment center where he was advised to study for a law degree first. In 1970, Putin entered the Law Department of Leningrad State University (now St. Petersburg State University) and received an associate doctorate in economics in 1975.
After graduating from college, Putin began working in the KGB. In 1985, he was sent to work in the Democratic Republic of Germany. In 1989, Putin, a low-level KGB agent stationed in Dresden, was involved in the wave of drastic changes in Eastern Europe. Putin returned to China in 1990 and began his political career in Leningrad. He served as foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg.
Since 1996, Putin has held a number of senior positions in Moscow, including deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Service, deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, first deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration, director of the Russian Federal Security Service, Russian Federal Security Service Conference secretary, etc. In 1999, he was appointed prime minister by then Russian President Yeltsin. On December 31, Yeltsin suddenly announced his resignation as president, and Putin was appointed as acting president. On March 26, 2000, Putin was elected President of Russia. Since then, Putin has served as President of Russia except for serving as Prime Minister from 2008 to 2012.
If Putin can win the general election in March 2024, it will be his fifth term as president of Russia.

According to the Kremlin website, Putin wanted to work in the Soviet intelligence service "long before he graduated from school." He went to a KGB recruitment center where he was advised to study for a law degree first. In 1970, Putin entered the Law Department of Leningrad State University (now St. Petersburg State University) and received an associate doctorate in economics in 1975.
After graduating from college, Putin began working in the KGB. In 1985, he was sent to work in the Democratic Republic of Germany. In 1989, Putin, a low-level KGB agent stationed in Dresden, was involved in the wave of drastic changes in Eastern Europe. Putin returned to China in 1990 and began his political career in Leningrad. He served as foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg.
Since 1996, Putin has held a number of senior positions in Moscow, including deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Service, deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, first deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration, director of the Russian Federal Security Service, Russian Federal Security Service Conference secretary, etc. In 1999, he was appointed prime minister by then Russian President Yeltsin. On December 31, Yeltsin suddenly announced his resignation as president, and Putin was appointed as acting president. On March 26, 2000, Putin was elected President of Russia. Since then, Putin has served as President of Russia except for serving as Prime Minister from 2008 to 2012.
If Putin can win the general election in March 2024, it will be his fifth term as president of Russia.

title: 普京宣布压倒性胜利再连任6年！各国反应一次看 | 文学城
content:
▲普丁再度当选俄罗斯总统。

俄罗斯大选17日落幕，总统普丁宣布获得逾87%选票，以压倒性胜利赢得连任，将继续主宰国家6年，而《路透社》也整理各国政府或官员对于这场大选的回应。
美国白宫国安委员会发言人
「考虑到普丁如何监禁政治异议人士，并且阻止其他人参选、与他竞争，这场大选显然既不自由也不公正。」

▲俄罗斯大选日，民众在投票所外排队参与「午」逆普丁（Noon against
Putin）抗议行动。
乌克兰总统泽伦斯基

「这些日子以来，俄罗斯独裁者正在模拟另一场选举。对于世界上每一个人来说都很清楚，正如历史上经常发生的那样，这号人物就是对权力有着病态的渴望，而且正在竭尽全力永远统治下去。这种模仿选举没有、也不可能具有合法性。这个人应该在海牙（国际刑事法院）接受审判。这是我们必须确保的。」
德国外交部

「俄罗斯这场伪造的选举既不自由也不公正，结果更不会让任何人感到意外。普丁的统治是专制的，他仰赖的是审查、压制与暴力。这场在乌克兰被占领地区的『选举』是无效的，也是另一次违反国际法的行为。」

一名乌克兰男子在被俄罗斯控制的顿内茨克（Donetsk）投票站投票。
英国外交大臣卡麦隆（David Cameron）
「在乌克兰领土上非法举行选举后，在俄罗斯的投票已经结束了，选民没有选择，也缺乏欧洲安全与合作组织（OSCE
）的独立监督。这不是自由公正选举看起来的模样。」
波兰外交部

「2024年3月15至17日，俄罗斯举行了所谓的总统大选。投票是在对于社会极端压迫的情况下进行的，因此不可能做出自由民主的选择。」
translation:
▲Putin was re-elected as President of Russia.

The Russian election ended on the 17th. President Putin announced that he had won more than 87% of the votes and won re-election with an overwhelming victory. He will continue to dominate the country for 6 years. Reuters also compiled the responses of governments or officials from various countries to this election.
Spokesperson of the White House National Security Council
"Given how Putin has imprisoned political dissidents and prevented others from running against him, this election is clearly neither free nor fair."

▲On Russia’s election day, people lined up outside polling stations to participate in the Noon against Putin
Putin) protests.
Ukrainian President Zelensky

"These days, the Russian dictator is simulating another election. It is clear to everyone in the world that, as so often happens in history, this man has a pathological thirst for power and is doing everything he can to Forever. This copycat election has no legitimacy. This man should be tried in The Hague (International Criminal Court).”
german foreign ministry

“Russia’s sham election was neither free nor fair, and the results will surprise no one. Putin’s rule is authoritarian, relying on censorship, repression and violence. This election in occupied Ukraine The 'election' was invalid and another violation of international law."

A Ukrainian man cast his vote at a polling station in Donetsk, a Russian-controlled city.
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron
"The voting in Russia has ended after illegal elections were held on Ukrainian territory, leaving voters with no choice and lack of support from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)
) independent supervision. This is not what a free and fair election looks like. "
Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs

"On March 15-17, 2024, Russia held a so-called presidential election. The voting was conducted under conditions of extreme social oppression, making it impossible to make a free and democratic choice."

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
content:
Завершен подсчет голосов после выборов президента России. Главное об итогах голосования — в материале РБК
Владимир Путин лидирует с 87,28%, свидетельствуют данные ЦИК после обработки 100% протоколов. Вторым идет Николай Харитонов (4,31%), третьим — Владислав Даванков (3,85%), четвертым — Леонид Слуцкий (3,20%). Число поданных голосов за Путина превысило 75,9 млн и поставило абсолютный рекорд.
По результатам федерального ДЭГ (не включая Москву, считается отдельно) Путин набирает 87,41% голосов, сообщает ЦИК. Даванков занимает второе место с 6,28% голосов, у Слуцкого и Харитонова — соответственно 3,75 и 2,56%.
translation:
The counting of votes after the Russian presidential elections has been completed. The main thing about the voting results is in the RBC material
Vladimir Putin is in the lead with 87.28%, according to CEC data after processing 100% of the protocols. Second is Nikolai Kharitonov (4.31%), third is Vladislav Davankov (3.85%), fourth is Leonid Slutsky (3.20%). The number of votes cast for Putin exceeded 75.9 million and set an absolute record.
According to the results of the federal DEG (not including Moscow, counted separately), Putin gains 87.41% of the votes, the CEC reports. Davankov takes second place with 6.28% of the votes, Slutsky and Kharitonov have 3.75 and 2.56%, respectively.
input:
The counting of votes after the Russian presidential elections has been completed. The main thing about the voting results is in the RBC material
Vladimir Putin is in the lead with 87.28%, according to CEC data after processing 100% of the protocols. Second is Nikolai Kharitonov (4.31%), third is Vladislav Davankov (3.85%), fourth is Leonid Slutsky (3.20%). The number of votes cast for Putin exceeded 75.9 million and set an absolute record.
According to the results of the federal DEG (not including Moscow, counted separately), Putin gains 87.41% of the votes, the CEC reports. Davankov takes second place with 6.28% of the votes, Slutsky and Kharitonov have 3.75 and 2.56%, respectively.

title: 普京称“在台湾问题上对中国挑衅注定失败”，中方高度赞赏
content:
3月18日，外交部发言人林剑主持例行记者会。塔斯社记者提问，俄罗斯总统普京今天在总统选举后的发布会表示，对华不友好的国家在台湾问题上对中国挑衅注定失败。中方对此有何评论？
林剑表示，中方高度赞赏普京总统的有关表态。世界上只有一个中国，中华人民共和国政府是代表全中国的唯一合法政府，台湾是中国领土不可分割的一部分，这是国际社会普遍共识和公认的国际关系基本准则。
translation:
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference. A reporter from TASS asked: Russian President Vladimir Putin said at a press conference after the presidential election today that provocations by countries unfriendly to China on the Taiwan issue are destined to fail. What is China's comment?
Lin Jian said that China highly appreciates President Putin’s relevant remarks. There is only one China in the world. The government of the People's Republic of China is the only legitimate government representing the whole of China. Taiwan is an inalienable part of China's territory. This is the general consensus of the international community and the recognized basic norm of international relations.
input:
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference. A reporter from TASS asked: Russian President Vladimir Putin said at a press conference after the presidential election today that provocations by countries unfriendly to China on the Taiwan issue are destined to fail. What is China's comment?
Lin Jian said that China highly appreciates President Putin’s relevant remarks. There is only one China in the world. The government of the People's Republic of China is the only legitimate government representing the whole of China. Taiwan is an inalienable part of China's territory. This is the general consensus of the international community and the recognized basic norm of international relations.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
content:
Зеленка, поджоги и петарды. Что происходило на избирательных участках?
В ходе голосования на избирательных участках произошел ряд инцидентов, связанных с порчей бюллетеней. Так, в Москве женщина вылила краску в урну с бюллетенями, на другом столичном участке подожгли будку для голосования.

В Санкт-Петербурге на избирательном участке бросили бутылку с зажигательной смесью; в Воронежской области на двух участках урны залили зеленкой; в Карачаево-Черкесии женщина залила бюллетени чернилами; аналогичный случай произошел в Ростове-на-Дону. В Челябинской области на одном из избирательных участков попытались взорвать петарду.

Самый серьезный известный на данный момент инцидент произошел на территории избирательного участка в Перми: посетительница взорвала петарду. По предварительной информации, 64-летней женщине оторвало руку

По другой информации, у нее лишь травма руки. Пострадавшей оказали медицинскую помощь и госпитализировали. По словам очевидцев, перед взрывом гражданка разговаривала с кем-то по телефону. Возможно, она говорила с мошенниками. Также отмечается, что при себе у нее был пакет, охранник проверил его содержимое, но не увидел ничего запрещенного. Правоохранительные органы проводят проверку.

Уже известно об уголовных делах. Московские следователи возбудили дело в отношении местной жительницы, которая вылила красящее вещество в урну для бюллетеней. Также были возбуждены еще два уголовных дела из-за инцидентов на избирательных участках в Карачаево-Черкесской Республике и Ростовской области.
translation:
Green paint, arson and firecrackers. What happened at the polling stations?
During voting at polling stations, a number of incidents involving damage to ballots occurred. Thus, in Moscow, a woman poured paint into a ballot box, and at another precinct in the capital, a voting booth was set on fire.

In St. Petersburg, a Molotov cocktail was thrown at a polling station; in the Voronezh region, in two areas, ballot boxes were filled with brilliant green; in Karachay-Cherkessia, a woman spilled ink on ballot papers; a similar incident occurred in Rostov-on-Don. In the Chelyabinsk region, they tried to explode a firecracker at one of the polling stations.

The most serious incident known to date occurred on the territory of a polling station in Perm: a visitor exploded a firecracker. According to preliminary information, a 64-year-old woman's arm was torn off

According to other information, she only has a hand injury. The victim was given medical assistance and hospitalized. According to eyewitnesses, before the explosion, the citizen was talking to someone on the phone. Perhaps she was talking to scammers. It is also noted that she had a package with her, the guard checked its contents, but did not see anything prohibited. Law enforcement agencies are conducting an investigation.

Criminal cases are already known. Moscow investigators opened a case against a local resident who poured a dye into a ballot box. Two more criminal cases were also opened due to incidents at polling stations in the Karachay-Cherkess Republic and the Rostov region.
input:
Green paint, arson and firecrackers. What happened at the polling stations?
During voting at polling stations, a number of incidents involving damage to ballots occurred. Thus, in Moscow, a woman poured paint into a ballot box, and at another precinct in the capital, a voting booth was set on fire.

In St. Petersburg, a Molotov cocktail was thrown at a polling station; in the Voronezh region, in two areas, ballot boxes were filled with brilliant green; in Karachay-Cherkessia, a woman spilled ink on ballot papers; a similar incident occurred in Rostov-on-Don. In the Chelyabinsk region, they tried to explode a firecracker at one of the polling stations.

The most serious incident known to date occurred on the territory of a polling station in Perm: a visitor exploded a firecracker. According to preliminary information, a 64-year-old woman's arm was torn off

According to other information, she only has a hand injury. The victim was given medical assistance and hospitalized. According to eyewitnesses, before the explosion, the citizen was talking to someone on the phone. Perhaps she was talking to scammers. It is also noted that she had a package with her, the guard checked its contents, but did not see anything prohibited. Law enforcement agencies are conducting an investigation.

Criminal cases are already known. Moscow investigators opened a case against a local resident who poured a dye into a ballot box. Two more criminal cases were also opened due to incidents at polling stations in the Karachay-Cherkess Republic and the Rostov region.

title: 普京大胜,谁赞成,谁反对？
content:
本届俄罗斯总统大选在3月15日~17日进行,前两天根据统计超过90%选票的结果,普京已经获胜。今天,俄罗斯中央选举委员会正式宣布,普京赢得本届俄罗斯总统大选,将展开新的六年任期。
这场选举,在开始前全世界基本都预判普京最后能赢,不过西方还是提前布局了三个“黑普京”的点。
第一个,西方媒体密集搜寻,希望在选举过程中找到激烈反普京的游行,或者破坏选举站的暴动。
第二个,西方媒体盯着总投票人数,即便普京赢了,如果总投票人数不如以往,西方就可以吹嘘“沉默的大多数”才是反对的真民意。
第三个,就是普京最终获胜的支持率。今年是普京参加的第五次总统选举,每次支持率不同,如果这次支持率降低,西方也可以炒作普京掌控力下降,或者民众反普京意愿抬头。
结果普京选举不仅赢了,而且我称他为大胜,就是因为他赢的同时,戳破了西方三大图谋。
在“反普京集会,破坏选举站”方面,西方提前布局,舍弃了流放北极,失去影响力的纳瓦里内,扶植他的“未亡人”,希望成为攻击普京的黑寡妇。
纳瓦里内领导的反对派在国外社交媒体上, 确实声嘶力竭的号召俄罗斯民众拒绝投票。或者投反对票。结果应者寥寥,西方媒体搜遍俄罗斯全国,也只找到一个俄罗斯老人泼投票站油漆的“反选举新闻”。
另外,本次选举,普京在投票总人数破历史记录,突破74%的情况下,支持率也打破历次选举纪录,达到惊人的87.3%。
普京2000年首次参选的得票率为53%,2004年是71%,2012年是63%,2018年是76%。也就是说今年的普京,比历史最鼎盛时期,支持率还要高10%。
超高的投票率叠加超高的支持率,让全世界看清了,催动俄乌冲突这场仗的,不是普京个人的意愿,而是北约东扩践踏了全体俄罗斯人共同信奉的安全观念。
面对普京这场大胜,世界各国的态度是不一样的,潜台词就是有些人支持,有些人反对。
translation:
The current Russian presidential election was held from March 15th to 17th. According to the results of the first two days, more than 90% of the votes were counted, and Putin had won. Today, Russia's Central Election Commission officially announced that Putin won the current Russian presidential election and will start a new six-year term.
Before this election, the whole world basically predicted that Putin would win in the end. However, the West still laid out three "black Putin" points in advance.
First, the Western media searched intensively, hoping to find violent anti-Putin demonstrations during the election process, or riots that disrupted election stations.
Second, the Western media focuses on the total number of voters. Even if Putin wins, if the total number of voters is not as good as before, the West can boast that the "silent majority" is the real public opinion against it.
The third one is the support rate for Putin’s final victory. This year is the fifth presidential election that Putin has participated in. Each time the support rate is different. If the support rate drops this time, the West can also hype Putin's decline in control or the rise of people's anti-Putin desire.
As a result, Putin not only won the election, but I called him a great victory because when he won, he exposed the three major plots of the West.
In terms of "anti-Putin rallies and destruction of election stations", the West made plans in advance, abandoning Navalny, who was exiled in the Arctic and losing influence, and supported his "widow" in the hope of becoming a black widow to attack Putin.
The opposition led by Navariny indeed called on the Russian people hoarse on foreign social media to refuse to vote. Or vote no. As a result, very few people responded. Western media searched all over Russia and found only "anti-election news" about an old Russian man throwing paint at a polling station.
In addition, in this election, Putin's approval rate also broke previous election records, reaching an astonishing 87.3% when the total number of voters broke the historical record, exceeding 74%.
Putin's vote rate when he first ran for office was 53% in 2000, 71% in 2004, 63% in 2012, and 76% in 2018. In other words, Putin's approval rate this year is 10% higher than during his peak period in history.
The ultra-high turnout combined with the ultra-high support rate made it clear to the world that it was not Putin's personal wishes that drove the Russia-Ukraine conflict, but that NATO's eastward expansion trampled on the security concepts shared by all Russians. .
Faced with Putin's great victory, the attitudes of countries around the world are different. The subtext is that some people support it and some people oppose it.

title: Russia election: Putin basks in electoral victory even as Russians quietly protest | AP News
content:
Several people were arrested, including in Moscow and St. Petersburg, after they tried to start fires or set off explosives at polling stations while others were detained for throwing green antiseptic or ink into ballot boxes.
Stanislav Andreychuk, co-chair of the Golos independent election watchdog, said that pressure on voters from law enforcement had reached unprecedented levels. 
Russians, he said in a social media post, were searched when entering polling stations, there were attempts to check filled-out ballots before they were cast, and one report said police demanded a ballot box be opened to remove a ballot.
“It’s the first time in my life that I’ve seen such absurdities,” Andreychuk wrote on the messaging app Telegram, adding that he started monitoring elections in Russia 20 years ago. 
The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that 80 people were arrested in 20 cities across Russia on Sunday.
That left little room for people to express their displeasure, but Ivan Zhdanov, the head of Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation, said that the opposition’s call to protest had been successful.
Beyond Russia, huge lines also formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris, Milan, Belgrade and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. 
Protesters in Berlin displayed a figure of Putin bathing in a bath of blood with the Ukrainian flag on the side, alongside shredded ballots in ballot boxes. 
Russian state television and officials said the lines abroad showed strong turnout.
In Tallinn, where hundreds stood in a line snaking around the Estonian capital’s cobbled streets leading to the Russian Embassy, 23-year-old Tatiana said she came to take part in the protest. 
“If we have some option to protest I think it’s important to utilize any opportunity,” she said, only giving her first name.
Boris Nadezhdin, a liberal politician who tried to join the race on an anti-war platform but was barred from running by election officials, voiced hope that many Russians cast their ballots against Putin.
“I believe that the Russian people today have a chance to show their real attitude to what is happening by voting not for Putin, but for some other candidates or in some other way, which is exactly what I did,” he said after voting in Dolgoprudny, a town just outside Moscow.

The OVD-Info group that monitors political arrests said that 80 people were arrested in 20 cities across Russia on Sunday.
That left little room for people to express their displeasure, but Ivan Zhdanov, the head of Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation, said that the opposition’s call to protest had been successful.
Beyond Russia, huge lines also formed around noon outside diplomatic missions in London, Berlin, Paris, Milan, Belgrade and other cities with large Russian communities, many of whom left home after Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

Boris Nadezhdin, a liberal politician who tried to join the race on an anti-war platform but was barred from running by election officials, voiced hope that many Russians cast their ballots against Putin.
“I believe that the Russian people today have a chance to show their real attitude to what is happening by voting not for Putin, but for some other candidates or in some other way, which is exactly what I did,” he said after voting in Dolgoprudny, a town just outside Moscow.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
content:
在大选前接受采访时，哈里托诺夫曾表示：“无论谁赢得选举，都必须考虑到每一张选票和每一位候选人的方案。只有这样，我们才能团结民众。”此外，哈里托诺夫还表示，他在竞选期间不会批评现任总统普京，“每个人都要对自己的工作负责，因此选民将评估我和包括普京在内的其他候选人的工作成果。”
名单之外
在此次俄罗斯大选中，除最终被确认的4名参选者外，有多名有意参选者最终因提交材料存在问题、未能收集足够签名等原因而未能获得参选资格。其中，纳杰日丁、敦佐娃这两位“反战派”人士备受各方关注。
纳杰日丁
纳杰日丁1963年出生于苏联时期的乌兹别克斯坦塔什干，后随父母移居至莫斯科州，就读于莫斯科物理技术学院物理与能源问题系，在1989年获得副博士学位，随后又学习了法律。
上世纪90年代初，纳杰日丁在莫斯科州多尔戈普鲁德内市开始了自己的政治生涯，后曾担任时任总理谢尔盖·基里延科（1998）的助理，并加入由后者领导的“右翼力量联盟”。1999年年底，纳杰日丁曾当选为国家杜马议员并工作至2003年，但随后未能再度当选。2005年，纳杰日丁还曾参与到提名尤科斯石油公司总裁霍多尔科夫斯基进入国家杜马的一个倡议小组中。当时，霍多尔科夫斯基已经被捕近两年。
2008年“右翼力量联盟”解散后，纳杰日丁依然活跃于政治舞台，曾代表不同政党活动。2023年10月，纳杰日丁宣布通过公民倡议党参加2024年总统大选。该党由叶利钦时期的经济部长安德烈·涅恰耶夫于2012年创建。由于公民倡议党未进入国家杜马，纳杰日丁需要收集10万个签名，并在2024年1月31日前提交至俄中选委。
translation:
In an interview before the election, Kharitonov once said: "No matter who wins the election, every vote and every candidate's plan must be taken into account. Only in this way can we unite the people." In addition, Kharitonov Nov also said he would not criticize current President Putin during the campaign. "Everyone is responsible for their own work, so voters will evaluate the work results of me and other candidates, including Putin."
outside the list
In this Russian general election, in addition to the four candidates who were finally confirmed, many potential candidates were ultimately unable to qualify for the election due to problems with the submitted materials and the failure to collect enough signatures. Among them, Nadezhidin and Duntsova, two "anti-war" figures, have attracted much attention from all parties.
nadezdin
Nadezhidin was born in Tashkent, Uzbekistan during the Soviet period in 1963. He later moved to Moscow Oblast with his parents and studied at the Department of Physics and Energy Issues of the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology. He received an associate's degree in 1989 and later studied law.
In the early 1990s, Nadezdin began his political career in Dolgoprudny, Moscow Region. He later served as an assistant to then Prime Minister Sergey Kiriyenko (1998) and joined the The "right-wing forces alliance" led by the latter. At the end of 1999, Nadezdin was elected as a member of the State Duma and worked until 2003, but was subsequently unable to be re-elected. In 2005, Nadezdin also participated in an initiative group that nominated Yukos President Khodorkovsky to the State Duma. At that time, Khodorkovsky had been arrested for nearly two years.
After the disbandment of the "Union of Right-wing Powers" in 2008, Nadezdin remained active in the political arena and represented different political parties. In October 2023, Nadezdin announced his participation in the 2024 presidential election through the Citizens' Initiative Party. The party was founded in 2012 by Andrei Nechayev, Yeltsin's economy minister. Since the Civic Initiative Party has not entered the State Duma, Nadezdin needs to collect 100,000 signatures and submit them to the Russian-Chinese Election Committee before January 31, 2024.

Only in this way can we unite the people." In addition, Kharitonov Nov also said he would not criticize current President Putin during the campaign. "Everyone is responsible for their own work, so voters will evaluate the work results of me and other candidates, including Putin."

title: 俄罗斯总统选举投票结束，目前数据显示普京得票率超87%
content:
当地时间3月17日，俄罗斯莫斯科，一名女性在投票站为俄总统选举投票。

莫斯科当地时间3月17日21时（北京时间18日2时），2024俄罗斯总统选举投票结束，俄全境内投票站均已关闭。
另据新华社报道，俄罗斯中央选举委员会17日晚宣布，在已统计的60.01%的俄总统选举选票中，普京得票率为87.26%。
俄罗斯民调机构17日发布的俄总统选举出口民调数据显示，现任总统普京以87.8%的得票率在4名候选人中领先。
据俄罗斯媒体报道，俄罗斯社会舆论基金会发布的出口民调数据显示，俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫以4.7%的得票率位居第二，名列第三的俄新人党达万科夫得票率为3.6%，俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基得票率为2.5%，位列第四。
俄罗斯联邦第八届总统选举正式投票于15日至17日举行。根据俄总统选举规则，获得半数以上选票者即可当选总统。如果总统候选人数超过两名，并且任何一名候选人都未能获得半数以上选票，中央选举委员会将宣布得票领先的两名候选人进入第二轮投票。在第二轮投票中，得票领先者当选。
俄中央选举委员会将不晚于3月28日确认此次总统选举结果，并在选举结果确认后3日内予以公布。
translation:
On March 17, local time, in Moscow, Russia, a woman voted at a polling station for the Russian presidential election.

Voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election ended at 21:00 local time in Moscow on March 17 (2:00 Beijing time on the 18th), and all polling stations across Russia have been closed.
According to Xinhua News Agency, Russia’s Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th that Putin won 87.26% of the 60.01% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election.
Exit poll data for the Russian presidential election released by a Russian polling agency on the 17th showed that current President Putin led among the four candidates with 87.8% of the vote.
According to Russian media reports, exit poll data released by the Russian Social Opinion Foundation showed that Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.7% of the vote, and Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third. The vote rate was 3.6%, and Slutsky of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party ranked fourth with 2.5% of the vote.
The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than half of the votes can be elected president. If there are more than two presidential candidates and no candidate obtains more than half of the votes cast, the Central Election Commission will announce that the two leading candidates will advance to the second round of voting. In the second round of voting, the top vote-getter is elected.
The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
input:

According to Xinhua News Agency, Russia’s Central Election Commission announced on the evening of the 17th that Putin won 87.26% of the 60.01% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election.
Exit poll data for the Russian presidential election released by a Russian polling agency on the 17th showed that current President Putin led among the four candidates with 87.8% of the vote.
According to Russian media reports, exit poll data released by the Russian Social Opinion Foundation showed that Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.7% of the vote, and Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third. The vote rate was 3.6%, and Slutsky of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party ranked fourth with 2.5% of the vote.
The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than half of the votes can be elected president. If there are more than two presidential candidates and no candidate obtains more than half of the votes cast, the Central Election Commission will announce that the two leading candidates will advance to the second round of voting. In the second round of voting, the top vote-getter is elected.
The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.

title: Владимир Путин получил на выборах президента рекордный уровень поддержки
content: Россия выбрала президента на предстоящие шесть лет. Когда подписывался номер, избирательные комиссии еще продолжали подсчеты, но уже было ясно: действующий лидер страны Владимир Путин побеждает с рекордным уровнем поддержки россиян. Более 87% - такой результат в его пользу отображался на табло ЦИК по итогам обработки 40% протоколов участковых избиркомов. И еще важный момент - решение голосовать приняли рекордное число жителей Российской Федерации. Явка на момент закрытия голосования - 74,22%. Об этом сообщает "Рамблер".
translation: Russia has elected a president for the next six years. When the number was signed, the election commissions were still counting, but it was already clear: the current leader of the country, Vladimir Putin, was winning with a record level of support from Russians. More than 87% - this result in his favor was displayed on the CEC board based on the results of processing 40% of the protocols of precinct election commissions. And another important point is that a record number of residents of the Russian Federation decided to vote. Turnout at the close of voting was 74.22%. Rambler reports this.
input: Russia has elected a president for the next six years. When the number was signed, the election commissions were still counting, but it was already clear: the current leader of the country, Vladimir Putin, was winning with a record level of support from Russians. More than 87% - this result in his favor was displayed on the CEC board based on the results of processing 40% of the protocols of precinct election commissions. And another important point is that a record number of residents of the Russian Federation decided to vote. Turnout at the close of voting was 74.22%. Rambler reports this.

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
Французское же издание Le Journal du Dimanche рассказало о живущих в эмиграции гражданах России, которые, тем не менее, пришли на участки в дипломатических представительствах, чтобы исполнить свой долг:
В воскресенье 17 марта перед зданием российского посольства в Париже, несмотря на ливень, выстроилась очередь, растянувшаяся на сотни метров. Некоторые выражали свою поддержку президенту, скандируя: "Путин! Путин!" Другие предпочли остаться незамеченными и бесшумно проскользнули внутрь огромного здания на бульваре Ланн, не сообщая, напротив чьего имени они намерены поставить галочку в бюллетени.
translation:
The French publication Le Journal du Dimanche spoke about Russian citizens living in exile who, nevertheless, came to the stations in diplomatic missions to fulfill their duty:
On Sunday, March 17, in front of the Russian Embassy in Paris, despite the rain, a line stretched hundreds of meters. Some expressed their support for the president, chanting: "Putin! Putin!" Others chose to remain unnoticed and slipped silently inside the huge building on the Boulevard Lannes, without telling whose name they intended to tick off the ballot.
input:
The French publication Le Journal du Dimanche spoke about Russian citizens living in exile who, nevertheless, came to the stations in diplomatic missions to fulfill their duty:
On Sunday, March 17, in front of the Russian Embassy in Paris, despite the rain, a line stretched hundreds of meters. Some expressed their support for the president, chanting: "Putin! Putin!" Others chose to remain unnoticed and slipped silently inside the huge building on the Boulevard Lannes, without telling whose name they intended to tick off the ballot.

title: 普京提交自我提名总统选举候选人材料
content:
当地时间12月18日，俄罗斯总统新闻秘书佩斯科夫表示，当天俄罗斯总统普京向俄中央选举委员会提交了作为自我提名总统选举候选人所需的材料。
此前，普京于本月8日宣布将参加2024年俄罗斯总统选举。俄中央选举委员会当天宣布，俄总统选举的具体投票日为2024年3月15日、16日和17日。
translation:
On December 18, local time, Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin submitted the materials required to self-nominate a candidate for the presidential election to the Russian Central Election Commission that day.
Previously, Putin announced on the 8th of this month that he would participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election. The Russian Central Election Commission announced that day that the specific voting days for the Russian presidential election are March 15, 16 and 17, 2024.
input:
On December 18, local time, Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin submitted the materials required to self-nominate a candidate for the presidential election to the Russian Central Election Commission that day.
Previously, Putin announced on the 8th of this month that he would participate in the 2024 Russian presidential election. The Russian Central Election Commission announced that day that the specific voting days for the Russian presidential election are March 15, 16 and 17, 2024.

title: Russian presidential election 2024: Putin extends one-man rule after stage-managed election devoid of credible opposition | CNN
content:
President Vladimir Putin has tightened his grip on the country he has ruled since the turn of the century, winning Russia’s stage-managed election by an overwhelming majority in a result that was a foregone conclusion.
    

            Putin won 87.3% of the vote on a record turnout of 77.5%, the Central Election Commission (CEC) reported Monday after all the ballots from the three-day presidential vote were counted.
    

            The result means Putin will rule until at least 2030, when he will be 77. Russia’s longest-serving leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, he will secure a third full decade of rule.
    

            With most opposition candidates either dead, jailed, exiled or barred from running – and with dissent effectively outlawed in Russia since it launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 – Putin faced no credible challenge to his rule.
    

            The candidates allowed to oppose Putin were carefully curated by the Kremlin. His nearest rival, Nikolay Kharitonov of the Communist Party, had won just 4.3% of the ballots counted.
    

            The result was inevitable – Putin’s spokesman said last year that the vote was “not really democracy” but “costly bureaucracy” – but the ritual of elections is nonetheless crucially important to the Kremlin as a means of confirming Putin’s authority.
    

            The ritual used to be held every four years, before the law was changed in 2008 to extend presidential terms to six years. Later constitutional changes removed presidential term limits, potentially allowing Putin to stay in power until 2036.
    

            In a victory lap at his election headquarters late Sunday, Putin said the election had “consolidated” national unity and that there were “many tasks ahead” for Russia as it continues its course of confrontation with the West.
input:
President Vladimir Putin has tightened his grip on the country he has ruled since the turn of the century, winning Russia’s stage-managed election by an overwhelming majority in a result that was a foregone conclusion.
    

            Putin won 87.3% of the vote on a record turnout of 77.5%, the Central Election Commission (CEC) reported Monday after all the ballots from the three-day presidential vote were counted.
    

            The result means Putin will rule until at least 2030, when he will be 77. Russia’s longest-serving leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, he will secure a third full decade of rule.
    

            With most opposition candidates either dead, jailed, exiled or barred from running – and with dissent effectively outlawed in Russia since it launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 – Putin faced no credible challenge to his rule.
    

            The candidates allowed to oppose Putin were carefully curated by the Kremlin. His nearest rival, Nikolay Kharitonov of the Communist Party, had won just 4.3% of the ballots counted.
    

            The result was inevitable – Putin’s spokesman said last year that the vote was “not really democracy” but “costly bureaucracy” – but the ritual of elections is nonetheless crucially important to the Kremlin as a means of confirming Putin’s authority.
    

            The ritual used to be held every four years, before the law was changed in 2008 to extend presidential terms to six years. Later constitutional changes removed presidential term limits, potentially allowing Putin to stay in power until 2036.
    

            In a victory lap at his election headquarters late Sunday, Putin said the election had “consolidated” national unity and that there were “many tasks ahead” for Russia as it continues its course of confrontation with the West.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
content:
1999年,普京重拳出击,出动10万大军和新型装备,历时三年基本肃清了车臣境内非法武装,取得第二次车臣战争胜利。
在某一年的年度记者会上,普京曾讲过一个“佩剑换表”的故事,强调发展军事力量的重要性:一位前军官问他的儿子,原有的一把佩剑去哪了？儿子回答把它拿去跟邻居小孩换表了。军官看了看换来的表,对儿子说,“不错,但如果有一天强盗来了,打我、妈妈还有你的兄弟,欺侮你的姐妹。你该怎么办？跟他说‘晚上好,现在是莫斯科时间12点30分？’”
近些年来,俄罗斯的军事现代化水平不断提升。2012年,俄军现代化武器装备所占比例只有16%,2021年底,这一比例达到了71.2%。2022年后,尽管俄罗斯在对乌克兰的特别军事行动中投入了大量军事资源,但仍保持了对“三位一体”战略核力量的投入力度,将其中现代化武器装备的比例提升至95%,以确保对北约进行有效战略威慑。
同时,俄罗斯的新式武器系统也在不断突破,“锆石”海基高超音速巡航导弹已投入使用,“先锋”洲际高超音速导弹等已进入战斗值班,“海燕”核动力巡航导弹的试验已接近完成。
translation:
In 1999, Putin struck hard, dispatching 100,000 troops and new equipment. It took three years to basically eliminate the illegal armed forces in Chechnya and win the second Chechen War.
At the annual press conference of a certain year, Putin once told a story about "exchanging swords for watches" to emphasize the importance of developing military power: A former military officer asked his son where the original sword went. Already? The son replied that he took it to exchange watches with a neighbor's kid. The officer looked at the exchanged watch and said to his son, "Yes, but if one day a robber comes and beats me, my mother and your brothers, and bullies your sisters. What should you do? Say to him 'Good evening' , it’s 12:30 Moscow time?’”
In recent years, Russia's military modernization level has continued to improve. In 2012, the proportion of modern weapons and equipment in the Russian army was only 16%. By the end of 2021, this proportion reached 71.2%. After 2022, although Russia invested a large amount of military resources in its special military operation against Ukraine, it still maintained its investment in the "Trinity" strategic nuclear force and increased the proportion of modern weapons and equipment to 95% to ensure that it NATO conducts effective strategic deterrence.
At the same time, Russia's new weapon systems are also making continuous breakthroughs. The "Zircon" sea-based hypersonic cruise missile has been put into use, the "Pioneer" intercontinental hypersonic missile has entered combat duty, and the test of the "Haiyan" nuclear-powered cruise missile is approaching. Finish.
input:
In 1999, Putin struck hard, dispatching 100,000 troops and new equipment. It took three years to basically eliminate the illegal armed forces in Chechnya and win the second Chechen War.
At the annual press conference of a certain year, Putin once told a story about "exchanging swords for watches" to emphasize the importance of developing military power: A former military officer asked his son where the original sword went. Already? The son replied that he took it to exchange watches with a neighbor's kid. The officer looked at the exchanged watch and said to his son, "Yes, but if one day a robber comes and beats me, my mother and your brothers, and bullies your sisters. What should you do? Say to him 'Good evening' , it’s 12:30 Moscow time?’”
In recent years, Russia's military modernization level has continued to improve. In 2012, the proportion of modern weapons and equipment in the Russian army was only 16%. By the end of 2021, this proportion reached 71.2%. After 2022, although Russia invested a large amount of military resources in its special military operation against Ukraine, it still maintained its investment in the "Trinity" strategic nuclear force and increased the proportion of modern weapons and equipment to 95% to ensure that it NATO conducts effective strategic deterrence.
At the same time, Russia's new weapon systems are also making continuous breakthroughs. The "Zircon" sea-based hypersonic cruise missile has been put into use, the "Pioneer" intercontinental hypersonic missile has entered combat duty, and the test of the "Haiyan" nuclear-powered cruise missile is approaching. Finish.

title: With the election behind him, Putin says Russia aims to set up a buffer zone inside Ukraine | AP News
content:
A possible conflict between Russia and NATO would put the world “a step away” from World War III, he said.
French President Emmanuel Macron recently said that sending Western troops into Ukraine should not be ruled out, though he said the current situation does not require it.
Commenting on the prospects for peace talks with Kyiv, Putin reaffirmed that Russia remains open to negotiations but won’t be lured into a truce that will allow Ukraine to rearm.
However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has apparently shut the door on such talks, saying Putin should be brought to trial at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, which last year issued an arrest warrant for Putin on war crime charges.
With crucial U.S. aid being held up in Washington, U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham visited Kyiv on Monday. Ukraine desperately needs the around $48 billion that the package of support would provide, especially artillery shells and air defense systems.
Graham said he discussed the issue with Zelenskyy and suggested that aid in the form of a no-interest loan might get more more support from U.S. voters. He also denounced the result of Russia’s presidential election as “not legitimate” and said he wanted to introduce legislation in the U.S. that would deem Russia a state sponsor of terrorism.
Ukraine’s air force said it intercepted 17 out of 22 Shahed drones launched by Russia over various regions of the country overnight. Russia also fired five S-300/S-400 missiles at the Kharkiv region and two Kh-59 at the Sumy region, both in northeastern Ukraine, it said.
Authorities say the intensity of ground attacks and airstrikes has increased recently in the Sumy region, prompting the evacuation of 56 people, including 26 children, from one border village over the past week.
In the past two and a half months the region has been struck more than 3,000 times, after some 8,000 strikes over all of last year, the Ukrainian regional government says. The number of aerial bomb attacks has tripled, and Russian saboteurs are highly active, according to officials.
This story corrects the name of the court to the International Criminal Court.
input:
A possible conflict between Russia and NATO would put the world “a step away” from World War III, he said.
French President Emmanuel Macron recently said that sending Western troops into Ukraine should not be ruled out, though he said the current situation does not require it.
Commenting on the prospects for peace talks with Kyiv, Putin reaffirmed that Russia remains open to negotiations but won’t be lured into a truce that will allow Ukraine to rearm.
However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has apparently shut the door on such talks, saying Putin should be brought to trial at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, which last year issued an arrest warrant for Putin on war crime charges.
With crucial U.S. aid being held up in Washington, U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham visited Kyiv on Monday. Ukraine desperately needs the around $48 billion that the package of support would provide, especially artillery shells and air defense systems.
Graham said he discussed the issue with Zelenskyy and suggested that aid in the form of a no-interest loan might get more more support from U.S. voters. He also denounced the result of Russia’s presidential election as “not legitimate” and said he wanted to introduce legislation in the U.S. that would deem Russia a state sponsor of terrorism.
Ukraine’s air force said it intercepted 17 out of 22 Shahed drones launched by Russia over various regions of the country overnight. Russia also fired five S-300/S-400 missiles at the Kharkiv region and two Kh-59 at the Sumy region, both in northeastern Ukraine, it said.
Authorities say the intensity of ground attacks and airstrikes has increased recently in the Sumy region, prompting the evacuation of 56 people, including 26 children, from one border village over the past week.
In the past two and a half months the region has been struck more than 3,000 times, after some 8,000 strikes over all of last year, the Ukrainian regional government says. The number of aerial bomb attacks has tripled, and Russian saboteurs are highly active, according to officials.
This story corrects the name of the court to the International Criminal Court.

title: 多名俄官员支持普京竞选连任，俄总统大选投票将首次持续三天
content:
据新华社援引塔斯社、今日俄罗斯通讯社等媒体12月8日报道，俄罗斯总统普京当天表示将参加2024年举行的总统选举。俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃8日宣布，2024年俄总统选举投票将进行三天，从3月15日持续至17日。
这将是俄罗斯首次举行为期三天的总统大选投票。此前，多日投票方式曾被应用于新冠疫情期间，以防投票站出现选民过度拥挤的情况。据悉，该方式的首次应用是在2020年6月25日至 7月1日的俄罗斯修宪全民公投期间。
此外，本次总统大选投票还将采用实地投票和远程电子投票相结合的方式进行，选民可在2024年1月29日至3月11日期间申请进行远程电子投票，正式投票时间为3月15日8时至3月17日20时。目前俄中央选举委员会尚未公布可以使用远程电子投票方式的地区。对于是否在顿涅茨克、卢甘斯克、扎波罗热和赫尔松四个“新地区”举行投票，俄中央选举委员会预计将于12月12日做出决定。
12月8日，普京在克里姆林宫出席“祖国英雄日”庆祝仪式。仪式结束后，“顿涅茨克人民共和国”人民委员会主席阿尔乔姆·佐加在与普京进行交谈时表示，整个顿巴斯地区都希望普京参与大选。
他对普京说：“您是我们的总统，我们是您的团队。我们需要您，俄罗斯需要您。”对此，普京回应称：“我在不同的时期有不同的想法，但现在到了必须做出决定的时刻。我将竞选俄罗斯总统。”
在普京宣布参与2024年大选后，多名俄罗斯官员表示支持。
俄罗斯联邦委员会（议会上院）主席马特维延科表示，普京的这一决定是俄罗斯作为强大、安全的主权国家的保障。
俄罗斯国家杜马（议会下院）主席沃洛金表示，普京参加选举的决定对于俄罗斯和世界而言都非常重要。普京的这一决定表明了他对俄罗斯的热爱和要使俄罗斯强大、繁荣的愿望，也表明了他要在当前充满挑战和威胁的困难时期保护俄罗斯的愿望。
俄罗斯联邦安全会议副主席梅德韦杰夫表示，考虑到当前的形势，普京的这一决定是绝对合理且正确的，普京应继续担任总统一职。
如果现年71岁的普京能够在2024年3月的大选中获胜、顺利连任，将是他第五次担任俄罗斯总统。普京作为俄罗斯总统的现任任期将于2024年5月7日结束。根据俄罗斯宪法，普京可以在此次任期结束后寻求连任两届至2036年。
目前，在俄议会的五个政党中，统一俄罗斯党、“公正俄罗斯-爱国者-为了真理”党已明确表态将支持普京竞选总统。俄罗斯联邦共产党中央委员会主席久加诺夫此前曾表示自己将参加大选，但最终决定将由该党中央委员会做出。俄罗斯自由民主党、“新人”党预计也将推举出各自政党的总统候选人。
在议会之外，“亚博卢”党领导人亚夫林斯基称，如自己能够收集10万个支持者签名从而获得参选资格，就将竞选总统。而包括呼吁结束“特别军事行动”的俄罗斯前地方电视台记者叶卡捷琳娜·敦佐娃在内的独立候选人则需召集至少500人的倡议小组，并获得超过30万个支持者签名，方能获得参选资格。
translation:
According to reports from Xinhua News Agency on December 8, citing TASS, Russia Today and other media, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that day that he would participate in the presidential election in 2024. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced on the 8th that voting in the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held for three days, lasting from March 15th to 17th.
This will be Russia's first three-day presidential election vote. The multi-day voting method has previously been used during the coronavirus pandemic to prevent overcrowding of voters at polling stations. It is reported that the first application of this method was during the Russian constitutional referendum from June 25 to July 1, 2020.
In addition, voting in this presidential election will also be conducted using a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting. Voters can apply for remote electronic voting from January 29 to March 11, 2024. The official voting time is March 15 From 8:00 on Sunday to 20:00 on March 17. At present, the Russian Central Election Commission has not announced the regions where remote electronic voting can be used. Russia's Central Election Commission is expected to make a decision on December 12 on whether to hold voting in the four "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhye and Kherson.
On December 8, Putin attended the "Heroes of the Motherland Day" celebration ceremony at the Kremlin. After the ceremony, Artyom Zoga, Chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic", said in a conversation with Putin that the entire Donbas region hopes that Putin will participate in the election.
He said to Putin: "You are our president, we are your team. We need you, Russia needs you." In response, Putin responded: "I had different ideas at different times, but now the time has come to do what must be done It’s time to make a decision. I will run for president of Russia.”
After Putin announced his participation in the 2024 election, many Russian officials expressed support.
Matviyenko, chairman of the Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament), said that Putin’s decision is a guarantee for Russia as a strong, secure and sovereign country.
Volodin, chairman of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that Putin's decision to participate in the election is very important for Russia and the world. Putin's decision demonstrates his love for Russia and his desire to make Russia strong and prosperous. It also demonstrates his desire to protect Russia in the current difficult period full of challenges and threats.
Medvedev, deputy chairman of the Security Council of the Russian Federation, said that considering the current situation, Putin's decision is absolutely reasonable and correct, and Putin should continue to serve as president.
If the 71-year-old Putin can win the general election in March 2024 and be successfully re-elected, it will be his fifth term as President of Russia. Putin's current term as President of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.
Currently, among the five political parties in the Russian parliament, the United Russia Party and the "Just Russia-Patriots-For Truth" party have made it clear that they will support Putin's presidential bid. Zyuganov, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, has previously stated that he will participate in the election, but the final decision will be made by the Central Committee of the Party. The Russian Liberal Democratic Party and the Newcomer Party are also expected to nominate presidential candidates from their respective parties.
Outside parliament, Yabolu party leader Yavlinsky said that if he could collect 100,000 signatures from supporters to qualify for the election, he would run for president. Independent candidates, including former Russian local TV reporter Yekaterina Duntsova who called for an end to "special military operations," need to convene an initiative group of at least 500 people and obtain more than 300,000 signatures from supporters. Only in order to be eligible to participate in the election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
content:
据央视新闻报道，俄罗斯总统选举正式投票将于3月15日至17日进行，包括现任总统普京在内的4名候选人参选。
根据俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布的消息，此次大选最终确认的四名候选人包括：普京，斯卢茨基（俄自由民主党），哈里托诺夫（俄联邦共产党）以及达万科夫（俄新人党）。
2024年俄罗斯大选是该国2020年通过宪法修正案后的首次总统大选，也是俄罗斯首次战时选举。此次大选有何关键节点，较以往大选相比又有何值得关注的特殊之处？
谁有资格参选？
2020年1月，俄罗斯总统普京发起修宪进程。《俄罗斯联邦宪法》修正案草案3月在俄国家杜马和俄罗斯联邦委员会获得通过，随后于当年7月经全民公投后生效。
根据该宪法修正案，俄罗斯联邦总统在无记名投票的普遍平等和直接普选的基础上由俄罗斯联邦公民选出，任期6年。年满35周岁、在俄罗斯联邦居住至少25年且没有外国国籍或居留许可的俄罗斯联邦公民方有资格竞选俄罗斯联邦总统。
此外，同一人不得担任俄罗斯联邦总统连续两个任期以上。该条文并没有发生变化，只是这一限制不包括修正案生效之时曾担任俄罗斯联邦总统和（或）正担任俄罗斯联邦总统的任期数量。现任总统普京仍然能够参加2024年总统大选。
translation:
According to CCTV News, official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.
According to information released by the Russian Central Election Commission, the four final candidates confirmed in this election include: Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian newcomer party).
The 2024 Russian election will be the country’s first presidential election after the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 2020, and it will also be Russia’s first wartime election. What are the key points of this election, and what are the special features worthy of attention compared with previous elections?
Who is eligible to run?
In January 2020, Russian President Vladimir Putin initiated the constitutional amendment process. The draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation was approved by the Russian State Duma and the Russian Federation Council in March, and then came into effect after a referendum in July of that year.
According to this constitutional amendment, the President of the Russian Federation is elected by the citizens of the Russian Federation on the basis of universal equality and direct suffrage by secret ballot for a term of 6 years. Citizens of the Russian Federation who are over 35 years old, have lived in the Russian Federation for at least 25 years, and do not have foreign citizenship or residence permit are eligible to run for President of the Russian Federation.
Furthermore, the same person may not serve as President of the Russian Federation for more than two consecutive terms. This provision has not changed, except that this limit does not include the number of terms in office that were and/or are currently serving as President of the Russian Federation at the time when the amendment comes into force. Current President Putin can still participate in the 2024 presidential election.
input:
According to CCTV News, official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.
According to information released by the Russian Central Election Commission, the four final candidates confirmed in this election include: Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian newcomer party).
The 2024 Russian election will be the country’s first presidential election after the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 2020, and it will also be Russia’s first wartime election. What are the key points of this election, and what are the special features worthy of attention compared with previous elections?
Who is eligible to run?
In January 2020, Russian President Vladimir Putin initiated the constitutional amendment process. The draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation was approved by the Russian State Duma and the Russian Federation Council in March, and then came into effect after a referendum in July of that year.
According to this constitutional amendment, the President of the Russian Federation is elected by the citizens of the Russian Federation on the basis of universal equality and direct suffrage by secret ballot for a term of 6 years. Citizens of the Russian Federation who are over 35 years old, have lived in the Russian Federation for at least 25 years, and do not have foreign citizenship or residence permit are eligible to run for President of the Russian Federation.
Furthermore, the same person may not serve as President of the Russian Federation for more than two consecutive terms. This provision has not changed, except that this limit does not include the number of terms in office that were and/or are currently serving as President of the Russian Federation at the time when the amendment comes into force. Current President Putin can still participate in the 2024 presidential election.

title: 俄罗斯大选：普京宣布压倒性胜利，赞俄罗斯民主优于很多西方国家 - BBC News 中文
content:
一如外界预期，普京在大选中压倒性赢得第五个总统任期，而其他三名候选人则充当了陪跑者。
当选举官员宣布普京获得超过87%选票时，普京指俄罗斯的民主比西方许多国家更加透明。事实却是，没有任何可信的反对派人士获准参选。
异议领袖纳瓦尔尼（Alexei Navalny）上月猝逝后，其支持者发起名为“中午反普京”（Noon Against Putin）的象征性抗议，号召俄罗斯公民于中午时分在莫斯科、圣彼得堡等城市的街道以及俄罗斯驻外使领馆前聚集。然而，这并没有撼动选举结果。
监督组织OVD-Info称至少80名俄罗斯抗议者因破坏选举秩序被捕。 周五曾有人把绿色染料倒进投票箱，以及在投票站内燃放烟火。
西方国家纷纷谴责这次选举既不自由也不公正。
德国称这是在依赖审查、镇压和暴力的专制统治下举行的“伪选举”。英国外相卡梅伦谴责“在乌克兰领土上非法举行选举”。
乌克兰总统泽连斯基指“俄罗斯独裁者正在模拟另一种选举”。
用纳瓦尔尼盟友沃尔科夫（Leonid Volkov）的话来说：“当然，普京的选票与现实没有丝毫关系。”沃尔科夫上周在立陶宛流亡期间被人用肉锤野蛮殴打。
这次大选中俄罗斯人有三天时间投票，而在俄罗斯占领的乌克兰地区，居民甚至有更长的投票时间，这是为了鼓励居民参与投票。
据报道，一名选举委员会官员周日在被占领的别尔江斯克（Berdyansk）被杀，有居民说亲俄人士在武装士兵的陪同下，带着投票箱走访各家各户。
在俄罗斯政府精心控制的国家电视台上，选举结果被誉为胜利，官方指投票率高达74%。
一名记者兴奋地说：“对普京的支持和团结达到了令人难以置信的程度，这也是向西方国家发出的信号。”
普京总统在接受记者提问时显得比较低调，但他确实称赞俄罗斯的总统竞选比美国先进得多，提到俄罗斯使用在线投票，官方称这吸引了800万选民。
普京稍早也被拍到在线投票，他说：“这是透明且绝对客观的，不像美国的邮寄投票……你可以花10美元买一张选票。”
71岁的普京从2000年开始统治俄罗斯，是自苏联独裁者斯大林以来在任时间最长的克里姆林宫领导人，预计他将继续执政至少到2030年。
独立选举监督机构Golos未获准观察投票，但有报道指选举期间有违规行为，公共部门雇员也被施压要在投票站或网上投票。
普京总统赞扬反对派活动人士鼓励更多选民参加投票，但他谴责那些破坏选票的人，表示将对他们采取行动。
translation:
As expected, Putin overwhelmingly won a fifth presidential term in the election, with the other three candidates acting as runners.
When election officials announced that Putin had won more than 87% of the vote, Putin pointed out that Russia's democracy is more transparent than many Western countries. The fact is that no credible opposition figure has been allowed to run.
After the sudden death of dissident leader Alexei Navalny last month, his supporters launched a symbolic protest called "Noon Against Putin", calling on Russian citizens to take to the streets of Moscow, St. Petersburg and other cities at noon. and gathered in front of Russian embassies and consulates abroad. However, this did not sway the election results.
Monitoring group OVD-Info said at least 80 Russian protesters were arrested for disrupting election order. Green dye was poured into ballot boxes and fireworks were set off inside polling stations on Friday.
Western countries have condemned the election as neither free nor fair.
Germany called it a "pseudo election" held under an authoritarian rule that relies on censorship, repression and violence. British Foreign Secretary David Cameron condemned "the illegal holding of elections on Ukrainian soil."
Ukrainian President Zelensky said that "the Russian dictator is simulating another kind of election."
In the words of Navalny ally Leonid Volkov, who was savagely beaten with a meat hammer while living in exile in Lithuania last week: "Of course, Putin's vote has nothing to do with reality."
Russians have three days to vote in this election, and in Russian-occupied Ukraine, residents have even longer to vote. This is to encourage residents to participate in voting.
An election commission official was reportedly killed in occupied Berdyansk on Sunday, and residents said pro-Russian figures, accompanied by armed soldiers, were visiting homes with ballot boxes.
On state television, which is carefully controlled by the Russian government, the election results were hailed as a victory, with official turnout reported as high as 74%.
One reporter said excitedly: "The support and solidarity for Putin has reached an incredible level, which is also a signal to Western countries."
President Putin kept a low profile when taking questions from reporters, but he did praise Russia's presidential campaign as being much more advanced than the United States, citing Russia's use of online voting, which officials said attracted 8 million voters.
Putin was also photographed voting online earlier. He said: "This is transparent and absolutely objective, unlike mail-in voting in the United States... you can buy a vote for $10."
Putin, 71, has ruled Russia since 2000 and is the longest-serving Kremlin leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, and is expected to remain in power until at least 2030.
Independent election watchdog Golos was not allowed to observe the vote, but there were reports of irregularities during the election and public sector employees being pressured to vote at polling stations or online.
President Putin praised opposition activists for encouraging more voters to go to the polls, but he condemned those who sabotaged ballots and said action would be taken against them.
input:
