Putin, 71, has ruled Russia since 2000 and is the longest-serving Kremlin leader since Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin, and is expected to remain in power until at least 2030.
Independent election watchdog Golos was not allowed to observe the vote, but there were reports of irregularities during the election and public sector employees being pressured to vote at polling stations or online.
President Putin praised opposition activists for encouraging more voters to go to the polls, but he condemned those who sabotaged ballots and said action would be taken against them.

title: 普京：总统选举日期确定时再宣布是否参选
content: 9月12日，第八届东方经济论坛全会开幕。俄罗斯总统普京在讲话中表示，等到年底俄罗斯国家杜马（议会下院）确定总统选举日期时，他再宣布是否决定参加总统大选。
translation: On September 12, the plenary session of the 8th Eastern Economic Forum opened. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in his speech that he will not announce his decision to participate in the presidential election until the end of the year when the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) determines the date for the presidential election.
input: On September 12, the plenary session of the 8th Eastern Economic Forum opened. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in his speech that he will not announce his decision to participate in the presidential election until the end of the year when the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) determines the date for the presidential election.

title: In Russian presidential election, voting is forced at gunpoint in occupied Ukraine - The Washington Post
content:
The election, even for legitimate voters in Russia, offers no genuine democratic choice with the Kremlin blocking genuine opposition candidates from the ballot, controlling media coverage and, critics allege, falsifying results.
Constitutional changes engineered by Putin in 2020 enable him to rule potentially until 2036, but it is generally understood that he will remain in charge as long as he wants.
In Belgorod, Russian city hit hardest by war, Putin is still running strong
The forced vote is part of a broader process of Russification in occupied regions, including forced curriculum changes in schools, the torture, imprisonment and expulsion of pro-Kyiv figures, the installation of Kremlin puppet administrations, and requiring Ukrainians to sign up for Russian passports to function in daily life.
In Mariupol, the occupied city on the Azov Sea, on Saturday, voting took place two years after Russia’s March 16, 2022, bombing of the city’s drama theater, which killed hundreds of people sheltered there, despite a huge sign on the ground indicating that civilians, including children, were inside.
Russian state media, however, showed happy residents at a Mariupol polling station, which featured an exhibition of children’s drawings bearing slogans like “I’m a future voter” — part of Russia’s continued use of children for state propaganda and indoctrination, which has been a central feature of the war in occupied areas and in Russia.
One Mariupol resident interviewed by The Washington Post by phone said, “People couldn’t care less about the elections because everyone understands perfectly well that it’s elections without choice.” The person spoke on the condition of anonymity  because of the risk of retribution by Russian authorities.
“There's no rule of law, no courts, nothing.
input:
The election, even for legitimate voters in Russia, offers no genuine democratic choice with the Kremlin blocking genuine opposition candidates from the ballot, controlling media coverage and, critics allege, falsifying results.
Constitutional changes engineered by Putin in 2020 enable him to rule potentially until 2036, but it is generally understood that he will remain in charge as long as he wants.
In Belgorod, Russian city hit hardest by war, Putin is still running strong
The forced vote is part of a broader process of Russification in occupied regions, including forced curriculum changes in schools, the torture, imprisonment and expulsion of pro-Kyiv figures, the installation of Kremlin puppet administrations, and requiring Ukrainians to sign up for Russian passports to function in daily life.
In Mariupol, the occupied city on the Azov Sea, on Saturday, voting took place two years after Russia’s March 16, 2022, bombing of the city’s drama theater, which killed hundreds of people sheltered there, despite a huge sign on the ground indicating that civilians, including children, were inside.
Russian state media, however, showed happy residents at a Mariupol polling station, which featured an exhibition of children’s drawings bearing slogans like “I’m a future voter” — part of Russia’s continued use of children for state propaganda and indoctrination, which has been a central feature of the war in occupied areas and in Russia.
One Mariupol resident interviewed by The Washington Post by phone said, “People couldn’t care less about the elections because everyone understands perfectly well that it’s elections without choice.” The person spoke on the condition of anonymity  because of the risk of retribution by Russian authorities.
“There's no rule of law, no courts, nothing.

title: 俄罗斯中央选举委员会正式宣布普京赢得总统选举
content:
当地时间3月21日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会召开会议，总结2024年总统选举结果。数据显示，87576075名选民参加了投票，投票率为77.49%。
俄罗斯中央选举委员会主席帕姆菲洛娃当天正式宣布，根据对所有选票的初步统计，俄罗斯现任总统普京获得87.28%的选票，赢得2024年总统选举。
数据显示，共有76277708名选民投票给现任总统普京。俄联邦共产党候选人哈里托诺夫、俄新人党候选人达万科夫、俄自由民主党候选人斯卢茨基分别获得4.31%、3.85%和3.20%的选票。
translation:
On March 21, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission held a meeting to summarize the results of the 2024 presidential election. Data showed that 87,576,075 voters participated in the voting, with a turnout rate of 77.49%.
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that according to preliminary statistics of all votes, current Russian President Vladimir Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won the 2024 presidential election.
Data shows that a total of 76,277,708 voters voted for current President Putin. Kharitonov, the candidate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Davankov, the candidate of the New People's Party of Russia, and Slutsky, the candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, received 4.31%, 3.85%, and 3.20% of the votes respectively.
input:
On March 21, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission held a meeting to summarize the results of the 2024 presidential election. Data showed that 87,576,075 voters participated in the voting, with a turnout rate of 77.49%.
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced that day that according to preliminary statistics of all votes, current Russian President Vladimir Putin won 87.28% of the votes and won the 2024 presidential election.
Data shows that a total of 76,277,708 voters voted for current President Putin. Kharitonov, the candidate of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, Davankov, the candidate of the New People's Party of Russia, and Slutsky, the candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, received 4.31%, 3.85%, and 3.20% of the votes respectively.

title: 莫斯科近郊恐袭·解读｜俄国内安全漏洞暴露，后续反击首先要锁定袭击者
content:
“俄罗斯总统大选之际，美国及其西方盟友专门针对俄总统选举发动了新一轮的对俄舆论战和外交战，双方在此期间互呛不断，俄罗斯当局大概率把美方发布的这一信息视为西方试图在俄境内引发恐慌或混淆视听的信息战内容，因此采取了针锋相对的态度。"
对于袭击发生后的全球应对，张家栋分析称，从反恐的角度，俄美可能合作，因为恐怖主义本质是反人类罪。不管两国在战略上如何对立，在反人类罪的问题上，是有一致性的。
translation:
“On the occasion of the Russian presidential election, the United States and its Western allies have launched a new round of public opinion and diplomatic war against Russia specifically for the Russian presidential election. During this period, the two sides have been constantly at each other’s throats. There is a high probability that the Russian authorities will use this information released by the United States. It is regarded as information warfare content that the West is trying to cause panic or confuse in Russia, so it has adopted a tit-for-tat attitude."
Regarding the global response after the attack, Zhang Jiadong analyzed that from the perspective of counter-terrorism, Russia and the United States may cooperate, because terrorism is essentially a crime against humanity. No matter how strategically opposed the two countries are, they are consistent on the issue of crimes against humanity.
input:
“On the occasion of the Russian presidential election, the United States and its Western allies have launched a new round of public opinion and diplomatic war against Russia specifically for the Russian presidential election. During this period, the two sides have been constantly at each other’s throats. There is a high probability that the Russian authorities will use this information released by the United States. It is regarded as information warfare content that the West is trying to cause panic or confuse in Russia, so it has adopted a tit-for-tat attitude."
Regarding the global response after the attack, Zhang Jiadong analyzed that from the perspective of counter-terrorism, Russia and the United States may cooperate, because terrorism is essentially a crime against humanity. No matter how strategically opposed the two countries are, they are consistent on the issue of crimes against humanity.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
“问题是随着时间的推移，这种趋势将持续到什么程度。”他说。
独立分析师、曾就职于俄罗斯央行的亚历山德拉·普罗科彭科此前也在一篇撰文中写道，与战事有关的钱款大大减少了贫穷人数。生活在贫困线以下的俄罗斯人比例自1992年以来首次下降到9.8%（注，根据俄罗斯统计局3月公布的最新数据，俄罗斯的贫困水平下降了0.5%。全年从9.8%下降至9.3%。80万人不再是“正式贫困人口”）。
“2024年，这一势头很可能会持续下去——政府将不得不向死伤者家属支付2-3万亿卢布。” 亚历山德拉·普罗科彭科写道，由于劳动力短缺，企业不得不向剩下的人支付高薪，或者从其他部门吸引他们过来。新西伯利亚、萨马拉、斯维尔德洛夫斯克、下诺夫哥罗德和图拉等国防工业企业集中的地区的工资增长速度高于全国平均水平。
彭博社今年1月从当地招聘服务机构Superjob获得的数据也显示，在俄罗斯，工程师、机械师、机器操作员、焊工、司机和快递员等专业人员现在可以找到薪水与军队职位相当或更高的工作，因为去年这类工作的报酬上涨了8-20%。
但长期跟踪俄罗斯经济的知名经济学家阿斯隆德（Anders Aslund）在自由派媒体《莫斯科时报》网站刊文警告说，从经济结构和主要指标来看，俄罗斯经济似乎越来越像苏联。“失业率已低于3%，但平均工资按美元计算已从2013年的每月1200美元骤降至目前的每月略低于600美元。”
2023年春天，俄罗斯多个地区，尤其是新西伯利亚地区和阿尔泰边疆区，发生了一系列针对公用事业成本增加和地方政府无力改善公用事业网络的抗议活动。这些抗议活动中的愤怒通常不是针对联邦政府，但州长和地区政府机构面临的风险较高，因为大多数地区的预算越来越有限，而优先事项却越来越多。
列瓦达中心的丹尼斯·沃尔科夫认为，经济条件较差的人群对局势的适应能力稍强一些——他们的要求更加温和，对政府的支持措施反应更加积极。相比之下，西方国家的经济制裁主要打击的是俄罗斯大城市中较富裕和较西方化的地区。
translation:
"The question is to what extent this trend will continue over time," he said.
Independent analyst Alexandra Prokopenko, who once worked for the Russian Central Bank, also previously wrote in an article that war-related money has greatly reduced the number of poor people. The proportion of Russians living below the poverty line fell to 9.8% for the first time since 1992 (note, according to the latest data released by Rosstat in March, Russia's poverty level fell by 0.5%. It fell from 9.8% to 9.3% for the whole year . 800,000 people are no longer "officially poor").
"In 2024, this momentum is likely to continue - the government will have to pay 2-3 trillion rubles to the families of the dead and injured." Alexandra Prokopenko writes that due to labor shortages, companies must not Don’t pay the remaining people well or attract them from other departments. Wage growth is higher than the national average in regions such as Novosibirsk, Samara, Sverdlovsk, Nizhny Novgorod and Tula, where defense industry enterprises are concentrated.
Data obtained by Bloomberg from local recruitment service Superjob in January also showed that in Russia, professionals such as engineers, mechanics, machine operators, welders, drivers and couriers can now find jobs with salaries comparable to or higher than military positions. , because wages for such jobs have increased by 8-20% in the past year.
However, Anders Aslund, a well-known economist who has long tracked the Russian economy, published an article on the website of the liberal media "Moscow Times" warning that in terms of economic structure and major indicators, the Russian economy seems to be increasingly like the Soviet Union. "The unemployment rate is below 3%, but average wages in dollar terms have plummeted from $1,200 per month in 2013 to just under $600 per month currently."
In the spring of 2023, a series of protests took place in several regions of Russia, especially the Novosibirsk region and Altai Krai, against the increase in utility costs and the inability of local governments to improve utility networks. The anger in these protests is generally not directed at the federal government, but governors and regional government agencies face higher risks as most regions have increasingly limited budgets and growing priorities.
Denis Volkov of the Levada Center believes that economically disadvantaged groups are slightly more resilient to the situation - their demands are more modest and they respond more positively to government support measures. In contrast, economic sanctions from Western countries have mainly hit the wealthier and more Westernized areas of Russia's major cities.
input:
"The question is to what extent this trend will continue over time," he said.
Independent analyst Alexandra Prokopenko, who once worked for the Russian Central Bank, also previously wrote in an article that war-related money has greatly reduced the number of poor people. The proportion of Russians living below the poverty line fell to 9.8% for the first time since 1992 (note, according to the latest data released by Rosstat in March, Russia's poverty level fell by 0.5%. It fell from 9.8% to 9.3% for the whole year . 800,000 people are no longer "officially poor").
"In 2024, this momentum is likely to continue - the government will have to pay 2-3 trillion rubles to the families of the dead and injured." Alexandra Prokopenko writes that due to labor shortages, companies must not Don’t pay the remaining people well or attract them from other departments. Wage growth is higher than the national average in regions such as Novosibirsk, Samara, Sverdlovsk, Nizhny Novgorod and Tula, where defense industry enterprises are concentrated.
Data obtained by Bloomberg from local recruitment service Superjob in January also showed that in Russia, professionals such as engineers, mechanics, machine operators, welders, drivers and couriers can now find jobs with salaries comparable to or higher than military positions. , because wages for such jobs have increased by 8-20% in the past year.
However, Anders Aslund, a well-known economist who has long tracked the Russian economy, published an article on the website of the liberal media "Moscow Times" warning that in terms of economic structure and major indicators, the Russian economy seems to be increasingly like the Soviet Union. "The unemployment rate is below 3%, but average wages in dollar terms have plummeted from $1,200 per month in 2013 to just under $600 per month currently."
In the spring of 2023, a series of protests took place in several regions of Russia, especially the Novosibirsk region and Altai Krai, against the increase in utility costs and the inability of local governments to improve utility networks. The anger in these protests is generally not directed at the federal government, but governors and regional government agencies face higher risks as most regions have increasingly limited budgets and growing priorities.
Denis Volkov of the Levada Center believes that economically disadvantaged groups are slightly more resilient to the situation - their demands are more modest and they respond more positively to government support measures. In contrast, economic sanctions from Western countries have mainly hit the wealthier and more Westernized areas of Russia's major cities.

title: Russia District Calls Recount After Putin Rival Gets More Votes: Reports
content:
An election recount is underway in one Russian district after President Vladimir Putin failed to win the vote there, according to local reports.
In fact, one of Putin's political rivals in the recent presidential election was recorded as gaining 10 times as many votes, reports said.
The polling station, in the city of Barnaul, in the southern republic of Altai, counted 763 votes for Communist Party candidate Nikolai Kharitonov, compared with just 73 for Putin, independent Russian news outlet Meduza reported, citing local sources.
The polling station is now undertaking a recount, after its results received considerable media attention, Meduza reported.
Officials say a data entry error led to inflated results for Kharitonov, the outlet reported.
Business Insider was unable to verify the reports independently, and the news feed of the city's official website makes no mention of the reported errors and recount, instead quoting multiple local officials who effusively praised the elections.
Russia's presidential election, which was held over the weekend, declared Putin the winner in a sweeping victory generally regarded as a sham and foregone conclusion.
Kharitonov, a longtime member of parliament, was one of three candidates who were allowed to compete in the election by Russia's Central Elections Commission.
Like fellow challengers ultranationalist Leonid Slutsky and the comparatively liberal Vladislav Davankov, Kharitonov does not oppose Putin's war in Ukraine — a position that has seen him placed under sanction in both the UK and the US.
Anti-war candidates Yekaterina Duntsova and Boris Nadezhdin were barred from running in the election.
Kharitonov also took part in Russia's 2004 presidential election, gaining 13.7% of the vote. This time around, he gained 4.37% of the overall vote.
Asked by the BBC ahead of the elections why he would be a better candidate than Putin, Kharitonov said: "It's not for me to say," adding: "That wouldn't be right."
He went on to lavish praise on the incumbent, telling the BBC: "He's trying to consolidate the nation for victory in all areas. And this will happen!"
The reported vote recount wasn't the only reason Barnaul made the news. On March 17, one resident at another polling station in Barnaul tried to tear up the voting roll, regional outlet Bankfax reported.
input:
An election recount is underway in one Russian district after President Vladimir Putin failed to win the vote there, according to local reports.
In fact, one of Putin's political rivals in the recent presidential election was recorded as gaining 10 times as many votes, reports said.
The polling station, in the city of Barnaul, in the southern republic of Altai, counted 763 votes for Communist Party candidate Nikolai Kharitonov, compared with just 73 for Putin, independent Russian news outlet Meduza reported, citing local sources.
The polling station is now undertaking a recount, after its results received considerable media attention, Meduza reported.
Officials say a data entry error led to inflated results for Kharitonov, the outlet reported.
Business Insider was unable to verify the reports independently, and the news feed of the city's official website makes no mention of the reported errors and recount, instead quoting multiple local officials who effusively praised the elections.
Russia's presidential election, which was held over the weekend, declared Putin the winner in a sweeping victory generally regarded as a sham and foregone conclusion.
Kharitonov, a longtime member of parliament, was one of three candidates who were allowed to compete in the election by Russia's Central Elections Commission.
Like fellow challengers ultranationalist Leonid Slutsky and the comparatively liberal Vladislav Davankov, Kharitonov does not oppose Putin's war in Ukraine — a position that has seen him placed under sanction in both the UK and the US.
Anti-war candidates Yekaterina Duntsova and Boris Nadezhdin were barred from running in the election.
Kharitonov also took part in Russia's 2004 presidential election, gaining 13.7% of the vote. This time around, he gained 4.37% of the overall vote.
Asked by the BBC ahead of the elections why he would be a better candidate than Putin, Kharitonov said: "It's not for me to say," adding: "That wouldn't be right."
He went on to lavish praise on the incumbent, telling the BBC: "He's trying to consolidate the nation for victory in all areas. And this will happen!"
The reported vote recount wasn't the only reason Barnaul made the news. On March 17, one resident at another polling station in Barnaul tried to tear up the voting roll, regional outlet Bankfax reported.

title: Реакция мировых СМИ на победу Владимира Путина
content:
Владимир Путин победил на президентских выборах. Зарубежная пресса написала об этом событии, отметив высокую явку избирателей и колоссальный уровень поддержки действующего главы государства.

Издание Al Jazeera обратило внимание на крайне высокую явку во время трехдневного голосования и на уверенность российского лидера в его собственных силах:
Президент России Владимир Путин укрепил свою власть, одержав убедительную победу на выборах.
На пресс-конференции, состоявшейся после голосования, Путин назвал его результаты подтверждением своего решения бросить вызов Западу.
translation:
Vladimir Putin won the presidential election. The foreign press wrote about this event, noting the high voter turnout and the enormous level of support for the current head of state.

Al Jazeera drew attention to the extremely high turnout during the three-day vote and the Russian leader’s confidence in his own abilities:
Russian President Vladimir Putin consolidated his power with a landslide election victory.
At a press conference after the vote, Putin called the results a confirmation of his decision to challenge the West.
input:
Vladimir Putin won the presidential election. The foreign press wrote about this event, noting the high voter turnout and the enormous level of support for the current head of state.

Al Jazeera drew attention to the extremely high turnout during the three-day vote and the Russian leader’s confidence in his own abilities:
Russian President Vladimir Putin consolidated his power with a landslide election victory.
At a press conference after the vote, Putin called the results a confirmation of his decision to challenge the West.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
content:
大选在即，形势严峻，但人们会投票给普京，因为他，我们还活着。简而言之，乌克兰想炸死我们，但多亏了普京，他们带来了军队，他们帮助击落了炸弹。因为媒体，每个人都对情况的看法不同，这是可以理解的，但我们看到了发生了什么。
直到2014年，我都是乌克兰人，但我长期以来一直认为自己是俄罗斯人，我们在家也一直说俄语。2014年期间我们住在基辅，这很困难，我们没有得到住房、金钱和帮助，但我很高兴一切都结束了。
西方媒体总是说，我们“被迫”成为俄罗斯的一部分，并且我们讨厌普京。这是一个谎言，我们喜欢他，他让卢甘斯克的人们过上了更好的生活。但现在情况不是特别平静，人们一半的工资被拿走来帮助军队，物价也在上涨。人们会抱怨，但我们能怎么办？
“希望优秀的（俄罗斯）品牌尽快走向国际”
translation:
The election is coming, the situation is grim, but people will vote for Putin, because of him we are still alive. In short, Ukraine wanted to bomb us, but thanks to Putin, they brought their troops and they helped bring down the bombs. Everyone sees the situation differently because of the media, which is understandable, but we saw what happened.
Until 2014, I was Ukrainian, but I have long considered myself Russian and we always spoke Russian at home. During 2014 we lived in Kiev and it was difficult, we didn't get housing, money and help, but I'm glad it's over.
The Western media always says that we are "forced" to be part of Russia and that we hate Putin. This is a lie, we like him and he makes people in Lugansk live a better life. But things are not particularly peaceful now. Half of people's wages are being taken away to help the army, and prices are rising. People will complain, but what can we do?
“I hope that excellent (Russian) brands will go global as soon as possible”
input:
The election is coming, the situation is grim, but people will vote for Putin, because of him we are still alive. In short, Ukraine wanted to bomb us, but thanks to Putin, they brought their troops and they helped bring down the bombs. Everyone sees the situation differently because of the media, which is understandable, but we saw what happened.
Until 2014, I was Ukrainian, but I have long considered myself Russian and we always spoke Russian at home. During 2014 we lived in Kiev and it was difficult, we didn't get housing, money and help, but I'm glad it's over.
The Western media always says that we are "forced" to be part of Russia and that we hate Putin. This is a lie, we like him and he makes people in Lugansk live a better life. But things are not particularly peaceful now. Half of people's wages are being taken away to help the army, and prices are rising. People will complain, but what can we do?
“I hope that excellent (Russian) brands will go global as soon as possible”

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
content:
”卡丽娜此前告诉澎湃新闻。
当投票在3月15日拉开帷幕时，卡丽娜早早赶到投票站投票。与大多数俄罗斯人一样，卡丽娜明白选举的结果不会有什么意外，然而，对她而言，此次投票仍有一层特殊意义。
“顿巴斯确认了和俄罗斯在一起的未来。”卡丽娜说，“这才是最重要的。”
当地时间2024年3月15日，顿涅茨克，民众在投票站参加俄罗斯总统选举投票。

自从2022年2月24日以来，卡丽娜家中有多人参加了民兵组织。她的哥哥萨沙早已进入军营，成为顿涅茨克第一军的军官。这是一支多由本地人组成的民兵部队，其前身早在2014年基辅“广场革命”后就开始与乌政府军作战。十年战斗之中，双方可谓结下“血仇”。随着俄乌冲突全面爆发，俄军大举进入顿巴斯，第一军也逐渐正规化，被整合进俄军的指挥体系。
卡丽娜的丈夫和父亲都已穿上了军装到前线参战。年逾五十的父亲曾经是苏联军队中的一名基层军官，但已经退役近三十年，早已失去了大部分军事技能。
“我告诉爸爸，你年轻时已经履行了军事使命。但他说，我怎么能把萨沙一个人丢在战壕里。于是他背着一个打包好的背包，不问我，也不问我妈妈，一个人去了招兵点报到。”卡丽娜说。
最近一段时间以来，在其他俄军单位的配合下，顿涅茨克第一军正面参与了对马林卡、阿夫杰耶夫卡等顿涅茨克西郊卫星城镇的攻击。这些城镇被占领后，俄乌两军的交火线被推到了更西边，炮火渐渐远离顿涅茨克市区。对于卡丽娜这样自我认同为俄罗斯人的当地人而言，大选的顺利进行意味着顿涅茨克的“腹地化”，当地的日常生活变得更加安全。
translation:
"Karina previously told The Paper.
When the voting opened on March 15, Karina rushed to the polling station early to cast her vote. Like most Russians, Karina understands that the outcome of the election will come as no surprises. However, for her, the vote still has a special meaning.
"Donbas has confirmed its future with Russia," Karina said. "This is the most important thing."
On March 15, 2024 local time, people in Donetsk voted at the polling station in the Russian presidential election.

Since February 24, 2022, many people in Karina’s family have joined the militia. Her brother Sasha had already entered the military camp and became an officer of the First Army of Donetsk. This is a militia force composed mostly of locals. Its predecessor began fighting against the Ukrainian government forces as early as 2014 after the "Square Revolution" in Kiev. During the ten years of fighting, the two sides could be described as having a "blood feud." As the Russian-Ukrainian conflict broke out in an all-round way, the Russian army entered Donbass in large numbers, and the First Army was gradually formalized and integrated into the Russian army's command system.
Karina's husband and father have donned military uniforms and gone to the front lines to fight. My father, who is over 50 years old, was once a junior officer in the Soviet army, but he has been retired for nearly 30 years and has lost most of his military skills.
"I told Dad that you had fulfilled your military mission when you were young. But he said, how could I leave Sasha alone in the trenches. So he carried a packed backpack without asking me or my mother. , one person went to the recruitment point to report." Karina said.
In recent times, with the cooperation of other Russian military units, the First Donetsk Army has participated head-on in attacks on satellite towns in the western suburbs of Donetsk such as Malinka and Avdeyevka. After these towns were occupied, the line of fighting between the Russian and Ukrainian armies was pushed further west, and the artillery fire gradually moved away from the urban area of ​​Donetsk. For locals like Karina who self-identify as Russians, the smooth conduct of the election means the "hinterlandization" of Donetsk, where daily life has become safer.

title: Russian President Putin Cozies up to China After Election Victory
content:
Fresh out of a carefully engineered presidential-election victory on Monday, Russian President Vladimir Putin wasted no time getting on Beijing's good side.
"China is developing at a rapid pace, with great confidence. And, which is very important, the structure of China's economy is changing toward innovation," Putin said at his campaign headquarters on Monday, according to the state news agency TASS.
"And we are trying to do the same at home. We are facing absolutely the same tasks in Russia," Putin added.
He said Russia and China had "numerous points of convergence in economy and foreign policy."
On Monday, China's leader, Xi Jinping, congratulated Putin in turn, saying the Russian president's reelection "fully reflects the support of the Russian people."
Dollar-denominated trade between the two countries climbed 26% from $190 billion in 2022 to a record $240 billion in 2023, according to official data.
Europe was traditionally Russia's largest single market. But after being hit by sweeping Western sanctions over the war in Ukraine, Moscow has pivoted its economy toward alternative markets including China, India, and Iran to keep its economy humming.
Beijing and Moscow declared their "no limits" friendship in a joint statement on February 4, 2022, when Russian President Vladimir Putin visited China for the Beijing Winter Olympics.
Even though the two countries already appear cozy, Putin tried to score extra points with China during the press conference on Monday by affirming Beijing's claim that self-ruled Taiwan is a part of China.
At a regular press briefing that day, a spokesperson for China's foreign ministry said, "China highly commends President Putin's statement."
Taiwan's foreign-affairs ministry slammed Putin's support for China's position, saying in a statement on Monday that the Chinese Communist Party has never ruled democratic Taiwan.
The island also took a swipe at Putin's election and its invasion of Ukraine.
"Putin in Russia pretends to be a democracy but actually acts as a dictatorship," Taiwan's foreign-affairs ministry said. "The election was held without opposition or opponents, and the election was forcibly held in the occupied territories that were originally Ukrainian territory, highlighting the violent nature of the dictatorship."

title: 俄中央选举委员会：俄总统选举结果将在3月28日前宣布
content:
当地时间2024年2月25日，俄罗斯萨哈，在偏远地区Ulakhan-An村的投票站，选民在提前投票中投票。这是3月15日至17日举行的俄罗斯总统选举的一部分。俄罗斯总统选举提前投票已经启动，一些交通不便和偏远地区的选民从当天开始投票选举总统。视觉中国 图

当地时间2月28日，俄罗斯中央选举委员会副主席尼古拉∙布拉耶夫通报说，俄中央选举委员会将在3月28日前宣布俄罗斯总统选举结果。
俄罗斯总统选举正式投票将于3月15日至17日进行，包括现任总统普京在内的4名候选人参选。
translation:
On February 25, 2024 local time, in Sakha, Russia, voters cast their votes in early voting at a polling station in Ulakhan-An village in a remote area. This is part of Russia's presidential election, which takes place from March 15 to 17. Early voting for the Russian presidential election has started, and voters in some areas with inaccessible and remote areas can start voting for the president from the same day. Visual China Map

On February 28, local time, Nikolay Buraev, deputy chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission, informed that the Russian Central Election Commission will announce the results of the Russian presidential election before March 28.
The official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15th to 17th. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.
input:
On February 25, 2024 local time, in Sakha, Russia, voters cast their votes in early voting at a polling station in Ulakhan-An village in a remote area. This is part of Russia's presidential election, which takes place from March 15 to 17. Early voting for the Russian presidential election has started, and voters in some areas with inaccessible and remote areas can start voting for the president from the same day. Visual China Map

On February 28, local time, Nikolay Buraev, deputy chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission, informed that the Russian Central Election Commission will announce the results of the Russian presidential election before March 28.
The official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15th to 17th. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.

title: Как проходили выборы Президента России в 2024 году
content:
Выборы Президента России проходили с 15 по 17 марта 2024 года. В них участвовали четыре кандидата: самовыдвиженец — действующий президент Владимир Путин, от ЛДПР — Леонид Слуцкий, от КПРФ — Николай Харитонов, от «Новых людей» — Владислав Даванков.

По данным ЦИК, за Путина в общей сложности проголосовали 87,28 процента избирателей, или 76 277 708 человек. На втором месте оказался Харитонов с 4,31 процента голосов, на третьем — Даванков с 3,85 процента, на четвертом — Слуцкий с 3,2 процента.

Явка составила 77,49 процента от общего числа избирателей.

Участки были открыты для избирателей с 8.00 и до 20.00 по местному времени. Также можно было проголосовать онлайн. Это первые президентские выборы, на которых появилась такая возможность. Принять участие в онлайн-голосовании смогли около 38 миллионов избирателей из 29 регионов.

За рубежом можно было проголосовать на 295 избирательных участках, они открылись в 144 странах. Мониторинг выборов Президента России вели наблюдатели от Межпарламентской Ассамблеи (МПА) СНГ из 22 стран. В составе группы — депутаты и сенаторы стран Содружества, а также эксперты Международного института мониторинга развития демократии из Молдовы, Туркменистана, Лаоса, Египта, Вьетнама, Китая, Ирана, Камеруна, Кот д'Ивуара, Палестины, Сирии, Судана, Турции, Хорватии и Великобритании.
translation:
The Russian Presidential elections took place from March 15 to 17, 2024. Four candidates participated in them: self-nominated incumbent President Vladimir Putin, from the LDPR - Leonid Slutsky, from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation - Nikolai Kharitonov, from the New People - Vladislav Davankov.

According to the Central Election Commission, a total of 87.28 percent of voters, or 76,277,708 people, voted for Putin.In second place was Kharitonov with 4.31 percent of the votes, in third place was Davankov with 3.85 percent, and in fourth place was Slutsky with 3.2 percent.

The turnout was 77.49 percent of the total number of voters.

Polling stations were open to voters from 8:00 to 20:00 local time. It was also possible to vote online. This is the first presidential election in which such an opportunity has arisen. About 38 million voters from 29 regions were able to take part in online voting.

Abroad, it was possible to vote at 295 polling stations; they opened in 144 countries.Monitoring of the presidential elections in Russia was carried out by observers from the Interparliamentary Assembly (IPA) of the CIS from 22 countries. The group includes deputies and senators from Commonwealth countries, as well as experts from the International Institute for Monitoring Democracy Development from Moldova, Turkmenistan, Laos, Egypt, Vietnam, China, Iran, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Palestine, Syria, Sudan, Turkey, Croatia and Great Britain.
input:
The Russian Presidential elections took place from March 15 to 17, 2024. Four candidates participated in them: self-nominated incumbent President Vladimir Putin, from the LDPR - Leonid Slutsky, from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation - Nikolai Kharitonov, from the New People - Vladislav Davankov.

According to the Central Election Commission, a total of 87.28 percent of voters, or 76,277,708 people, voted for Putin.In second place was Kharitonov with 4.31 percent of the votes, in third place was Davankov with 3.85 percent, and in fourth place was Slutsky with 3.2 percent.

The turnout was 77.49 percent of the total number of voters.

Polling stations were open to voters from 8:00 to 20:00 local time. It was also possible to vote online. This is the first presidential election in which such an opportunity has arisen. About 38 million voters from 29 regions were able to take part in online voting.

Abroad, it was possible to vote at 295 polling stations; they opened in 144 countries.Monitoring of the presidential elections in Russia was carried out by observers from the Interparliamentary Assembly (IPA) of the CIS from 22 countries. The group includes deputies and senators from Commonwealth countries, as well as experts from the International Institute for Monitoring Democracy Development from Moldova, Turkmenistan, Laos, Egypt, Vietnam, China, Iran, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Palestine, Syria, Sudan, Turkey, Croatia and Great Britain.

title: Who congratulated Putin on his election victory and what does it say about global alliances? | Russia | The Guardian
content:
After Vladimir Putin’s landslide presidential election victory on Sunday, western governments lined up to characterise the win as unfair and undemocratic.
The elections underlined the “depth of repression” in Russia, according to British foreign minister David Cameron, while the US state department said the jailing and disqualification of opponents meant the process was “incredibly undemocratic”.
The comments from leaders across Europe and the US stood however in sharp contrast to messages of congratulation that flowed from countries across Asia, Africa and Latin America.
These contrasting reactions underscore the geopolitical faultlines that have been cleaved wider since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine two years ago, triggering a crisis in relations with the west.
China’s president Xi Jinping was quick to congratulate Putin on his victory, saying Beijing would continue to promote the “no limits” partnership that it forged with Moscow just before Russia invaded Ukraine.
Questions around the democratic process are entirely absent from coverage of the election in Chinese state media, in which Putin’s victory is characterised as bringing “certainty to a world in turbulence”.
In the face of increasingly strained relations with the US, China has sought to expand its influence internationally. Galvanised by the belief that the era of US hegemony is at an end, Beijing has attempted to secure its own sphere of influence that stands in contrast to the west – and Russia under Putin has proved a willing partner in this effort.
After declaring victory on Monday, Putin used a speech to supporters to again declare that “Taiwan is an inherent part of the People’s Republic of China”, in comments that were likely directed at the government in Beijing which claims Taiwan as a province of China, and which has made “reunification” a crucial policy. Putin also accused other countries of creating “provocations” around Taiwan and said they – and their sanctions on China – were “doomed to fail”.

The comments from leaders across Europe and the US stood however in sharp contrast to messages of congratulation that flowed from countries across Asia, Africa and Latin America.
These contrasting reactions underscore the geopolitical faultlines that have been cleaved wider since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine two years ago, triggering a crisis in relations with the west.
China’s president Xi Jinping was quick to congratulate Putin on his victory, saying Beijing would continue to promote the “no limits” partnership that it forged with Moscow just before Russia invaded Ukraine.
Questions around the democratic process are entirely absent from coverage of the election in Chinese state media, in which Putin’s victory is characterised as bringing “certainty to a world in turbulence”.
In the face of increasingly strained relations with the US, China has sought to expand its influence internationally. Galvanised by the belief that the era of US hegemony is at an end, Beijing has attempted to secure its own sphere of influence that stands in contrast to the west – and Russia under Putin has proved a willing partner in this effort.
After declaring victory on Monday, Putin used a speech to supporters to again declare that “Taiwan is an inherent part of the People’s Republic of China”, in comments that were likely directed at the government in Beijing which claims Taiwan as a province of China, and which has made “reunification” a crucial policy. title: 普京胜选,中方:祝贺！
content:
当地时间18日,俄罗斯中央选举委员会公布的总统选举初步计票最新数据显示,截至目前已统计99.67%的选票；在四名候选人中,现任总统普京以87.32%的得票率大幅领先,实际已经赢得此次总统选举。
3月18日,外交部发言人林剑主持例行记者会。
俄新社记者提问,俄罗斯总统选举于3月15日至17日举行,现任总统普京得票领先,中方对此有何评论？此次大选将如何影响中俄关系？
林剑表示,中方对此表示祝贺。中俄互为最大邻国和新时代全面战略协作伙伴,我们深信,在习近平主席和普京总统的战略引领下,中俄关系将持续向前发展。
translation:
On the 18th local time, the latest preliminary vote count data for the presidential election released by the Russian Central Election Commission showed that 99.67% of the votes have been counted so far; among the four candidates, current President Putin leads by a wide margin with 87.32% of the votes. In fact, he has already won 87.32% of the votes. Win this presidential election.
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference.
A reporter from the RIA Novosti News Agency asked that the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Current President Putin won the vote. What is China’s comment on this? How will this election affect Sino-Russian relations?
Lin Jian said that China congratulates this. China and Russia are each other's largest neighbors and comprehensive strategic partners of coordination in the new era. We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to develop.
input:
On the 18th local time, the latest preliminary vote count data for the presidential election released by the Russian Central Election Commission showed that 99.67% of the votes have been counted so far; among the four candidates, current President Putin leads by a wide margin with 87.32% of the votes. In fact, he has already won 87.32% of the votes. Win this presidential election.
On March 18, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Lin Jian hosted a regular press conference.
A reporter from the RIA Novosti News Agency asked that the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Current President Putin won the vote. What is China’s comment on this? How will this election affect Sino-Russian relations?
Lin Jian said that China congratulates this. China and Russia are each other's largest neighbors and comprehensive strategic partners of coordination in the new era. We are convinced that under the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin, China-Russia relations will continue to develop.

title: Итоги выборов президента: Победа Путина, второе место КПРФ, рекордная явка
content:
Важнейший показатель - явка избирателей. Она составила 77,44%. Активность избирателей стала рекордной за всю историю выборов президента России.

В 1991 году - когда состоялись единственные выборы президента РСФСР - на участки пришли 76,66% избирателей. Все последующие годы явка на выборах президента всегда была высокой (65% и выше), однако планку в 70% преодолеть не удавалось. В этом смысле нынешние выборы можно назвать историческими. На желание людей голосовать, как отмечают эксперты, повлияла консолидация общества и удобный формат самих выборов - участки работали три дня, впервые был доступ к онлайн (в 29 регионах).


Впервые на президентских выборах граждане России в 29 регионах могли голосовать онлайн
Явку выше среднероссийской показали новые регионы, жители которых избирали президента России впервые - в ДНР, ЛНР, Запорожской и Херсонской областях на участки пришли более 80% избирателей.

Порог явки в 90% преодолели Чеченская Республика, Северная Осетия-Алания, Кабардино-Балкария, Тыва, Кемеровская область, Ямало-Ненецкий автономный округ.

Явка на онлайн-голосование всегда выше, чем очная, и она тоже была рекордной, - 94% от подавших заявки. На федеральной платформе электронные галочки поставили почти 4,5 млн избирателей. Москва голосовала на отдельной платформе, в столице было выдано почти 3,7 млн электронных бюллетеней. Инфраструктура дистанционного электронного голосования в целом справилась с нагрузкой и хакерскими атаками, заявил министр цифрового развития Максут Шадаев.

Нарушения и провокации (залив урн зеленкой и другие) в ходе голосования были, однако они незначительные и не способны повлиять на итоги волеизъявления граждан. Об этом заявили уполномоченный по правам человека в РФ Татьяна Москалькова и глава Совета по правам человека при президенте РФ Валерий Фадеев. А председатель ЦИК Элла Памфилова, объявляя первые предварительные результаты выборов, сказала так: "Вместе мы сила, проголосовали за Россию".
translation:
The most important indicator is voter turnout. It was 77.44%. Voter turnout was a record high in the history of Russian presidential elections.

In 1991 - when the only presidential elections of the RSFSR took place - 76.66% of voters came to the polling stations. In all subsequent years, turnout in presidential elections was always high (65% and above), but the 70% bar could not be overcome. In this sense, the current elections can be called historic. The desire of people to vote, as experts note, was influenced by the consolidation of society and the convenient format of the elections themselves - polling stations worked for three days, for the first time there was access to online (in 29 regions).


For the first time in the presidential elections, Russian citizens in 29 regions could vote online
Turnout was higher than the Russian average in new regions, whose residents were electing the President of Russia for the first time - in the DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions, more than 80% of voters came to the polling stations.

The Chechen Republic, North Ossetia-Alania, Kabardino-Balkaria, Tyva, Kemerovo Region, and Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug passed the 90% turnout threshold.

The turnout for online voting is always higher than in-person voting, and it was also a record - 94% of those who applied. Almost 4.5 million voters checked electronic boxes on the federal platform. Moscow voted on a separate platform; almost 3.7 million electronic ballots were issued in the capital. The remote electronic voting infrastructure has generally coped with the load and hacker attacks, said Minister of Digital Development Maksut Shadayev.

There were violations and provocations (filling ballot boxes with green stuff and others) during the voting, but they were insignificant and were not capable of influencing the results of the expression of the will of citizens. This was stated by the Commissioner for Human Rights in the Russian Federation, Tatyana Moskalkova, and the head of the Human Rights Council under the President of the Russian Federation, Valery Fadeev. And the chairman of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, announcing the first preliminary results of the elections, said this: “Together we are strong, we voted for Russia.”
input:
The most important indicator is voter turnout. It was 77.44%. Voter turnout was a record high in the history of Russian presidential elections.

In 1991 - when the only presidential elections of the RSFSR took place - 76.66% of voters came to the polling stations. In all subsequent years, turnout in presidential elections was always high (65% and above), but the 70% bar could not be overcome. In this sense, the current elections can be called historic. The desire of people to vote, as experts note, was influenced by the consolidation of society and the convenient format of the elections themselves - polling stations worked for three days, for the first time there was access to online (in 29 regions).


For the first time in the presidential elections, Russian citizens in 29 regions could vote online
Turnout was higher than the Russian average in new regions, whose residents were electing the President of Russia for the first time - in the DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions, more than 80% of voters came to the polling stations.

The Chechen Republic, North Ossetia-Alania, Kabardino-Balkaria, Tyva, Kemerovo Region, and Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug passed the 90% turnout threshold.

The turnout for online voting is always higher than in-person voting, and it was also a record - 94% of those who applied. Almost 4.5 million voters checked electronic boxes on the federal platform. Moscow voted on a separate platform; almost 3.7 million electronic ballots were issued in the capital. The remote electronic voting infrastructure has generally coped with the load and hacker attacks, said Minister of Digital Development Maksut Shadayev.

There were violations and provocations (filling ballot boxes with green stuff and others) during the voting, but they were insignificant and were not capable of influencing the results of the expression of the will of citizens. This was stated by the Commissioner for Human Rights in the Russian Federation, Tatyana Moskalkova, and the head of the Human Rights Council under the President of the Russian Federation, Valery Fadeev. And the chairman of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, announcing the first preliminary results of the elections, said this: “Together we are strong, we voted for Russia.”

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
content:
对于政府官员而言，这次选举将考验他们是否有能力调集行政资源，为总统带来压倒性胜利。
俄罗斯独立新闻网站《美杜莎》（Meduza）报道，克里姆林宫希望投票率至少达到70%，其中约80%选票投给普京。这将超过他在2018年76.7%的得票率。
BBC研究发现，为了取得这样的结果，当局的目标是动员国有部门雇员，即中央和地方当局以及国有企业工作的人，大力鼓励他们投票并支持现任总统。
俄罗斯约有1.123亿合资格选民。
这个数字包括生活在乌克兰被占领土的俄罗斯公民，范围包括2014年被俄罗斯非法接管的克里米亚和顿巴斯地区部分区域，以及自2022年2月以来被占领的乌克兰东部和南部其他地区。
另有190万居住在国外的俄罗斯公民有资格投票，其中1.2万人居住在邻国哈萨克斯坦，俄罗斯在当地租用了拜科努尔航天发射基地。
普京在竞选期间出席多场活动，主要是与俄罗斯不同地区的学生和工人会面。
虽然他避而不谈“特别军事行动”，即莫斯科对入侵乌克兰的称呼，但战争在俄罗斯人的生活中无处不在：国际制裁、旅行选择受限、外国商品减少，以及与欧洲和北美的隔绝感。
战争还夺去了数万甚至数十万俄罗斯士兵的生命。
translation:
For government officials, the election will test their ability to marshal administrative resources to deliver a landslide victory for the president.
The Russian independent news website Meduza reported that the Kremlin hopes to achieve a turnout of at least 70%, with about 80% of the votes going to Putin. This would exceed his 76.7% vote share in 2018.
BBC research found that to achieve such an outcome, the authorities aimed to mobilize state sector employees, that is, those who work in central and local authorities and state-owned enterprises, to strongly encourage them to vote and support the sitting president.
There are approximately 112.3 million eligible voters in Russia.
This number includes Russian citizens living in the occupied territories of Ukraine, including parts of Crimea and the Donbas region illegally taken over by Russia in 2014, as well as other areas of eastern and southern Ukraine occupied since February 2022 .
An additional 1.9 million Russian citizens living abroad are eligible to vote, including 12,000 in neighboring Kazakhstan, where Russia leases the Baikonur space launch base.
Putin attended many events during the campaign, mainly meeting with students and workers in different regions of Russia.
While he avoided talking about "special military operations," Moscow's term for the invasion of Ukraine, the war is ubiquitous in Russian life: international sanctions, restricted travel options, reduced foreign goods, and conflicts with Europe and North America Feeling of isolation.
The war also claimed the lives of tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of Russian soldiers.
input:
For government officials, the election will test their ability to marshal administrative resources to deliver a landslide victory for the president.
The Russian independent news website Meduza reported that the Kremlin hopes to achieve a turnout of at least 70%, with about 80% of the votes going to Putin. This would exceed his 76.7% vote share in 2018.
BBC research found that to achieve such an outcome, the authorities aimed to mobilize state sector employees, that is, those who work in central and local authorities and state-owned enterprises, to strongly encourage them to vote and support the sitting president.
There are approximately 112.3 million eligible voters in Russia.
This number includes Russian citizens living in the occupied territories of Ukraine, including parts of Crimea and the Donbas region illegally taken over by Russia in 2014, as well as other areas of eastern and southern Ukraine occupied since February 2022 .
An additional 1.9 million Russian citizens living abroad are eligible to vote, including 12,000 in neighboring Kazakhstan, where Russia leases the Baikonur space launch base.
Putin attended many events during the campaign, mainly meeting with students and workers in different regions of Russia.
While he avoided talking about "special military operations," Moscow's term for the invasion of Ukraine, the war is ubiquitous in Russian life: international sanctions, restricted travel options, reduced foreign goods, and conflicts with Europe and North America Feeling of isolation.
The war also claimed the lives of tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of Russian soldiers.

title: Russia election: Putin declared winner of race that was never in doubt | AP News
content:
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
After the harshest crackdown on dissent since Soviet times, it was clear from the earliest returns that Putin’s nearly quarter-century rule would continue with a fifth term that grants him six more years. Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday. 
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair” about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia’s opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin’s greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation.
input:
President Vladimir Putin extended his reign over Russia in a landslide election whose outcome was never in doubt, declaring his determination Monday to advance deeper into Ukraine and dangling new threats against the West.
After the harshest crackdown on dissent since Soviet times, it was clear from the earliest returns that Putin’s nearly quarter-century rule would continue with a fifth term that grants him six more years. Still, Russians heeded a call to protest Putin’s repression and his war in Ukraine by showing up at polling stations at noon Sunday. 
With all the precincts counted Monday, election officials said Putin had secured a record number of votes, underlining his total control over the political system. U.S. and other Western leaders denounced the election as a sham.
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan said there was “nothing free or fair” about the election but seemingly resisted calls from Russia’s opposition to not recognize Putin as the winner.
Ahead of the election, Putin’s greatest political foe, Alexei Navalny, died in an Arctic penal colony, anti-war candidates were barred from the ballot and independent voices were silenced in a Kremlin-backed media blockade. No independent monitoring organizations were able to observe the election and analysts said online polling meant the vote was highly susceptible to manipulation.

title: 克宫:沙特王储热烈祝贺普京赢得大选
content:
俄罗斯卫星通讯社莫斯科电 据克宫新闻局消息,沙特阿拉伯王储兼首相穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼热烈祝贺俄罗斯总统普京胜选连任。
克宫新闻局发布消息说:“在通电会谈期间,沙特阿拉伯王储兼首相穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼热烈祝贺普京在俄罗斯总统选举中取得令人信服的胜利”。
俄罗斯联邦委员会宣布2024年3月17日举行总统选举。投票为期三天:3月15日、16日和17日。
据俄罗斯中央选举委员会发布的数据,在已统计的100%的俄总统选举选票中,普京以87.28%的得票率在4名总统候选人中位列第一,俄联邦共产党的哈里托诺夫以4.31%的得票率位居第二,俄新人党的达万科夫得票率为3.85%名列第三,俄自由民主党的斯卢茨基以3.2%的得票率位列第四。
translation:
Russian Satellite News Agency, Moscow: According to the Kremlin Palace News Bureau, Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Salman warmly congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his re-election.
The Kremlin's press bureau said: "During the teleconference, Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Salman warmly congratulated Putin on his convincing victory in the Russian presidential election."
The Russian Federation Council announced that the presidential election will be held on March 17, 2024. Voting lasts for three days: March 15, 16 and 17.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 100% of the Russian presidential election votes that have been counted, Putin ranked first among the four presidential candidates with a vote rate of 87.28%, followed by Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. He ranked second with a vote rate of 4.31%, Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third with a vote rate of 3.85%, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked fourth with a vote rate of 3.2%.
input:
Russian Satellite News Agency, Moscow: According to the Kremlin Palace News Bureau, Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Salman warmly congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his re-election.
The Kremlin's press bureau said: "During the teleconference, Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Salman warmly congratulated Putin on his convincing victory in the Russian presidential election."
The Russian Federation Council announced that the presidential election will be held on March 17, 2024. Voting lasts for three days: March 15, 16 and 17.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 100% of the Russian presidential election votes that have been counted, Putin ranked first among the four presidential candidates with a vote rate of 87.28%, followed by Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation. He ranked second with a vote rate of 4.31%, Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third with a vote rate of 3.85%, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked fourth with a vote rate of 3.2%.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
content:
据俄罗斯卫星通讯社（Sputnik）3月18日报道，此次俄罗斯大选，有4,300多名旅居中国的俄罗斯公民，在上海、哈尔滨等6个俄国驻外机构组织设立的投票站完成投票，引发部分中国网民于微博留言讽刺称:“在中国境内设投票站选总统，这算什么事，给我们上眼药呢?”另有网民语带钦羡地写道:“俄罗斯人在中国也能给普京投票…他们幸福了。”

俄罗斯选举期间，多个俄罗斯城市传出有选民破坏投票箱，以表达对普京独裁、无限连任的抗议。

对此，也有中国网民意有所指地在微博留言问道:“选票长啥模样”、“俄罗斯普通人还能接触到总统选举票箱，羡慕了”。还有中国网民状似吹捧习近平地调侃说:“普京应该好好学学中国的‘全过程人民民主’，就没有人敢对他吹毛求疵了。”

习近平2023年3月于《光明日报》发表文章称，中共的全过程人民民主是“最真实、最管用”的民主，超越了资本主义的党争民主，真正实现人民当家作主。

相对于普京透过普选赢得连任，习近平则是透过2023年3月的全国人大，由2,952名代表“全票通过”的修宪，来打破中国领导人两任十年的惯例，取得第三任期。

对此，在纽约的政论作家陈破空指出，中共的“全过程人民民主”是把专制包装成民主的“语言化妆术”，中国网民的各种讽刺留言显示，在相对清醒的中国民众面前，这种政治话术没有任何说服力。
translation:
According to a report by the Russian Satellite News Agency (Sputnik) on March 18, in the Russian general election, more than 4,300 Russian citizens living in China completed their voting at polling stations organized by six Russian overseas agencies, including Shanghai and Harbin. This triggered some Chinese Netizens left messages on Weibo and said sarcastically: "What kind of thing is it to set up a polling station in China to elect the president? Are you giving us eye drops?" Another netizen wrote with admiration: "Russians can also give Putin in China. Vote...they are happy."

During the Russian election, there were reports of voters destroying ballot boxes in many Russian cities to express protest against Putin's dictatorship and unlimited re-election.

In response to this, some Chinese netizens commented on Weibo and asked: "What does the ballot look like?" and "Ordinary people in Russia can still have access to the presidential election ballot box. I am envious." Some Chinese netizens seemed to be flattering Xi Jinping and joked: "Putin should learn from China's 'whole-process people's democracy', and no one would dare to find fault with him."

Xi Jinping published an article in Guangming Daily in March 2023, stating that the CCP’s whole-process people’s democracy is the “most authentic and effective” democracy, transcending capitalist party-based democracy and truly realizing that the people are the masters of the country.

While Putin won re-election through universal suffrage, Xi Jinping won a third term through constitutional amendments that were "unanimously approved" by 2,952 deputies at the National People's Congress in March 2023, breaking the practice of two ten-year terms for Chinese leaders. .

In this regard, Chen Pokong, a political commentator in New York, pointed out that the CCP’s “whole-process people’s democracy” is a “linguistic cosmetic technique” that packages autocracy as democracy. Various sarcastic messages from Chinese netizens show that in front of the relatively sober Chinese people, , this kind of political rhetoric has no persuasiveness.
input:
According to a report by the Russian Satellite News Agency (Sputnik) on March 18, in the Russian general election, more than 4,300 Russian citizens living in China completed their voting at polling stations organized by six Russian overseas agencies, including Shanghai and Harbin. This triggered some Chinese Netizens left messages on Weibo and said sarcastically: "What kind of thing is it to set up a polling station in China to elect the president? Are you giving us eye drops?" Another netizen wrote with admiration: "Russians can also give Putin in China. Vote...they are happy."

During the Russian election, there were reports of voters destroying ballot boxes in many Russian cities to express protest against Putin's dictatorship and unlimited re-election.

In response to this, some Chinese netizens commented on Weibo and asked: "What does the ballot look like?" and "Ordinary people in Russia can still have access to the presidential election ballot box. I am envious." Some Chinese netizens seemed to be flattering Xi Jinping and joked: "Putin should learn from China's 'whole-process people's democracy', and no one would dare to find fault with him."

Xi Jinping published an article in Guangming Daily in March 2023, stating that the CCP’s whole-process people’s democracy is the “most authentic and effective” democracy, transcending capitalist party-based democracy and truly realizing that the people are the masters of the country.

While Putin won re-election through universal suffrage, Xi Jinping won a third term through constitutional amendments that were "unanimously approved" by 2,952 deputies at the National People's Congress in March 2023, breaking the practice of two ten-year terms for Chinese leaders. .

In this regard, Chen Pokong, a political commentator in New York, pointed out that the CCP’s “whole-process people’s democracy” is a “linguistic cosmetic technique” that packages autocracy as democracy. Various sarcastic messages from Chinese netizens show that in front of the relatively sober Chinese people, , this kind of political rhetoric has no persuasiveness.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
content:
克里姆林宫控制的民意调查机构VTsIOM在今年2月份进行的一项调查显示，约有79%的俄罗斯人打算投票给普京。
一些普通的俄罗斯人在适应了周围的战时现实之后，冷漠而绝望地等待着投票。
来自莫斯科郊区的自由撰稿人米哈伊尔告诉半岛电视台记者，“大家似乎都已经习惯了这种局面，放弃了，有时甚至开始尝试从中获益”，“震惊已经被冷漠和抑郁所取代。”
这将是俄罗斯历史上第一次持续三天而非一天的投票。同时，有29个地区的选民首次可以通过在线方式投票。
俄罗斯约有1.12亿18岁及以上的人士拥有投票资格。
被吞并的克里米亚半岛和被占领的乌克兰部分地区的民众也将参与投票，但乌克兰及其西方盟友则谴责此举是非法的。
居住在境外的数百万俄罗斯国民——从哈萨克斯坦南部的拜科努尔太空港到美国的加利福尼亚州——也可以在当地大使馆、领事馆参与投票，或者通过邮寄方式投票。
克里姆林宫资助的民意调查机构FOM在今年3月5日发布的一项民意调查的结果显示，至少61%的俄罗斯人“肯定”会参加投票。
这项民意调查显示，另外16%的人“可能”会参与投票，只有9%的人会弃权。
初步结果预计将于3月19日公布，最终结果将于3月29日公布。
俄罗斯官方数据显示，官方预期的投票率几乎与2018年投票时一样高——当时，有近68%的俄罗斯人参与投票。
在2018年，独立选举监测员记录了数千起选举舞弊案件，包括塞选票和“轮番投票”，即数百名选民被送往多个投票站。
一些监察员面临威胁并被拒绝进入投票站。
国际选举观察员“欧洲安全与合作组织”表示，此次投票“受到过度控制”，并且“缺乏真正的竞争”。报告称，当局强迫政府雇员、军人和执法人员投票支持普京。
关注俄罗斯政治的观察人士对这次投票能够以自由和公平的方式进行几乎不抱任何希望。
普京作为独立候选人参选，因为执政的统一俄罗斯党被普遍认为腐败且效率低下。
已故反对党领袖纳瓦尔尼称之为“骗子和小偷的政党”。
其他候选人则被视为傀儡——他们的参与只是为了表明普京有多么“受欢迎”。
其中之一是来自俄罗斯共产党的尼古拉·哈利托诺夫。他参加了2004年的投票，并得到了远远落后的第二名的结果。
translation:
A February survey conducted by VTsIOM, a Kremlin-controlled polling agency, showed that about 79% of Russians planned to vote for Putin.
Some ordinary Russians, adjusting to the wartime reality around them, awaited the vote with apathy and despair.
Mikhail, a freelance journalist from the suburbs of Moscow, told Al Jazeera, “Everyone seems to have gotten used to this situation, given up, and sometimes even started to try to benefit from it.” “Shock has been replaced by apathy and depression. "
It will be the first time in Russian history that voting will last three days instead of one. At the same time, voters in 29 regions can vote online for the first time.
About 112 million people in Russia aged 18 and over are eligible to vote.
People in the annexed Crimean peninsula and parts of occupied Ukraine will also take part in the vote, but Ukraine and its Western allies have condemned the move as illegal.
Millions of Russian nationals living abroad — from the Baikonur spaceport in southern Kazakhstan to the U.S. state of California — can also vote at local embassies, consulates or by mail.
The results of a poll released by the Kremlin-funded polling agency FOM on March 5 this year showed that at least 61% of Russians would "definitely" participate in the vote.
The poll showed another 16% were "likely" to vote, while only 9% would abstain.
Preliminary results are expected to be announced on March 19, with final results on March 29.
Russian official data shows that the official turnout is expected to be almost as high as in the 2018 vote, when nearly 68% of Russians voted.
In 2018, independent election monitors documented thousands of cases of electoral fraud, including ballot stuffing and "balloon voting," in which hundreds of voters were sent to multiple polling stations.
Some inspectors faced threats and were denied access to polling stations.
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, an international election observer, said the vote was "overly controlled" and "lacked real competition." The report said authorities forced government employees, military personnel and law enforcement officers to vote for Putin.
Observers of Russian politics have little hope that the vote will be conducted in a free and fair manner.
Putin is running as an independent candidate because the ruling United Russia party is widely seen as corrupt and ineffective.
The late opposition leader Navalny called it "a party of liars and thieves."
Other candidates are seen as puppets – involved only to show how “popular” Putin is.
One of them was Nikolay Kharitonov from the Russian Communist Party. He was on the 2004 ballot and finished a distant second.

title: Shpilkin's Razor: How A Statistical Model Raises Questions About Putin's Election. Again.
content:
"Never before have we seen a presidential campaign that fell so far short of constitutional standards," Golos, a now-banned election watchdog organization, wrote in its summary report.
Asked by RFE/RL about the journalists' findings, Shpilkin, who last month was designated a "foreign agent" under a punitive Russian law aimed at restricting the work of journalists, civil society activists, and others, declined to comment.

In 2012, Shpilkin won a top Russian political science award for his work on the previous year's parliamentary election.

Outcomes Foretold

For Kremlin experts in and out of Russia, the outcome of the three-day election, which concluded on March 17, was never in doubt. The Kremlin had engineered the campaign to exclude even the semblance of a genuine challenge: A former lawmaker named Boris Nadezhdin who espoused an anti-war political stance while refraining from criticizing the Ukraine invasion, was prevented from appearing on the ballot based on a technicality.

The three contenders who did appear on the ballot were lawmakers or political figures who never criticized Putin or adopted positions that significantly differed from the incumbent's.
The man many Russians saw as a real political threat to Putin -- Aleksei Navalny -- had been shuffled in and out of punishment cells in remote prisons since being arrested in 2021. On February 16, Navalny was found dead in an Arctic prison, prompting an outpouring of outrage and grief.

Months ahead of the vote, the newspaper Kommersant and the news outlet Meduza, citing unnamed officials, said the Kremlin department responsible for overseeing the election had set a target of 70 percent voter turnout and for the winning candidate to get at least 75 percent of the vote.

In the days ahead of the vote, the state-funded pollster VTsIOM issued a survey predicting Putin would receive 82 percent of the vote, with 71 percent turnout.

Official results, announced on March 18 by the Central Election Commission, whose head is a loyal Kremlin appointee, showed that with 100 percent of ballots tallied, Putin had received 87.3 percent of the votes.
input:
"Never before have we seen a presidential campaign that fell so far short of constitutional standards," Golos, a now-banned election watchdog organization, wrote in its summary report.
Asked by RFE/RL about the journalists' findings, Shpilkin, who last month was designated a "foreign agent" under a punitive Russian law aimed at restricting the work of journalists, civil society activists, and others, declined to comment.

In 2012, Shpilkin won a top Russian political science award for his work on the previous year's parliamentary election.

Outcomes Foretold

For Kremlin experts in and out of Russia, the outcome of the three-day election, which concluded on March 17, was never in doubt. The Kremlin had engineered the campaign to exclude even the semblance of a genuine challenge: A former lawmaker named Boris Nadezhdin who espoused an anti-war political stance while refraining from criticizing the Ukraine invasion, was prevented from appearing on the ballot based on a technicality.

The three contenders who did appear on the ballot were lawmakers or political figures who never criticized Putin or adopted positions that significantly differed from the incumbent's.
The man many Russians saw as a real political threat to Putin -- Aleksei Navalny -- had been shuffled in and out of punishment cells in remote prisons since being arrested in 2021. On February 16, Navalny was found dead in an Arctic prison, prompting an outpouring of outrage and grief.

Months ahead of the vote, the newspaper Kommersant and the news outlet Meduza, citing unnamed officials, said the Kremlin department responsible for overseeing the election had set a target of 70 percent voter turnout and for the winning candidate to get at least 75 percent of the vote.

In the days ahead of the vote, the state-funded pollster VTsIOM issued a survey predicting Putin would receive 82 percent of the vote, with 71 percent turnout.

Official results, announced on March 18 by the Central Election Commission, whose head is a loyal Kremlin appointee, showed that with 100 percent of ballots tallied, Putin had received 87.3 percent of the votes.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
content:
”英国伦敦国王学院战争研究系现代战争研究教授大卫·贝茨（David Betz）近日告诉澎湃新闻，“因为其经济强劲，普京政府在政治上是安全的，俄罗斯军队正进行有效的战斗，且伤亡率不会对社会造成严重的影响，同时俄罗斯的军事工业正在全面生产新武器。”
András Tóth-Czifra在他撰写的报告中也认为，俄罗斯国内政治的稳定得到了保证，因为有足够数量的选民和精英开始相信战争不可避免，而且胜利已经接近了；而与此同时，俄罗斯政府需要维持国际社会的看法，即俄罗斯人已经做好了长期战争的准备。
“即使俄罗斯政府作了巨大的努力，俄罗斯的军事生产能力也即将达到顶峰，俄罗斯也没有无限的可能性来增加10倍或20倍的产量，并继续在这条道路上年复一年。”乌克兰经济和政治研究中心外交关系和国际安全项目联席主任阿列克谢·梅尔尼克（Oleksiy Melnyk）持不同意见，他日前告诉澎湃新闻，“这是因为如果你用你的预算或你的工业能力来支持战争，那么你肯定要减少其他民用项目上的生产。”
当地时间2024年3月15日，俄罗斯莫斯科，2024年俄罗斯总统选举期间，选民在投票站投票。

不同阶层的体感和新加入的中产群体
而在更广泛的社会层面，俄罗斯民众的心态和情绪也在发生微妙的变化。俄著名独立民调机构列瓦达中心主任丹尼斯·沃尔科夫（Denis Volkov）今年初撰文认为，尽管受到特别军事行动、西方制裁和部分动员的冲击，根据民调结果，三分之二的受访者认为2023年比较成功，是自2000年以来的最高值。
该调查显示，"工资和养老金上涨"连续第二年跻身年度十大事件之列。民众对经济形势的积极评价很可能得到了"特别军事行动"相关费用的支持，因为这些费用比大多数俄罗斯人的月收入高出数倍。一位受访者在被问及最近她的生活究竟有哪些改善时说："我儿子在打仗，他寄钱回来。”
俄罗斯问题专家格尔曼教授告诉澎湃新闻，俄罗斯政府向经济注入了大量资金，这促进了军工和其他一些行业的收入增加，因此许多人的经济状况并没有那么糟糕。
translation:
David Betz, professor of modern war studies at the Department of War Studies at King's College London, recently told The Paper, "Because of its strong economy, the Putin government is politically safe, and the Russian army is fighting effectively, and The casualty rate will not have a serious impact on society, and Russia's military industry is in full production of new weapons. "
András Tóth-Czifra also believes in his report that the stability of Russian domestic politics is guaranteed because a sufficient number of voters and elites have begun to believe that war is inevitable and victory is close; at the same time, the Russian government needs Maintaining the international community's perception that the Russians are prepared for a protracted war.
"Even with the great efforts of the Russian government, Russia's military production capabilities are about to reach their peak, and Russia does not have unlimited possibilities to increase production 10 or 20 times and continue on this path year after year." Oleksiy Melnyk, co-director of the Foreign Relations and International Security Project at the Ukrainian Economic and Political Research Center, disagrees. He recently told The Paper, “This is because if you use your budget or your industry capabilities to support the war effort, then you definitely have to reduce production on other civilian projects.”
On March 15, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, voters cast their votes at a polling station during the 2024 Russian presidential election.

Feelings of different classes and the newly joined middle class group
At the broader social level, the mentality and emotions of the Russian people are also undergoing subtle changes. Denis Volkov, director of the Levada Center, a well-known Russian independent polling agency, wrote an article earlier this year that despite the impact of special military operations, Western sanctions and partial mobilization, according to poll results, two-thirds of Respondents considered 2023 to be relatively successful, with the highest value since 2000.
The survey revealed that "wage and pension rises" were among the top 10 events of the year for the second year running. The public's positive assessment of the economic situation is likely supported by the costs associated with "special military operations", since these costs are several times higher than the monthly income of most Russians. One interviewee, asked how her life had improved recently, said: "My son is at war and he sends money back."
Professor Herman, an expert on Russia, told The Paper that the Russian government has injected a large amount of money into the economy, which has promoted the increase in income in the military industry and some other industries, so the economic situation of many people is not that bad.

"
András Tóth-Czifra also believes in his report that the stability of Russian domestic politics is guaranteed because a sufficient number of voters and elites have begun to believe that war is inevitable and victory is close; at the same time, the Russian government needs Maintaining the international community's perception that the Russians are prepared for a protracted war.
"Even with the great efforts of the Russian government, Russia's military production capabilities are about to reach their peak, and Russia does not have unlimited possibilities to increase production 10 or 20 times and continue on this path year after year." Oleksiy Melnyk, co-director of the Foreign Relations and International Security Project at the Ukrainian Economic and Political Research Center, disagrees. He recently told The Paper, “This is because if you use your budget or your industry capabilities to support the war effort, then you definitely have to reduce production on other civilian projects.”
